column2: To music, speeches and some exuberant student shenanigans, a peripatetic monument made a comeback on the campus of Yale University last night.

A spokesman for President Ford said today it would be up to the House Judiciary Committee to decide whether it wanted Mr. Ford to answer further questions on his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon.

The Democratic National Committee presented today a special award to Frank Wills, the security guard who discovered the break-in at committee headquarters in June, 1972, and set in motion the events of the Watergate scandal.

President Ford signed into law today a $3-billion housing aid bill that could finance up to 100,000 home purchases. The measure, called the Emergency Home Purchase Assistance Act of 1974, is aimed at helping people buy single houses through conventional loans, rather than rich Government-assisted plans as G.I. and F.H.A. financing. It would not help the condominium, cooperative or rental markets.
After their first victory in the National Hockey League, members of the Washington Capitals. were this excited: "They were measuring one another for ring sizes.

A report that an Arab consortium was negotiating to buy the International Business Machines Corporation caused a flurry of buying yesterday of the giant computer company's stock-on European markets as well as on the New York Stock Exchange.
When the special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, announced his resignation last Saturday, effective Oct. 25, he said that the "bulk" of the investigations was over.

Representative Joseph J. Mariziti, Republican of the 13th District, issued a statement today in which he said the woman he hired as a research assistant on his Congressional payroll earned $19,970 working on a "project" basis over the last 20 months.

If public opinion were polled as to who was the best-loved living American artist, Alexander Calder would be way up near the top. As an artist, as a man and as a citizen, Mr. Calder has deserved well of us all. Yet in the magazines that pride themselves on being up to the minute, you'll get shown the door if you mention his name.

Perth Amboy's public high school, which was closed for two days this week because of student disturbances, will reopen next Monday under what Mayor Alexander F. Jakowski termed today "a hard-nosed plan to prevent troubles on the city's streets from interfering with our education system any longer."

United States Representative Robert, H. Steele, the Republican candidate for Governor, charged his Democratic opponent today with having threatened the jobs of thousands of workers in Connecticut, by her criticisms of the state's electric utilities.

More than two dozen parents and children who were protesting the ouster of the principal at Public School 34 on the Lower East Side by occupying his office left peaceably yesterday afternoon after having been threatened with arrests.
Recent disclosures of wrongdoing in thoroughbred racing here have touched off inquiries by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and three other agencies.
The nation's mutual funds sold more shares than they redeemed for investors in September, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

A year ago the Brooklyn Museum treated us to the appetizer-the superb Donald S. Morrison collection of English 18th-century silver. The assemblage of 80 pots, salts, bowls and salvers emphasizes Huguenot

An investigation into grafttaking by a "sergeants' club" in another police precinct in Queens has been started by agents of the special state prosecutor, Maurice H..Nadjari. The existence of the inquiry at the 107th Precinct in Fresh Meadows .was disclosed yesterday when departmental charges were filed against Lieut,

This is the 250th anniversary of Remy Martin, one of the great names in Cognac. This makes the company older than George Washington and a great deal older than the United States. All of which calls for something special in the way of a birthday celebration.
off four straight games today after losing the first eight and went on to beat Jan Kodes, 0-6, 9-7, 7-5, in the quarterfinals of the Spanish open tennis tournament.
The 1974 World Series was over, with the Oakland A's crowned as champions for the third straight year, but the comments still shimmered in the warm California air today. Such as:
Two more major extensions of Amtrak's rail passenger network--a Washington to Denver route and a link from Portland, Ore. through Idaho to Ogden, Utah--appear ready for formal announcement soon.
Toufic Mizrahi, who in 1929 founded Le Commerce du Levant, an economic and financial newspaper in Beirut, Lebanon, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Brussels on Oct. 5. He was 75 years old.
The trend to lower short-term interest rates in the money markets continued yesterday with a new round of reductions in the prime rate by several of the nation's leading commercial banks.
Harry Furst, who retired in 1970 as general manager for Consolidated Theaters here, died today at Stamford Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 126 Hoyt Street.
Lewis F. Gittler, who wrote extensively on Germany, died of a cerebral hemorrhage in Mount Sinai Hospital on Thursday evening. He was 60 years old and lived at 50 West 96th Street.

They used to say that not even God could defeat Wilbur D. Mills in an Arkansas election. That has changed. The Lord is now given a slight edge. The chief cause of the shift in allegiance was the evening of Oct. 6, when Mr. Mills,

The Government announced today it had ordered 27 top executives at the KimberlyClark Corporatioon to pay back an average of $17,294 apiece for bonuses they received while salaries were subject to Federal controls.

The development of European painting in the period since World War II has sometimes been difficult to keep in proper focus on this side of the Atlantic. American painting became an international force in these
Moon See Kwang, who tried to assassinate President Park Chung Hee of South Korea and killed his wife instead, was sentenced to death today.

Representative Hugh L. Carey said yesterday that New York State was in serious trouble on its housing and would need 200,000 new units a year "just to keep pace with new families and the rate of worn-out old units."
The trend to lower short-term interest rates in the money markets continued yesterday with a new round of reductions in the prime rate by several of the nation's leading commercial banks.

The Roman Catholic priest at the of the thinly disguised movement to oust President Nguyen Van Thieu reckons that 3,000 South Vietnamese colonels and lieutenant colonels have passed through his courses on anti-Communist psychological warfare.

Published reports that Saudi Arabia has joined other oil-exporting countries in raising tax and royalty payments on exports by foreign oil companies were denied today by a high Saudi Arabian petroleum source.

Louis Oshman, for many years owner of the Cedars Country Club in Lakeville, Conn., and a founder and former chairman of the Roberts shoe repair chain in New York and New Jersey, died Thursday at his home in Mount Vernon, N. Y. His age was 84.

Some signs of progress developed yesterday in the legal, ownership and players' salary problems of the financially-plagued Florida Blazers and Portland Storm of the World Football League. In Orlando, Fla., attorneys for the league and the Blazers said the team had been sold, effective next Friday, but declined to name the new owners.

Thirty-five states' and the District of Columbia have been told that they will receive $43.5-million less in Federal funds than they had requested to pay welfare recipients during the last half of this year.
The sponsors of a new system for heating and cooling buildings with the sun's rays believe it overcomes two usual drawbacks - the high

The.Rev. Maurice P. Lenihan, founding pastor in 1952 of the Roman Catholic parish of Our Lady of Fatima in Jackson Heights, Queens, died Monday in St. John's Hospital, Elmhurst, Queens, at the age of 75.
This season, for the first time, television programing for children on Saturday morning is showing improvement, according to the leader of a movement to win such changes.

The Union Carbide Corporation, the nation's second largest chemical producer after E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc, reported yesterday third-quarter earnings that were the highest for any quarter in its history. The nine months' profit exceeded any annual period.

The valet and maid long in service to the family of Richard M. Nixon have not been on the Federal Government payroll since Oct. 5, it was announced yesterday. The couple, Manolo and Fina Sanchez, had been listed on the payroll of the National Park Service at annual salaries of $13,000 and $8,000 respectively. The Sanchezes,1
Benjamin Britten's "Death in Venice," his most recent opera, received its first American performance last night at the Metropolitan Opera, and it was a genuine event.

The Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive was closed in both directions from Houston Street to the Bronx early this morning after the police found a stolen car containing 120 pounds of ammonium nitrate-a high explosive.

Following is the court transcript of a recording of a conversation between President Nixon and John W. Dean 3d, then his counsel, in-'the Oval Office on March 17, 1973, introduced as evidence in the Watergate cover-up trial today:
To music, speeches and some exuberant student shenanigans, a peripatetic monument made a comeback on the campus of Yale University last night.

A youthful lawyer who represented a man charged with finding and keeping $50,000 in ransom money intended for the kidnappers of an 8-year-old Dix Hills, L.I. boy last March testified today that an F.B.T. agent had instructed him on how his client should "launder" the money and secretly return it in order to be immune from prosecution.

I affixed my powerful WIN button to lapel and went to the White House chanting, "Whip inflation now!" "You have an idea for reducing America's self-indulgent waste, as urged by President Ford, to help whip inflation now?" asked a helmeted aide in the war against inflation.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered a new Democratic party primary election in the Second Councilmanic District, ni lower Manhattan, where Miriam Friedlander won by a plurality of 95 votes in the Sept. 10 balloting.
Superior Court Judge Herbert Horn said today that he would issue an injunction against the incarceration of youths under age 16 in the Cape May County Jail.

If you nappen to be going to Zaire for the George Foreman-Muhammad Ali fight on Oct. 30, I've got a couple of gastronomical hints for you. You won't have much trouble finding the best restaurants in Kinshasa-there aren't all that many-and you and a friend won't have much trouble dropping $50 for lunch, either, in the best hotels or at the Brussels.

Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller disclosed tonight that, as a result of an Internal Revenue Service audit of his Federal income and gift takes for the last five years, he must pay $820,718 additional in Federal income taxes and $83,000 more in gift taxes--a total of $903,718.
You could have fooled us Thursday night at the City Center, where Gerald Arpino's ballet "The Relativity of Icarus" was given its local premiere by the City Center Joffrey Ballet.

Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry, Yasuhiro Nakasone, said today he saw no need to relax the Government's stringent tight-money policy intended to fight the nation's cancerous inflation.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto is strengthening his grip on Pakistan, a splintered, troubled but economically resilient nation.

For months last year and the year before, hundreds of buyers flocked to Sleepy Hollow Lake here, lured by a sales campaign that promised a second home in the country near what it said was the largest manmade recreational lake in the state.

Eight of the nation's leading dye manufacturers, including E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., entered no contest pleas today to a criminal charge of conspiring to drive out competition in the multimillion-dollar dye industry over the last four years.
The body of Diana Schoonnaker, 16 years old, of Napanoch, was found forced into a garbage can at a landfill site two miles from this village.
The way many residents talk about Malba, the neighborhood had only one real problem and that one went away.

Herbert E. Harper, who retired in 1971 as president of the Public Service Coordinated Transport Company, now Transport of New Jersey, the state's largest bus concern, died Thursday in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in Verona, N.J.
George Allen may know more about the New York Giants than the Giants know about themselves. Two former members of the New York offense this year, Larance Jones and Charlie Evans,
When daytime soap operas moved from radio to television in the early nineteen-fifties, they retained the accustomed 15-minute format. In 1956,
Viktor G. Polsky, a Jewish activist, was convicted by a Moscow district court early today of reckless driving and was fined 100 rubles for having struck a young woman with his car.

President and Mrs. Ford added levity to a Civil Service ceremony today, with the alling Betty Ford pretending to toss a football to her laughing husband. The President led 16 Civil Service award winners into the White House: Rose Garden to honor their selection as "our top people."

Representative Joseph J. Maraziti, Republican of the 13th District, issued a statement today in which he said the woman he hired as a research assistant on his Congressional payroll earned $19,970 working on a "project basis" over the last 20 months.
The former head of a Brooklyn antipoverty agency was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of possessing hijacked truck cargoes.

The State Court of Appeals in Albany yesterday reversed a State Supreme Court decision that had removed the names of 19Liberal party candidates from the November ballot for Senatorial contests around the city.

Cary Dixon, daughter of Theodore P. Dixon Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., and the late Eugenia Carton Dixon, was, married last night to Scott Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs.. William Johnson of Windsor, Conn.
Despite the President's appeal for price restraint, prices are rising from 5 per cent to as much as 30 per cent on a wide variety of consumer goods to be sold this winter and next spring.
About four weeks ago Baron Edmond de Rothschild received a telephone call from a business associate who was worried about unauthorized foreign deposits of an Israeli investment company.
The 9-year-old son of a Watergate cover-up defendant, Kenneth W. Parkinson, was seriously burned yesterday when he and some friends were trying to set a turtle on fire, the police reported.

In the last 17 years, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, made substantial real-estate investments here, according to the Suffolk County Clerk's and Tax Assessor's offices.

President Ford is faced with a decision on whether to resubmit to the Senate three controversial nominations, two of them originally made by President Nixon, that are among more than 40 such appointments that will die a procedural death during the Congressional recess that began yesterday.

Charlie Joseph is going back to his first love this fall and Seton Hall University soccer rivals may wish that he had forgotten all about it. Joseph is the 22-year-old Trinidadian who last spring swept the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletic of America sprint titles, breaking the 220-yard record set 23 years earlier by another Seton Hall star,

Senator Henry M. Jackson in an announcement made at the White House, said that President Ford and Congress had formally agreed on a compromise to provide trade benefits to the Soviet Union. In return, he said, there will be a substantial relaxation in Moscow's emigration policies.
European Communist parties agreed today to hold a highlevel conference next year in East Berlin after Soviet plans for a world party congress aimed against China apparently fell through.
A college girl who died while exercising apparently had the same rare hereditary heart disease that killed her sister 10 days before, the county coroner said today.

The Office of Neighborhood Government, regarded by former Mayor John V. Lindsay as one of the most promising innovations of his eight years in office, is facing a drastic reorganization that, according to high agency officials, represents the virtual abandonment of the city's drive for decentralization.

Mardell Wilkiris, who hasn't won in three years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, overcame some putting troubles today. She carded a three-under-par 70 and took a one-stroke lead after the first orund of a $35,000 tournament.

BASEBALL goes on, essentially unaltered, though the nation itself goes through violent historical upheavals and the times are always changing. Violence is on the land today. But the game of baseball remains its peaceful self. It's constant, enduring, and links the century together in our land--the twentieth century, when so much happened and baseball remained essentially placid in the midst of all. It's dependable, and goes on. Fashions come and go, and wars,
A bond dealing concern was convicted today of a "horrible, vicious, brutal and diabolical" fraud of 20 to 30 Vietnam prisoners of war, the Securities and Exchange Commission said.

France has presented to her partners in the European Common Market proposals for closer political ties. But the ideas, which run counter to French policies of the Gaullist era, have stirred little enthusiasm in member countries.
Herbert Walther, longtime New York City editor and publisher of trade magazines, died yesterday at the Mary Heart Nursing Home near his home hire. He was 69 years old.

The economy keeps sliding downhill, but the Administration still insists there is no recession. The nation's total output of goods and services has declined for three consecutive quarters, the longest dip since the end of the Eisenhower Administration well over a decade ago.

The doctors treating Margaretta (Happy) Rockefeller announced yesterday that the completion of laboratory examination had disclosed no evidence of any spread of cancer beyond the malignant areas removed during radical surgery Thursday.

Bowie Kuhn, the baseball commissioner, came out against casino gambling in an interview on a Princeton radio station. He said approval of a state casino referendum in the Nov. 5 election could lead to gambling on athletic events that would undermine the public's confidence in baseball and other sports. Mr. Kuhn, who lives in Ridgewood, also said he felt casinos "will open the doors to organized crime."

The New York and American Stock Exchanges this week issued their latest reports on changes in stockholdings by leading shareholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following:
Irate Harlem parents kept 1,000 pupils out of Public School 46 yesterday but, heeding a police warning, abandoned their attempt to prevent teachers from entering.

A group of neighborhood businessmen has formed a committee to get Broadway reopened to traffic between 135th and 145th Streets, in an effort to recoup losses resulting from a water main break at 137th Street.

After their first victory in the National Hockey League, member of the Washington Capitals were this excited: "They were measuring one another for ring sizes. It was like they took the Stanley Cup," said Lefty McFadden,

The record for the world's longest bridge game with scores fully recorded may well belong to a quartet from Sea Girt, N. J. Robert Burke reports the current standings in his regular beach foursome, which includes Frank O'Connor and Mr. and Mrs. Albert Catalane.

A city is more than the sum of its buildings. The image evoked by the words London, Paris or New York is unique and irreplaceable-except to those who trade in destruction and change. The 'work of a Landmarks Commission is to protect that total image as much as single structures, and New York has been moving in thoughtful, creative ways to a kind of environmental or cultural preservation.
The public debate between President Ford and Congress about suspending American military aid to Turkey, though not very enlightening, did serve one useful purpose.

Earl L. Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, said today he expected an announcement soon of a new grain deal to the Soviet Union, divided into smaller shipments instead of one huge lump to avoid increas-. ing food prices.
In the Stepping Stone at Churchill Downs last April, Accipiter threw his jockey at the start, then ran the seven furlongs well ahead of all the others, for no reward, of course.
More than 450 National Guard troops will remain on stand-by duty in and around this city at least through the early part of next week, aides to Gov. Francis W. Sargent said today.
About four weeks ago Baron Edmond de Rothschild received a telephone call from a business associate who was worried about unauthorized foreign deposits of an Israeli investment company.

Nearly a million persons are close to starvation and need emergency water supplies in the vast arid Ogaden region of east central Ethiopia, the Ethiopian News Agency said today, quoting a provincial. official.

About do years ago, Charles T. Grace, thinking back to his ancestral home in County Cork, Ireland, began to make a 7-foot high, sevenroom castle. He never finished it, but his grandson, A. Tobias Grace, did last spring.
Representatives of African countries today demanded South Africa's expulsion from the United Nations as the Security Council began reviewing South Africa's relationship with the world organization.

Alvin Dark's assignment had been cruelly simple: Win the World Series, and in less than seven games. Anything less would be short of success, and not winning it at all would be total failure, even if a first-place finish in the division and an American League pennant in the playoff preceded the Series. Dark won the Series in five.

Ernie DiGregorio scored 33 points and Bob McAdoo 28 in leading the Buffalo Braves to a 126-119 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight, spoiling the season opener for the defending National Basketball Association champions.

A labor dispute involving uniformed police and firemen and the city administration here has taken an unusual twist, with bands of off-duty men staging daily, good-natured picketing of Mayor Paul T. Jordan at his home, at City Hall and at all his public appearances.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said last night that the controversial plan to extend its PATH rapidtransit line from Newark to Newark International Airport and then another 15 miles to Plainfield, N. J., "is being deplayed."
Sparked by a reduction in the prime rate by two major banks early in the session, the stock market managed to maintain most of its gains, and finished higher in heavier trading.
The allowable limit for oil exports to the United States has been set at 977,950 barrels a day for November, down from one million barrels a year ago, the National Energy Board said today.
They used to say that not even God could defeat Wilbur D. Mills in an Arkansas election. That has changed. The Lord is now given a slight edge.

Members of the City Planning Commission are entirely justified in complaining about the Board of Education's tendency to rubber-stamp costly project proposals by local communities. Such acquiescence may temporarily win friends; but to leave the budget-cutting to a host of non-educational city agencies can only have the effect of substituting political for educational criteria in the ultimate budget-cutting decisions.

Senator James L. Buckley, units. sharing the speakers' rostrum with Governor Wilson at the annual dinner of the State Conservative party last night, called for a new alignment of American political parties along ideological lines.
Twenty-seven paintings valued at $800,000 were stolen from a castle belonging to the British art critic Sir Douglas Cooper, the police reported today.
Bjorn Borg reeled off four straight games today after losing the first eight and went on to beat Jan Kodes, 0-6, 9-7, 7-5, in the quarterfinals of the Spanish open tennis tournament.

British troops killed today the 17-year-old son of an Irish Republican Army man who died in an explosion two years ago. And a bombing outside a school in a Roman Catholic area of Belfast injured 12 persons, including several children, authorities said.
"It's too good to be true," said Aleksandr Slepak, a skeptical young man wearing Western blue jeans, as he called to his mother and told her the news.
Harry S. Truman played the piano for Lauren Bacall there. Nikita Khrushchev warned the West from its platform that "we will bury you." President Ford is on the waiting list for membership.
Terry Diehl, a long shot and the last man on the course, romped in with a seven-under-par-65 and took the second-round lead today in the $125,000 San AntonioTexas open golf tournament.

Traders on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market sent prices up slightly again yesterday. The Amex market-value index rose 0.07 to 69.05. A total of 1.96-million shares were traded yesterday, up from 1.75 million Thursday.

Modern composers have not given ballet much of a chance in opera-probably for sound enough reason. Imagine a Soldiers' Dance in "Wozzeck" or a folk divertissement in "Katya Kabanova." The trend of contemporary opera has been toward naturalism.

Otto O. Binder, a science writer long associated with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and who had published more than 40 books on space and allied subjects, died Monday. He was 63 years old and lived in Chestertown, N.Y.
DILI, Portuguese Timor--A strange apparition known as "decolonization" has unexpectedly manifested itself here over Portugal's most remote and neglected territory.

COMMENT Rams' football trying to move ahead while Hofstra's is nearing breakdown. This can answer question of what team is best of Met small college elevens. Indians, Seahawks coming off lopsided losses to pair of Connecticut teams.

Lindsay as one of the most promising innovations of his eight years in office, is facing a drastic reorganization that, according to high agency officials, represents the virtual abandonment of the city's drive for decentralization.
TEL AVIV, Israel-The philosopher Heraclitus, who lived north of here on the Asia Minor coast, realized 2,500 years ago that one can' never step into the same river twice because the water changes.

A number of words were omitted in The New York Times yesterday in the text of one of the questions in a resolution of inquiry that figured in President Ford's appearance before a House Judiciary subcommittee.

Albert W. Byrnes, president of the Byrnes Express and Trucking Company and a vice presidents of the Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburgh, died yesterday in Victory Memorial Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 961 East 37th Street, Brooklyn.

Earnings performance in the banking industry has seldom diverged so sharply as it has this year, and some analysts conclude that the difference among banking institutionsthe so-called two-tier systemis going to widen, not narrow, in the future.

Under prodding from President Giscard d'Estaing, French management and labor have initiated 'a plan to assure- unemployed workers that they will suffer no loss in normal take-home pay for a full year.

Environmental activists, in the third national election in which the conservation vote is playing a significant role, are zeroing in on a score of House races, Senate contests in three states, and a race for a governorship.

When a new coach is hired to rejuvenate a sagging and tired college football team fans always want to know just how long it is going to take him to reach his goals. Athletic directors give these coaches three, four or five year contracts depending on how impatient they are for success.

There is a specter haunting the world-the specter of food shortages, widespread hunger and, in some areas, mass starvation. It is. a terrible and complex problem because it involves millions of human lives.

Senator Henry M. Jackson in an announcement made at the White House, said that President Ford and Congress had formally agreed on a compromise to provide trade benefits to the Soviet Union. In return, he said, there will be a substantial relaxation in Moscow's emigration policies.

A 78-year-old widow walking lear her home here late yesterday afternoon was killed by in assailant who pulled a hatchet from a green canvas bag, struck her across the lead with it and fled with $2 from her pocketbook.
Dorothy Biddle Johnson, a writer and lecturer on flower arrangement, died yesterday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 87 years old and lived in Pleasantville, N.Y.

Joseph C. Brennan, president of the Savings Banks Association of New York, said yesterday that the effect of the Treasury Department's upcoming $2.5-billion financing "is virtually to guarantee the continued scarcity of private mortgage funds."

The Episcopal Church's House of Bishops has endorsed the principle of ordination of women to priesthood despite the recent controversy over 11 women whose ordination was subsequently said to be invalid.

Voters, of California are about to Elect a relatively radical Governor -- relatively radical, that is, in terms of the man he will succeed, Ronald Reagan. The description fits both of the two leading candidates for the election Nov. 5.
Jerry Byers, a rookie playing in place of the injured Jacques Richard, scored his first National Hockey League goal and assisted on another tonight to lead Atlanta to a 4-2 victory over Kansas City.

The championship flag was hoisted over the home of the Oakland A's today for the third straight year, while observers of the most provocative team in baseball wondered about the future of several key players, Manager Alvin Dark and even the site of the franchise.

Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller disclosed tonight that, as a result of an Internal Revenue Service audit of his Federal income and gift taxes for the last five years, he must pay $820,718 additional in Federal income taxes and $83,000 more in gift taxes--a total of $903,718.
The Soviet Union and Egypt agreed today to support the creation of a Palestinian state as a prerequisite for an over-all peaceful settlement In the Middle East.
A former girl friend dumped a pan of scalding grits on Al Green, a popular singer, today as he was getting out of the bathtub and then apparently shot herself to death.

An Oregon judge who said "they call me where I come from the fastest gavel in the West" took 18 minutes yesterday to hear and dismiss on his own motion a conflict-of-interest suit against Governor Wilson as lacking Federal jurisdiction.

To the Editor: Your excellent news series on nurs, ing homes highlights once again what previous investigations and exposes have documented: that a large segment of the aged, the parents and grandparents of many of us, are spending their last years in degrading, debilitating conditions, suffering physical discomfiture and mental abuse.

George N. Farrand, who retired in 1968 as financial vice president and treasurer of Young Rubicam, Inc., the advertising agency, after 20 years of service, died Thursday at his home, 34 Club Road, Upper Montclair, N. J. He was 64 years old.

As we add more and more noise-making appliances and mechanized conveniences to our homes (washing machines, vacuum cleaners, television sets, hi-fi equipment, electric toys, air conditioners, etc.), and as houses are built closer and closer together with a corresponding increase in neighborhood traffic and other street noises, the increase in unwanted noise inside the home has become an annoying problem to many people.

Secretary of State Kissinger will carry to Moscow next week "concrete propositions" on how to break the deadlock in the Soviet-American talks on strategic nuclear arms, according to Administration officials.

For more than a decade Rebekah Harkness has been pouring dollars into ballet. Ballet has not received anything of any particularly lasting value from this, so one trusts that Mrs. Harkness has. had a swell trip, A few days ago the Comptroller of the Harkness Ballet Foundation, Theodore Bartwink, announced that the Harkness Ballet was on the skids.
Margaretta Rockefeller was in excellent condition and spirits on the third day of recovery from breast surgery, the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases reported yesterday.

Lorene Claire Stefan, a mortgage-loan officer with the Chemical Bank of New York, and Peter Young Gevalt, a senior associate of the Eastdil Realty Company, Inc., were married yesterday afternoon at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, N. Y.
Dr. and Mrs. Robert Peter Nenno of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Louise Nenno, to Carmen George Biller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Biller of Westfield.

To the Editor:. Since the founding of the United Nations in 1945, only one man who did not represent a member state has addressed the General Assembly-Pope Paul VI, spiritual leader of the Roman Catholic Church and the head of a sovereign state, Vatican City.
Undefeated Delaware moved 36 yards for a touchdown early in the third quarter today to defeat a stubborn Lehigh team, 14-7. Nate Beaslcy scored the decisive touchdown on a 21-yard run through center.
RIVERHEAD -- Two unusual interventions by citizens organizations are to mark the first combined state and local nuclear power plant hearing, which begins here Wednesday.

Anatoly Karpov was granted an illness postponement of the 15th game of his final candidates match with Viktor Korchnoi to pick a challenger or a successor to Bobby Fischer. The game, originally scheduled for this evening at 5 P.M., has been moved to Wednesday at the same time in Tchaikowsky Hall.
James A. Vogel, a 20-year-old Princeton University junior, was found dead in his dormitory room today after inhaling nitrous oxide, commonly known as laughing gas.
Jimmy Connors and Rod Laver, who have never met on the tennis court, will play a $100,000 winner-take-all match in January.

Several experts on tax law have said that some of the gifts made by former Governor Nelson A. Rockefeller to his friends and associates might be subject to payment of personal income taxes by the recipients. "It's a fuzzy area," said one law professor. "This situation is unique and there is just no precedent."
Egypt's Foreign Trade Ministries have drafted new laws aimed at the gradual removal of exchange controls on the Egyptian pound, the semi-official daily Al-Ahram reported today.

The officers on riot duty at Jackson State College overreacted when they fired into a dormitory on May 14, 1970, a Federal appeals court has ruled. But the three-judge panel said that the relatives of two slain youths could not recover damages from the State of Mississippi.

ESTES PARK, Colo.--This is the mating season of the elk and Rocky Mountain National Park is copiously posted with signs warning tourists to stay on the highways and well away from the herds; otherwise, there might be fewer elk for the future.

Leon Jaworski says Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., former White House chief of staff, talked him into taking the job of Watergate special prosecutor, The Los Angeles Times reports.

Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether involuntary patients in public mental hospitals have a constitutional right to receive some sort of psychiatric treatment, rather than merely custodial care.

The Concorde supersonic transport whistled into San Francisco International Airport today after an 1,880-mile flight from Mexico City in 2 hours 19 minutes. It was the sixth landing of the British-French SST in the continental United States. Hundreds watched it taxi up on its spidery landing gear.
"Miss Moffat," the musical play, has permanently closed because of the illness of Bette Davis, its star, it was disclosed yesterday by Joshua Logan and Eugene V. Wolsk, producers.

The police were searching for a killer today amid rumors that a psychopath was at large in the Soviet capital. The police confirmed only that they were looking for a young fair-haired man they said had murdered a woman.
The last of the rice is coming in now, overflowing the hoppers of the high-wheeled threshers that creep from sunrise to sunset across the muddy paddies of the Louisiana Cajun country.

The Broadway revival of the nineteen - twenties musical "Good News," starring Alice Faye and John Payne, has been postponed because the show's scenery was heavily damaged before dawn yesterday in a truck fire near Los Angeles.

The Executive Commission of the European Economic Community announced new measures today designed to reduce grain consumption and to build up reserve wheat stocks against a possible shortfall of cereal imports from the United States.
Earnings of the General Foods Corporation rose 3.6 per cent in the second fiscal quarter and 5.1 per cent in the six months ended Sept. 28, the company reported yesterday.

The Supreme Court cleaned the way today for an antitrust challenge to a multiple-bank acquisition by the Michigan National Corporation, a holding company that had successfully blocked the Government in Federal District Court.

Harold Wilson's Labor Government must tackle Britain's daunting problems with a majority of three in a House of Commons of 635.

A Byrne administration bill to extend public financing of gubernatorial campaigns to primary elections was approved in the Assembly today by a vote of 62 to 10.

Douglas Williams Barton, a retired vice president and director of the A. H. Bull Steamship Company, died Sunday at his farm in Drydon, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived at 515 Trotters Lane, Elizabeth, N. J.

Burlington Northern, Inc., the nation's largest railroad system, and the Norfolk Western Railway Company, the secondlargest coal-carrying road after the Chessie System, reported yesterday sharply higher results in the third quarter and nine months this year.

The state police issued a warning today for "a group of con men who victimize elderly women." The group was said to have moved into Connecticut after working in Maryland and New Jersey.

Manhattan is not exactly a bird sanctuary, though a surprising number of species have been seen in Central Park. But downtown, in such open spaces as the Battery and Trinity churchyard, urban bird-watchers often turn up birds that even outlanders have to look twice to find at home. Lower Manhattan seems to be a kind of crossroad on several avian air routes.

Official approval was given tonight to a controversial plan to change the face of Piccadilly Circus, the neon-lit hub of London's theater district. The decision by the Greater London Council ended almost 20 years of emotionally charged argument.
An elderly Queens landlord was bludgeoned to death last evening during a violent argument with a 20-year-old tenant who has been under treatment for mental disorders, the police charged.
The New York Stock Exchange yesterday announced that the short position in its listed shares for the month ended Oct. 15 rose by 1,951,800 shares to a total of 20,144,000.

Japanese leftists began a drive to stop President Ford's scheduled visit here next month with huge rallies all over Japan today. The organizers, led by the Communist party,

Encouraged by a 7 per cent decline in imports for the first eight months of 1974--the first such drop in more than a decade--American shoe manufacturers and suppliers are generally hopeful about regaining markets lost to foreign-made products.

William Tabbert, an actor and lyric tenor who originated the stage role of Lieut. Joseph Cable in "South Pacific," the Pulitzer Prize-winning musical, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Dallas.

A husband who is being stied for divorce by his wife is not entitled to alimony from her under New York State domestic relations law, the Appellate Division Second Department has ruled in a bitter Nassau County divorce case.

The International Olympic Committee gave an emphatic nod today to a new eligibility code which gives an athlete adequate time for training and payment for that time pending approval by the athlete's national federation.

The Government announced today that home buyers will get a larger break than originally anticipated under new Federal legislation providing low-interest loans.

The city's Human Rights Commissioner warned yesterday that racial hostility would become the central problem of New York City high schools unless there was immediate action to temper it. She urged the Board of Education, as well as individual schools, to initiate a full-scale drive aimed at preventing student racial clashes and calming neighborhood fears.

Dr. A. Robert Peskin, an internist and cardiologist, died Saturday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 2 Fifth Avenue.

Eleanor Beers Reed, widow of Henry Hope Reed Sr., a retired marine insurance executive here who became trusteein-residence at the American Farm School near Salonika, Greece, died yesterday at the school. Her age was 83.

The heads of state or government of'almost all Arab countries gather this week in Morocco for a meeting potentially so important for the chances of peace in the Middle East that officials in the United States and Israel are delaying policy decisions pending its outcome.

Presented by Richard Lee Marks, Henry jaffe and William Craver. At the Eastside Playhouse, 334 East 74th Street.

Jury selection began today in Federal District Court in the trial of eight former National Guardsmen indicted for violating the civil rights of students at Kent State University on May 4, 1970, in a confrontation in which four students were killed and nine were wounded.

A 19-year-old student walking outside her dormitory at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn died when a large panel of plywood that apparently had been blown from the roof of the 17-story dormitory building struck her on the head. Both sides in the strike by most of the 200 faculty members of Rider College in Trenton met with a state mediator in an effort to end the six-day-old dispute. Pearce Jr., the executive director of the State Mediation Board.

Hundreds of people in Harlem lined up yesterday for the opening of Muhammad's Fish House No. 1 - the latest of a series of business ventures and the first in a projected chain of 40 fish restaurants owned by the Nation of Islam.
Inez Garcia, 30 years old, was sentenced to five years to life in prison today for shooting to death the companion of a man she said had raped her.

Scientists at the Stanford Research Institute who conducted experiments with a number of persons, including Uri Geller, the magician and purported psychic, report that Mr. Geller, and probably most people, have an ability to send and receive information by some "as yet unidentified perceptual modality."
Americans may have to gel along with browner lawns nex summer so their gardens-and farms--can be greener, the chairman of the Fertilizer Insti tute says.

Air pollution caused some $12.3-billion damage to human health and property in 1970, the Environmental Protection Agency estimated today. The agency said its estimate for 1970, the latest available.

A wounded holdup man waiting to have his hand X-rayed after being shot by the police, bolted from the two officers who had captured him last night and led them on a wild chase through the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, and out onto the street, where he managed to make good his escape by ducking down one subway entrance and darting out another.

Premier Fidel Castro has said that he sees "positive" hope for closer relations between Cuba and the United States because President Ford "is not involved with the Cuban counter-revolutionary elements."
A medical examiner says that an autopsy confirms that a spurned woman died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound after she scalded Al Green, the pop singer with hot grits.

President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico confirmed at a meeting with President Ford today that substantial amounts of oil had been discovered in southeast Mexico and said that it would be put on the world market when developed.

Scientists at the Stanford Research Institute who conducted experiments with a number of persons, including Uri Geller, the magician and purported psychic, report that Mr. Geller, and probably most people, have an ability to send and receive information by some "as yet unidentified perceptual modality."
Police Chief William Hiler was making a routine search through the house of Jim Holloran; 68-year-old bachelor who died earlier this month, when he spotted a locked fishing tackle box.
The accusatory tone intensified in the campaign for United States Senator yesterday as Senator Jacob K. Javits and Ramsey Clark, his Democratic opponent, charged each other with a lack of integrity.

President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico has confirmed in talks with President Ford that a substantial amount of oil has been discovered in his country and will be put on the world market when it can be developed. Mr. Echeverria, who with Mr. Ford visited along the Mexican-American border, said the find would be a boon to the Mexican economy. [Page 1, Column 8.]
Governor Byrne today vetoed legislation that would have required publication in daily newspapers of a notice of the acquittal of defendants in criminal cases.
Air in the Philadelphia area is about 38 per cent cleaner than it was nine years ago, environmental and health groups reported today.

Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities. The average rate for the three-month bill was 7.524 per cent, down from 7.722 per cent in the sale on Friday, Oct. 11.

AQUEBOGUE, L. I.--The soft, insistent humming of the huge antipollution devices on Lloyd W. Corwin Jr.'s 100-acre duck farm here is just as familiar to him these days as is the constant quacking of his million ducks.
A tentative agreement was reached yesterday in a mechanics' strike that has grounded National Airlines planes for 98 days. It was not known when normal operations would resume.

The European - American Bank and Trust Company will close the London branch formerly operated by the Franklin National Bank within a week or two, Klaus Jacobs, vice chairman of European-American, said yesterday.

The Finance Ministers of the Common Market agreed this evehing on a plan under which the pine member countries could jointly borrow up to $3-billion from oil-producing countries to help members cover balanceof-payments deficits caused by oil imports.

The six people who died here Saturday night in a methodical execution-style murder were drawn to their deaths together by the merest chance. Each set out from home Saturday night in a different direaction and for a different purpose.

Imelda R. Marcos, the First Lady of the Philippines, who was received more attentively in China last month than most visiting heads of state, attributes her welcome there to a shared "Orientalness" that she discovered in conversations with Chiang Ching, wife of Chairman Mao Tse-tung.

A House subcommittee report released last weekend prophesies mass starvation and a world food crisis more severe than the' current energy crisis if present trends in population and food production are not changed. Over the same weekend the Administration announced plans for grain sales to the Soviet Union, somewhat scaled down from the ones recently canceled at President Ford's urging, but still very substantial.

District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan yesterday accused Owen McGivern, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, of an effort "to cover up the improprieties" in the seelection of members to elite sheriff's jury panels.

State Senate gave final approval today for a legislative investigation of the $550,000 gift by Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller to Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

The International Olympic Committee gave an emphatic nod today to a new eligibility code which gives an athlete adequate time for training and payment for that time pending approval by the athlete's national federation.
About 1,000 customers pushed into a department store this morning, pulled down displays and injured,an employee during the opening minutes of a sale on antifreeze.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 22--The General Assembly's Social Committee voted today to urge the 13-month-old military Government in Chile to restore human rights and free political prisoners detained after the overthrow of President Salvador Allende Gossens.
President Catlos Andres Perez said here today that Venezuela's oil and iron industries would be nationalized by the end of the year.

More than 300 public school teachers, secretaries and maintenance staff members in Long Branch went on strike today over a demand for higher wages, forcing the closing of six of the city's 10 schools.
Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto today announced extensive Cabinet changes, dropping his Finance Minister and bringing in four new men.

The Knicks unleashed a secret weapon at the Houston Rockets last night. He was Tom Riker, who looks like an awkward football player, but who played the longest and the best game of his National Basketball Association career in the Knicks' 110-100 victory over the Rockets before 14,555 at Madison Square Garden.
A debate among the New York candidates for United States Senator that focused on campaign financing and the nation's troubled economy suddenly flared into an angry face-to-face argument yesterday.

Charles D. Ravenel, who was denied the Democratic nomination for Governor of South Carolina by the courts because he failed to meet a state residence requirement, said today that he would cast a write-in vote for Representative William Jennings Bryan Dorn, who replaced him as the party's nominee.

An angry crowd of 300 people broke windows in workers' cars at the Rowland, Inc., plastics plant today on the first anniversary of a strike there. About 100 to 150 people in the crowd moved to Police Headquarters at about 6:30 P.M., where they massed outside and shouted.

Premier Kakuei Tanaka acknowledged today that he had continued his private business activities throughout his 27-year political career and did not deny charges of financial irregularities that were made against him in a recent magazine article.
A 28-year-old religious cult snake handler died in this Wayne County community yesterday of an untreated snakebite-the same way his fatherin-law died two months ago.
A former railroad worker accused of ly. ing to a grand jury and possession of $50,000 in ransom money intended for the kidnappers of young John Calzadilla was found guilty today on both charges.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22--John W. Dean 3d admitted under cross-examination today that he had continued to withhold damaging information about Watergate for many months after he had said that he had broken from the Watergate conspiracy and had told the authorities "everything" he knew.
The Soviet Union's leading ideologist today declared that the economic crisis in the West had strengthened the positions of Communists and other leftists in several countries.

BERKELEY, Calif.--Congress is nearing final approval of a bill designed by broadcasters and newspaper owners to make their existing television and radio licenses all but permanent. Such action is deserving of public disdain.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 22--In a reversal of the usual situation, Democratic Congressional candidates are raising more money this year than are Republicans, according to a study released today by Common Cause.

Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he had requested and received tape recordings from the Central Intelligence Agency of interviews given by Ramsey Clark and broadcast by the Hanoi radio during Mr. Clark's trip to North Vietna in 1972.
The Consumer Price Index rose substantially again in September, as the retail prices of foods took another jump, the Labor Department announced today.

The New York Times Company reported yesterday increased consolidated net income for the third fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 of $4.48million, or 41 cents a share, up 6.8 per cent from last year's quarter. Net income in the 1973 quarter was $4.19-million, or 37 cents a share.

A program of Russian music that opens with Mussorgsky and closes with Prokofiev's strenuous cantata "Alexander Nevsky" seems in prospect to guarantee an evening of bone-rattling sound and great splashes of orchestral color.

Warren W. Lebeck, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, the nation't largest commodities exchange, is leaving today for China. Mr. Leheck declined to say in a telephone interview whether he had been invited by the Chinese Government.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market continued to rise yesterday as traders on both markets demonstrated confidence in the economy.

The Delaware River Port Authority is studying recommendations by a Federal hearing examiner to slash tolls on three bridges between New Jersey and Pennsylvania by 10 cents. A spokesman said that "we are surprised" at the recommendations and added that the authority soon would file a request for exceptions with the Federal Highway Administration.
The Chrysler Corporation reported today a loss of $8-million in the third quarter despite a $493million increase in sales from the year-earlier period.

A strong conservation effort, including mandatory Federal standards for energy requirements of automobiles, appliances and buildings, is suggested in the Project Independence study on ways, of achieving energy self-sufficiency for the United States.

The Off Broadway Circle Repertory Theater Company, a chief provider of new American plays, has taken a 10-year lease on the Sheridan Square Playhouse, 99 Seventh Avenue South.

Hundreds of residents deluged the police today with tips and possible clues in the mass-murder Saturday night of six people in a bakery here. "The hot line we set up last night for people to call us on has really been hopping," said George Berescik, captain of detectives.
Dr. Varaztad H. Kazanjian, professor emeritus of plastic surgery at the Harvard Medical School, died Saturday at the age of 95. He lived in Belmont, Mass.

The National Football League schedule is coming up to the halfway mark, the seventh of 14 games, for the 26 teams. Eleven of them may be regarded as serious contenders for the eight postseason playoff berths.
Indicated earnings of the Consolidated Edison Company rose 12 percent, in the third quarter on a 46.6 per cent increase in indicated revenues, a company report showed yesterday.

RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 22--Foreign Ministers from the Arab League countries opened three days of preparatory talks here today and immediately made it clear that a conference of Arab leaders starting here Saturday would be dominated by the question of Palestine.

Secretary of State Kissinger left early this morning on a three-week mission to promote peace and the fight against world hunger in Moscow, South Asia and possibly the Middle East.

The Canadian Government announced tighter regulations for new immigrants. They are designed to make entry more difficult for the prospective settler who does not have a job waiting for him. The principal impact is expected to be on the flow of nonwhite immigrants.
WASHINGTON--In the last three years, food prices have leaped 34 per cent. In 1973 our total food bill jumped $14 billion, from $125 billion to $139 billion.
Students were searched with metal detectors today as officials tried to prevent them from taking weapons into two racially troubled high schools.

Investigators worked today on the assumption that a multimillion-dollarvault burglary, belived to be the biggest cash looting in American criminal history, was masterminded by an insder who knew the lock's combination and how to bypass a sensitive alarm system.

Orchestra Hall, the first permanent home of the 73-year-old Minnesota Orchestra, was opened officially last night in downtown Minneapolis. Rushed to completion in 16 months, at a cost of about $10-million, it has proved to be a hall with unusual acoustic properties, as demonstrated by the orchestra and its conductor, Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, in a program of Bach-Skrowaczewski, Ives, Stravinsky and Beethoven.
The countries of theMiddle East and North Africa have a potential for food production that many agricultural experts believe could make a substantial contribution to meeting the world's food needs.

The value of last July's Soviet-American treaty barring underground tests of large nuclear weapons lies primarily in a projected breakthrough on verification, including on-site inspection, which now is being negotiated in Moscow.

A $45-million order for 74 diesel electric locomotives and spare parts has been received by the General Motors Corporation from the Iranian State Railways. The locomotives are to be manufactured at G.M.'s electromotive plants at La Grange, Ill. Shipments will begin in the last quarter of 1975.

The Watergate scandal has added flavor and an element of uncertainty to the Campaign for a Representative in the 25th Congressional District.

The Chicago Mercantile Exchange plans to open the nation's first spot gold market and provide a cash price three times each day, when gold trading becomes legal. At present it is expected the Government will permit Americans to own and trade in gold on Jan. 1.

The Consumer Price Index rose substantially again in September, as the retail prices of foods took another jump, the Labor Department announced today. Prices of commodities other than food registered their smallest increase of the year, but that increase was nonetheless 1 per cent in one month.
New orders for durable goods in September suffered their sharpest monthly declines in nearly seven years, the Commerce Department said today.
Special zoning protection for the Clinton neighborhood was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission after revisions were made to satisfy objections by residents of the West Side area.

The United Nations Security Council postponed until tomorrow its debate on retewal of the mandate for the United Nations peace-keeping force in the Sinai and instead continued a debate on South Africa.
Mrs. JoAnne Brown of Uniondale, L. I., was charged last night with the murder three weeks ago of Burr C. Hollister, a State Supreme Court law secretary with whom she had lived for the two years.

A 23-year-old clerical worker who was found guilty of rape charges last Monday may be the first person convicted under the new state law that permits convictions without corroboration, the Bronx District Attorney's office said yesterday.
State and county law enforcement authorities concluded at a meeting here today that what might be prosecuted as pornography in one New Jersey county might be legally acceptable in another.

Prompted by new disclosures of covert operations of the United States Central Intelligence Agency in Chile, a growing number of Congressmen are demanding that such agency aclons be curtailed or stopped altogether.

Elie Lescot, President of Haiti from May 15, 1941, to Jan. 11, 1946, died today at La Boule, Haiti. He was 90 years old.

Fred Carter, a holdout with the Philadelphia 76ers, signed a contract yesterday. The 76ers had suspended Carter at the start of the season for failing to come to terms with the club. He was the 76ers' leading scorer last season with a 21.4-point average.
John B. Wright, who retired in 1963 as vice president and assistant manager of United States borrowings for the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, died yesterday of a massive internal hemorrhage.

John R. Quarles Jr., deputy administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that additional gasoline taxes or some form of rationing might still be necessary to cope with energy problems.
In National Football League trades yesterday the Los Angeles Rams sent John Hadl, the quarterback, to the Green Bay Packers.

President Ford contended today that if the Democrats gained a wide margin of Congressional seats in the election next month the chances for a bipartisan foreign policy would be threatened and "peace could be in jeopardy."
Alfred B. Kupferberg, a microbiologist, died Sunday this home Sunday. He was 61 years old and lived at 2 Claire Drive, Somerville, N.J.
Yes, says Charles Goldschmidt, there is another way for the principals of an agency to get their money out and still run the show without going public and without getting acquired. by another agency.

Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, in his dispute with Governor Byrne and New Jersey transportation officials over a proposed $300,million PATH rapid transit extension from Newark to Plainfield.
was bombed today as new violence erupted in Kanawha County's seven-week-old textbook protest.

Bob Love, who walked out of the Chicago Bulls' training camp last month in a contract dispute, will be granted an arbitration hearing Saturday in the office of Commissioner Walter Kennedy, the National Basketball Association announced yesterday.
The director general of the Foreign Service has expressed concern in the State Department's newsletter about "malicious or calculated" leaks aimed at discrediting high officials.
The Canadian Government, concerned over the steeply rising numbers and changing racial patterns in the steady flow of immigrants here, announced tighter regulations on new entries today.
Not all the basketball stars who leave the city streets come home again. The fact that some stay away, "and don't involve themselves with the kids in the ghettoes," bothers Tom Vincent.
Governor Wilson told a predominantly black and Democratic audience in Harlem last night that black voters should "for God's sake stop being taken for granted" by the Democratic party.

Two subway workers picking up equipment along an express track at 2 A.M. yesterday, were killed by an IRT work train near the Bergen Street station in Brooklyn.

Americans here for the spring readyto-wear showings are tremendously buoyed by the fact that fashion is alive and thriving. Teetering on the brink of economic disaster, the French are at least facing the precipice beautifully dressed.

ABRAMS-Joseph. Beloved husband of Eve, loving father of Judith Ann Nina Grace, dear brother of Dr. Raymond Abrams and Edna Gwosdow, loving grandfather of Lisanne and David Abram, beloved son-Inlaw of Tillie and Jack Gewirtz, respected father-in-law of Dr. Paul H. Elkins and Peter L. Klein, and beloved orother-inlaw. Services were held Oct. 20th. Contributions to Brotherhood Synagogue Building Fund. 80 5th Ave, NYC, will be appreciated.

The New York Public Interest Research Group has released a "Consumer's Guide to Queens Doctors," which reports the fees, office hours, billing practices and hospital affiliations, of about onethird of the 900 general practitioners and general internaists in the county.
Governor Wilson yesterday accused Representative Hugh L. Carey, his Democratic opponent, of having a poor voting record on environmental issues.
Arthur Ashe was upset, 6-1, 7-6, by Andrew Pattison of Rhodesia in the second round of the $100,000 Iranian tennis tournament today.

A Suffolk County teacher, censured by his principal last year for discussing his vasectomy with his seventhgrade science students, filed suit in Brooklyn yesterday to have the censure removed from his record.

The administrator of the Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administration sided today with Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, in his dispute with Governor Byrne and New Jersey transportation officials over a proposed $300million PATH rapid transit extension from Newark to Plainfield.

Eilzabeth Heiskell Cook, a director of The Gazette in Little Rock, Ark., and a former member of that newspaper's staff, died yesterday in New Haven. She was 62 years old and lived in Old Lyme, Conn., and Jefferson, N.H.
No letup in the oil industry's soaring earnings appeared in sight yesterday as major oil companies reported sharply higher profits for the third quarter of 1974.
Bill Lochead tallied twice within 29 seconds in the first period tonight to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 3-0 National Hockey League victory over the Washington Capitals.
The Union Bank of Switzerland said today that what it described last April as a "sizable loss" from foreign-exchange operations actually totaled $48.9-million.
From observations obtained by two observatories on six retent nights, it now appears virtually certain that the planet Jupiter has a 13th moon.

Eight of the 10 operating World Football League teams drafted 16 of the defunct Detroit Wheels' 37 players today. Philadelhia claimed Bubba Wyche, the quarterback who signed with the Chicago Fire after the Wheels went bankrupt recently. Philadelphia and Chicago later agreed that Wyche would remain with the Fire and that the Bell would receive compensation. The Hawaiians and the Florida Blazers.
Researchers from the State University of Buffalo reported today finding new evidence linking diabetes mellitus to mumps virus.

Edward M. Horey, acting Allegany County judge, today sentenced former District Attorney John T. D'Arcy to three one-year jail terms, to be served concurrently, in connection with several incidents of bondage involving women. Judge Horey also fined him $2.000.
Since late July, when the city started calling taxicabs into a new inspection center for mandatory annual inspections, more than one-third of the 1,728 vehicles tested have failed.
The Taxi and Limousine Commiission announced yesterday that it had approved an increase in the fare rate averaging 17.5 per cent for the city's 11,787 medallion taxicabs.

A Federal District Court was told here today that while James Earl Ray was awaiting trial for the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. he was held in a brightly lighted cell with the windows blocked off and that he was kept under constant surveillance by deputy sheriffs, television cameras and microphones.

Catapulted by sharp rises in the cost of food and housing ownership and maintenance the Consumer Price Index for the metropolitan New York Northern New Jersey region shot up 11.7 per cent during the one-year period ended in Sepmember, according to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

In Africa there is a proverb: "When elephants fight, it is the grass that suffers." Even in Connecticut, where the gubernatorial candidates are locked in combat over the rising cost of electricity, the utility companies leave the distinct impression that, as the battleground, they feel they are being unmercifully trampled on.

A 26-year-old man who was sent to a state hospital for the criminal insane after he allegedly stabbed a girlfriend to. death three years ago is being sought in the murder of Judith Becker, a 26-year-old staff psychologist at the Fishkill Correctional Facility in Beacon, N.Y.

A strong conservation effort, including mandatory Federal standards for energy requirements of automobiles, appliances and buildings, is suggested in the Project Independence study on ways of achieving energy self-sufficiency for the United States.

The agricultural ministers of the members of the European Economic Community agreed today to subsidize imports of sugar to Britain from world suppliers to cover that country's sugar deficit. The deficit is estimated to be 600,000 tons this season.
Portuguese' and black nationalist troops toured the wreckagestrewn streets of Mozambique's capital today appealing for calm after a night of racial violence in which at least 49 people were killed.

Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette, Inc., the parent of the Donaldson, Lufkin Jenrette Securities Corporation, the brokerage firm, reported here yesterday that it lost $1.33-million for the third quarter ended Sept. 30, down from a gain of $1.44-million, or 18 cents a share, a year ago.

Ten reputed members of organized crime and one police officer were indicted yesterday on charges that they had bribed undercover agents-who were posing as "rogue cops"-to fix cases and obtain secret police information to protect a multimillion-dollar gambling operation in Queens.
An ABC-TV news broadcast by Howard K. Smith was interrupted briefly tonight by two men and two women who walked into the Washington studio where Mr. Smith was.
A top official Of the Environmental Protection Agency criticized today as irresponsible and misleading a newspaper advertisement by a major utility group attacking the agency.
The Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops met today to approve a report to Pope Paul VI on their monthlong discussion on "evangelization in the modern world" and decided to reject most of it.

A number of major corporations have been shifting gears from an accounting point of view to conserve cash through a reduction in so-called inventory profits. They have thus sparked a debate in Wall Street.

The New York Giants did something about their quarterback situation today. They sent Norm Snead to San Francisco and acquired Craig Morton from Dallas. For Morton, the Giants gave up their No. 1 draft pick next year.
The Canadian Government, concerned over the steeply rising numbers and changing racial patterns in the steady flow of immigrants here, announced tighter regulations on new entries today.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, producers of a wide variety of products ranging from Scotch brand tape to graphic systems and abrasives, reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings were up 8.5 per cent and sales, up 16.8 per cent. Nine-month earnings rose 8.8 per cent on a sales gain of 17.3 per cent.

A string of six stores that had formed the heart of this Putnam County hamlet's business district for more than a century was destroyed last night in a swift-moving fire that drew volunteer fire departments from half a dozen surrounding communities and caused damage estimated at $1-million.

Following are excerpts from the debate among Senator Jacob K. Javits, Ramsey Clark and Barbara Keating, as recorded by The New York Times: Could each of you list what you regard as the principal issues in the campaign? CLARK: The first issue has to do with integrity in the political process and in government.

The 16-year-old son of Israel's chief delegate to the United Nations was robbed of $28 yesterday by five youths who pushed him off his bicycle in Central Park, the police said.
Largely as a result of higher prices and heavy sales volume a number of the nation's lead, ing metals and steel companies yesterday reported sharply higher earnings for the third quarter.

McKendree Spring paid what was basically the band's annual visit to Manhattan when it appeared Monday at the Bottom Line. The addition of a drummer to the lineup has loosened the band's sound somewhat but it is still very much a blues-based, countryoriented group.

Augustus Wolfman, editor and publisher of The Wolfman Report on the Photographic Industry in the United States, died Monday evening at his home, 209-26 30th Avenue, Bayside, Queens. He was 66 years old.

Scores of companies, ranging from Wall Street brokerage houses to neighborhood restaurants, have taken advantage of a controversial New York state law that allows them to contribute legally for the first time in statewide political contests.

James Earl Ray will take the witness sland in Federal District Court here tomorrow to tell in public for the first time his version of the assassination of the Rev. tha Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

John W. Dean 3d admitted today after repeated questioning that to save himself he had joined in a plan to have John N. Mitchell take the blame for the Watergate break-in. He did so, Mr. Dean said, even though he had no evidence that Mr. Mitchell had approved the bugging plan that led to the break-in.
Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada today won Belgium's backing for his demand that the European Common Market sign a formal trade agreement with Canada.
Paul Laxalt, a 52-year-old former Governor, is trying a political comeback here in a Republican effort to pick up a normally Democratic Senate seat.

The Metropolitan Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association do not swing into full gear here at the New York Hilton Hotel until tomorrow, but players at both ends of the skill scale have opportunities tonight.

The head of the General Services Administration denied, in a letter made public yesterday that the Government had acquired a huge office building, in a $27-million trade, to house the papers of former President Richard M. Nixon.

A reorganization plan that would convert the scandal-shattered, bankrupt Equity Funding Corporation of America into a new company was announced today.

The National Jaycees organization can take action against its Kansas City chapter for admitting women into membership, but a Federal judge prevented the national group yesterday from moving its "10 Outstanding young men" convention to another city.

The policc arrested four men today--and later released them-in connection with the theft of nearly $4-million, the largest theft of cash in the nation's history and the second largest recorded anywhere.

Representative Peter W. Rodino, Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, received today a report on Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller's income taxes for the last six years, but refused to talk about its contents.

Declines in automobile sales, profits and stock prices have spread gloom throughout the auto industry. The industry's concern was reflected today in a statement by Lynn A. A national heritage of fossilized animals and plants is being dug out of the earth and sold at an alarming rate by businessmen who are developing new and highly profitable markets for prehistoric remains as art objects, jewelry and materials for decorators.

A group of four Japanese companies has received a contract valued at about $200-million from P. T. Pertamina, the Indonesian Government-owned concern, to build a natural gas pipeline on Java Island, it was announced in Tokyo yesterday by Mitsui Co. The other companies are Toyo Menka Kaisha, Ltd., Marubeni Co. and the Far East Oil Trading Company. The Nippon Steel Corporation will do the construction work for the group.

Alvin L. Weil, a former director and president of Roosevelt Raceway, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital, Sarasota, Fla., as a result of a gunshot wound received some hours earlier. He was 66 years old.

Leaders of three associations representing the bulk of South Vietnam's journalists called today for the dismissal of Information Minister Hoang Duc Nha. It was the latest move in a campaign for press freedom.

Residents of New Britain, Conn., have offered to put up $5,000 more in reward money for information leading to the arrest of the murderers of six persons in a bakery there Saturday night, John D. LaBelle, the Hartford County State's Attorney, said yesterday.

The fate of 12 financially pressed New Jersey bus companies remained in doubt today despite a lengthy meeting between state officials and representatives of the bus lines, which State Transportation Commissioner Alan Sagner characterized as a "healthy exchange of views on the situation."

Dominated by blue-collar workers and upward-mobile suburbanites of Italian, Polish and Hungarian ancestry, among others, New Jersey's traditionally Democratic 15th Congressional District gave President Nixon a robust majority of 61 to 39 per cent over Senator George S. McGovern in the 1972 presidential election.

Margaret Manners Lippmann, who as Margaret Manners was a well-known writer of mystery stories, died Oct. 8 at the Princeton (N. J.) Medical Center. She was 60 years old and lived at 55 Harrison Street, Princeton.

James H. Meredith filed a suit in Federal District Court today in his battle for a place on the November ballot as an independent candidate for Representative from Mississippi's Fourth Congressional District.

Federal agencies will be closed on Monday in honor of Veterans Day, but the holiday will be observed in New York and Connecticut on Nov. 11 when city and state offices and public schools will be closed.
Samuel G. Cahan, an old-time quick-sketch newspaper artist, who had been on the staff of The New York World for 32 years, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital at the age of 88.

Robert Abrams, the Democratic candidate for State Attorney General, asserted yesterday that a "scandal-ridden and industry-dominated" State Department of Agriculture and Markets had "sabotaged" the New York City milk-dating law to benefit milk interests.
The editors of 10 Turkish newspapers and two major news agencies were indicted today on charges of having published state secrets during Turkey's invasion of Cyprus.

A 23-year-old zookeeper at the Prospect Park Zoo, brandishing a pitchfork, locked himself inside the Monkey House yesterday and smashed several windows before he was calmed by the police and Parks Department officials and removed to a hospital.
Correspondents traveling with Secretary of State Kissinger today protested the Soviet Union's refusal to admit one of their colleagues with the official party.

United States Representative Robert H. Steele, the Republican nominee for Governor of Connecticut, today accused John M. Bailey, the state Democratic chairman, of illegally buying an office building from the Hartford Electric Light Company and then renting it back to the company in a deal that brought him a profit of more than $2-million.

Ronald Maiorana, Commissioner of Wagering Systems of the State Racing and Wagering Board, urged President Ford yesterday to veto a bill that he said "would adversely affect the operation of state lotteries."
A 73-year-old widow, her face badly bruised, was found dead in the bedroom of her ransacked apartment at 1970 Walton Avenue in the High Bridge section of the Bronx, the police reported yesterday.

The cost of feeding a family of four resumed its climb last week after a one week pause when prices remained about the same. The City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday that its 38-item Market Basket for a family of four rose by 0.3 per cent above the previous week's level, to $63.37.

Secretary of State Kissinger arrived in Moscow with "fairly concrete" ideas on strategic arms limitation to explore in three days of talks with Soviet leaders. Accelerated progress would prepare the way for a meeting between President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev, possibly next month. Other subjects on the agenda include detente and Middle East issues. Rod Laver and Jimmy Connors set the date and place yesterday for the first match ever between the two star left-handed tennis players The $100,000 winner-take-all challenge match (the loser gets an unspecified consolation prize) is slated indoors for Feb. 2 at the Caesars Palace Hotel in Las Vegas.
At a meeting alongside a quiet boatyard, city planners proposed last night to safeguard the fishing-village flavor of City Island by declaring it a "special district."
