The Cabinet passed today a comprehensive energy program reducing planned fuel consumption by 9 per cent from previously planned levels. The program will reduce German dependence on oil as a prime source of energy from 55 per cent to 44 per cent by 1985, the Economics Minister, Hans Friderichs, said.

A black man was pulled from a truck and beaten in South Boston this afternoon as parts of this city remained tense under a courtordered plan of busing for school desegregation.
Syria proposed today to the Arab countries the creation of a joint military command comprising the Palestine Liberation Organization as well as Jordan, Egypt and Syria.

The Chicago Cubs announced today that they had traded Billy Williams, their slugging outfielder-first baseman, to the Oakland A's for three players: Darold Knowles and Bob and Manny Trillo, a second baseman.

A 31-year-old insurance agent was indicted yesterday on a charge of an election-law violation for allegedly offering to arrange for James Eagan to withdraw from la?? month's Republican primary race in Queens against Representative James J. Delaney.
Former President Richard M. Nixon was readmitted unexpectedly last night to Memorial Hospital Medical Center of Long Beach, Calif., because of complications in his phlebitis treatment.

The Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops, still without agreement on the principal topic of its meeting, adopted a message to the world today that urges the right to life, to food, to social, economic, political and cultural advancement and to religious liberty.

President Ford has told Congress that he has, in effect, vetoed an environmental protection bill, but Congressional sources say that by refusing to send Congress a formal veto message, Mr. Ford may have ensured the bill's enactment.

The Department of Justice argued today that the Railroad Reorganization Act that became law earlier this year is constitutional because the Federal Govern ment stands ready to pay valid claims in the case of losses resulting from its operation.

Diagnostic reading tests are being given this week to 150, 000 City high school students as the first step in a new program-the largest and most systematic ever attempted here--to overcome widespread reading retardation in the secondary schools.
The National Cancer Advisory Board has called for Federal regulation of tar and nicotine content in cigarettes in the agency's annual report, which was sent to Congress today by President Ford.

Attendance at Public School 46 in Harlem, where a parents' protest against four teachers kept 99 per cent of the students out of school last Friday, was back up to 70 per cent yesterday and the police contingent there had been reduced from a peak of 100 officers to the normal detail of two.
The Treasury borrowed $1billion yesterday by selling notes yielding 7.89 per cent in a financing that attracted fewer individuals that the Government's note sales late last summer.

A five-member Appellate Division panel sharply questioned the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, yesterday on the methods he used in obtaining an indictment last spring against Judge Paul P. Rao Sr. of the United States. Customs Court.

Eight months after he fled the United States for Sweden, Robert A. Luongo Jr. was brought home this evening to face charges of swindling more than 2,000 people here and abroad of at least $15-million in a getrich-quick investment scheme.

Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here today hoping to accelerate the talks on the limitation of strategic arms and prepare the way for progress by the time President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev meet, possibly next month.

A 32-year-old hospital clerk was convicted last night by a Bronx Supreme Court jury on charges of reckless manslaughter in the death of a Transit Authority police officer in a shootout in a Bronx subway station two years ago.

George Papadopoulos and four other leaders of the military coup of 1967 were arrested today and exiled to the small Aegean Island of Kea. In a brief announcement, the Government said the five "are engaged in conspiratorial activities, which cause uneasiness and create conditions threatening the peace."
A huge painting by the French artist Jean Dubuffet brought a record price of $340,000 at an auction of impressionist and modern paintings and sculpture at Sotheby Parke Bernet last evening.
Soybean oil futures led a downturn in soybean prices yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat and corn prices followed.

Harry Van Arsdale Jr., president of the Taxi Drivers Union, which he has headed for eight years, is being challenged in his re-election bid by two opponents who contend he has been an "absentee" leader and has suppressed democracy in the 30,000-member union.

A 74-year-old wartime opponent of Yugoslavia's President Tito and the Communist Partisans was sentenced by a Belgrade court today to five years in prison on charges that he wrote anti-Tito articles for foreign publications five years ago.

The prosecution rested its case yesterday in State Supreme Court, Manhattan, in the murder trial of Police Officer William R. Phillips. He is being retried for the alleged 1968 slaying of a pimp--James Smith, alias James Goldberg-and an 18year-old prostitute, Sharon Stango.
A Federal District Court jury today found three Black Liberation Army members guilty on charges stemming from a $10,000 bank robbery here last spring.

Jacob Schwalbe, whose firm, Kornblum Co., founded by his grandfather, was one of the oldest produce commission merchants here, died in his sleep Tuesday morning. He was 82 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street.

The first year that Robert F. Wagner was Mayor of New York, he helped to nominate and elect Averell Harriman as Governor--a post that, as it turned out, the Democrats were able to hold only briefly in between the Albany reigns of Thomas E. Dewey and Nelson A. Rockefeller.

The Citizens Union, the nonproposed partisan organization that produces an annual Voters Directory, announced its support yesterday for the $250million rail preservation bond issue that will be on the Nov. 5 ballot.

Senator Jacob K. Javits, citing a letter he said he had received from a former prisoner of war, charged yesterday that Ramsey Clark had allowed himself to be "exploited" by the North Vietnamese during Mr. Clark's visit with prisoners in Hanoi in 1972.

"Good News," the musical revival c-starring Alice Faye, John Payne and Stubby Kaye, will begin previews Nov. 11 at the St. James Theater. It was to have given its first performance here on Saturday but a fire destroyed the show's scenery while it was being transported by truck in Los Angeles.

About 21 million marks ($8.4-million) may have been lost by the Commerzbank as a result of alleged embezzlement by the former chief clerk at its Frankfurt bookkeeping department, the Hesse state prosecutor, Dietrich Rahn, said today.

Victor Korchnoi tried again to nail Anatoly Karpov in their final candidates match for the world championship, but after 46 moves in five hours in their 15th game, the Leningrad grandmaster had overextended himself and could hope only for a draw.

Railroad passenger service linking New York City with Detroit through Buffalo and Niagara Falls will begin next Wednesday, Governor Wilson's office announced today.

Weighed down by gloomy economic developments - including sagging automobile sales--the stock market reeled yesterday under persistent pressure, and the Dow Jones industrial average incurred its largest loss in two months.

A young County Attorney, or prosecutor, in rural New Hampshire, charged with violating the state's obscenity statute by showing the movies "Deep Throat" and "The Devil in. Miss Jones," has been cleared on two of four obscenity charges by an all-male jury.

James C. Fletcher, the head of the national space program, said today that the Soviet Union steadfastly refused to permit American newsmen to view the launching next July 15 of Russian astronauts in the joint United States-Soviet space mission.

Five large oil companies reported yesterday gains in thirdquarter earnings ranging from 75 per cent to. 124 per cent. The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) announced the largest gain, 124.4 per cent. The Continental Oil Company advanced by 121.8 per cent:

The Cleveland Cavaliers, led by Austin Carr's 28 points, dominated the Boston Celtics in the first half tonight then held off a furious last-minute Celtic surge for a 108-107 National Basketball Association victory.
Moscow was picked over Los Angeles today to hold the Summer Olympics in 1980, and Lake Placid, N. Y., the only candidate, will stage the Winter Games on virtually the same terrain as in 1932.

Governor Wilson announced yesterday a "get tough" anticrime program that could make juveniles found guilty of serious crimes of violence subject to the same penalties as adults, including life imprisonment.

Technology is now available to use this country's billions of tons of high-sulphur coal without harm to the environment. This announcement by the Environmental Protection Agency refutes the almost hysterical advertising campaign of the American Electric Power System, which would have the public believe that the only hope for adequate energy lies in strip-mining the low-sulphur coal of the West.

A 27-year-old woman was arrested last night at St. Luke's Hospital and charged with killing her 8-year-old son, who died at the hospital five hours after he was allegedly beaten and scalded with hot water at home, the police reported.

The Singer Company, proprietor of a brand name that is as much a part of Americana as Kodak, Levi's and Coca-Cola, is faced with omitting or drastically reducing the 65-cent quarterly dividend that it pays its 54,000 stockholders, many of whom are present and former employes.
Walton Alston of the Los Angeles Dodgers, was named the National League manager of the year yesterday by The Associated Press and United Press International.

The quarterback: Mike Tanner. Tanner, a three-year starter and offensive co-captain, is enjoying his finest season. So is St. Joseph's.

The National Conference of Motion Picture and Television Unions has warned ABC-TV that it will attempt to mount a public campaign against the television adaptation of Gore Vidal's "Burr" if the network goes forward with its proposal to produce the series abroad.

The National Investor Relations Institute 'called today for action by the President and Congress "recognizing the critical importance of the American system of raising capital for industry from millions of direct and indirect shareowners."

A national heritage of fossilized animals and plants is being dug out of the earth and sold at an alarming rate by businessmen who are developing new and highly profitable markets for prehistoric remains as art objects, jewelry and materials for decorators.
The president of the Mormon church has been subpoenaed to disclose all church policies and practices concerning blacks, who are denied full participation in the 3.3-millionmember religion.

Prices tumbled on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market yesterday in decreased trading. The Amex market value index dropped 1.14 to 68.59 as the price of an average share lost 13 cents.

Superior Court Judge Merritt Lane Jr. today ordered striking Long Branch public school teachers to return to work tomorrow. He also ordered a resumption of contract negotiations the teachers have demanded.

Secretary of State Kissinger arrived here today hoping to accelerate the talks on the limitation of strategic arms and prepare the way for progress by the time President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev meet, possibly next month.

Another big issue of United States Treasury securities was sold yesterday--this time $1-billion worth of 4.5-year notes yielding 7.89 per cent. And while there were fewer individual purchasers than in the previous Federal financing in August, when $4billion worth of notes were sold to yield 8.75 and 8.59 per cent, there were still large numbers of small purchasers.

The White House currently appears as a stage on which two plays are being acted side by side, with President Ford the leading character in both. In one scenario, he earns applause for having replaced a devious, solitary, autocratic Richard Nixon with his own gregarious frankness and simplicity. In the other, he disturbs the audience' with inexplicable deviations and decisions that shock and confound political friends and opponents alike.

Kenneth N. Jolly, vice president and assistant to the president of the Campbell Soup Company, Camden, N.J., died yesterday in the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in Villanova, Pa.

With the reopening of the Art Gallery of Ontario this week, the city of Toronto has acquired both a distinguished new museum facility and, what nowadays is even more unusual, a huge collection of primary works by a major living artist.

Loyd Wright, former president of the American Bar Association, died Tuesday at his home in Hemet, Calif. He was 81 years old. Mr. Wright, who had represented a number of movie personalities, devoted a considerable part of his life to public service.

A skin rash turned up today in George Foreman's camp. For the time being, the rash has brought only a minor disruption to the heavyweight champion's training routine: He now has to make his own breakfast in preparation for his title bout with Muhammad Ali on Oct. 29, New York time.

A bomb exploded at Harrow School, one of Britain's most exclusive schools tonight but no injuries were reported, the police said. It was the second explosion in the London area in 24 hours.

According to latest reports, David Bowie, the British rock performer, has given up his glitter wardrobe for a simpier, more tailored look, apparently along the lines of those broad-shouldered suits that once used to transform Rosalind Russell into a movie newspaperperson.

Representatives of the state's 607 school boards, facing a confused and gloomy fiscal outlook for next year, met here today to consider what Commissioner of Education Fred G. Burke described as a "crisis of confidence" in the state's educational system.

The United Stelworkers of America announced today that about 400,000 of its members in the basic stel industry would receive a cost-of-living wage increase of 16 cents an hour Nov. 1. The principal gubernatorial candidates in Connecticut crossed in opposite directions into traditionally hostile territories today, each hoping to undermine some of the other's strength.

The University of Houston, relying on three running backs, Marshall Johnson,John Housman and Reggie Cherry, who all gained more than 100 yards, rolled to a 27-6 victory tonight over the University of Cincinnati.

Senator Jacob K. Javits and Ramsey Clark traded another round of angry accusations at a luncheon debate yesterday, but they were also laughed at as Barbara Keating, the Conservative party's candidate, belittled their differences and said they ought "to wash their mouths out with soap."

The announcement of gloomy figures from the auto industry continued yesterday as the General Motors Corporation, the No. 1 auto maker, reported that its earnings for the third quarter plummeted 94 per cent from the same period of 1973. Its earnings for the first nine months of the year were the lowest in 16 years.
An Allegheny Airllines DC-9 carrying 99 persons made a safe emergency landing on a foam-covered runway here last night.
Derek Wilkinson was taking a break from his Manhattan construction job one day last week, swigging beer with a couple of friends, when the subject of politics and patriotism was raised.
SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 25--National daily newspapers and press agencies in South Korea today closed their ranks and pressed the Government of President Park Chung Hee to end press restrictions.

The Shell Oil Company, the American affiliate of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group announced yesterday that its wholly owned subsidiary, Shell Explorer, Ltd., was seeking a buyer for its interest in the Athabasca Tar Sands, which it shares with Shell Canada, Ltd. The tar sands are in Alberta.

Defense and prosecution lawyers in the Rubin (Hurricane) Carter murder case blamed each other yesterday for failing to comply with a court order to exchange confidential evidence before a hearing on a new trial begins.

Franco Udella of Italy knocked out Pedro Molledo of Spain in the fifth round tonight at Milan's Indoor Sports Palace and won the European flyweight boxing championship.

Former President Richard M. Nixon experienced "a small amount of bleeding from the gums" and "spent a comfortable night with a minimum of pain" at Memorial Hospital Medical Center here, Mr. Nixon's doctors said today.

CHICAGO -- Millions of Americans today consider themselves lucky to have a socalled"free"checking account. But what they don't realize is that many are actually letting $100, $300, even $500 or more in hard cash slip through their fingers every year.

The national commander of the American Nazi party was arrested today when he tried to force his way into a Federal courthouse. A second member of the party was arrested by the Boston police on a traffic violation.

A 2-cent-a-gallon increase in the minimum price of milk was ordered by the State Agriculture Department. The price increase will take effect Nov. 1, with the legal minimum rising to $1.20 a gallon. The price of a quart is going up to. a minimum of 34 cents and a half-gallon to 63 cents.

F. Shelton Farr, founder and former senior partner of the commodity and stock brokerage firm of Farr Co., now Farr Man Co., Inc., 120 Broadway, died Wednesday in Rapallo, Italy, where he had lived for several years.
The Canadian Government announced today that income taxes would go down next year as a result of legislation, passed last year, linking levies to the consumer price index.

After months of holding off network requests for exclusive interviews, President Ford has become available for television news specials just before the November elections and in a period when he has been actively campaigning for the election of Republicans to the Congress.

Johnson, a 6-foot-6-inch sophomore who was an occasional starter for the Bruins last season, entered the U.C.L.A. Medical Center a week ago.
The Federal Government introduced legislation today giving Ottawa the power to set domestic prices for oil and natural gas.
A 24-year-olds civilian employe of the Police Department was arrested yesterday and charged in the murder last March of his wife and her infant daughter in their Brooklyn apartment.

They will promplty return to Madison Square Garden to meet the Atlanta Flames tomorrow night.

Britain gained an unbeatable 4-0 lead in the Wightman Cup tennis competition tonight by winning a singles and a doubles match from the United States.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said yesterday that Congress had no plans to put a tax on Veterans Administration compensation.

The nation's chain stores and catalogue houses registered a sales gain of 11.6 per cent in September compared with September, 1973, according to a survey of 42 leading companies by Chain Store Age magazine. The gain was the largest since May.

T. Douglas Robson, president of Jacobs Robson, Inc., textile concern, died Thursday at his home in Plandome, L.I. He was 57 years old.
The New York Nets put together their best game of the young - American Basketball Association season tonight and defeated the San Antonio Spurs, 113-93, before 7,167 fans at Nassau Coliseum.

In a move to deter crimes against taxicab drivers, District Attorney Richard H. Kuh of Manhattan announced yesterday that his office would place most such crimes under its major-felony bureau so that they could be stringently prosecuted.

A sharp drop in September in imported food, oil and cars trimmed the deficit in the United States' trade balance to its best position in five months, the Commerce Department reported today.

Judge Merritt Lane Jr. tonight cited 11 persons for contempt of court for defying for the second dayan order he had issuedin Superior Court prohibitng a strike by teachers, custolians and clerical workers against the schools here.

An agreement between the State Department of Transportation and 12 financially distressed bus lines on terms for stepped up state subsidy payments was reached late yesterday, insuring that commuter service for 40,000 passengers will not end next Friday, as previously threatened by the 2 companies. the 2 ocmpanies.

Jimmy Walker scored 14 of his game-high 20 points in the first period tonight to lead the Kansas City-Omaha Kings to a 112-91 victory over the Chicago Bulls. It was the third straight loss for the Bulls.

The chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority said yesterday that he was hopeful that the over-all use of electricity in the seven-state region served by the authority could be reduced by about 20 per cent.

As the result of successful court challenges of close Democratic primary election results, special elections will be held Monday in two Manhattan Assembly Districts. (Pete) Grannis, an attorney who has served with the State Department of Environmental Conservation, once more will face former City Councilman Robert I. Postel.

Mr. Sargent, a liberal who has gone to some lengths to stake out his independence from the Nixon Administration and the state Republican party, is faced not only with the hard-driving campaign of his Democratic rival, Michael S. Dukakis, but also with voter disillusionment over Watergate, the Presidential pardon and the sagging economy.

Y., Oct. 27--On the basis of reports about increased use of torture against political prisoners, United Nations members have called for adoption of an international code of police ethics. Not everything happening these days is bad. Into the arcane science of :geopolitics is creeping a long-term trend that could even be considered benign, a change in the list of factors that add up to national power.

At the urging of Mayor Beame the teamsters union and United Parcel Service agreed to resume negotiations today in an effort to end a two-month-old strike that has seriously affected the apparel industry and retail stores. In a meeting at City Hall, the Mayor said, he emphasized the importance of a settlement "in view of the economic situation and unemployment in the city."

International Arab heads of state including Jordan's King Hussein have unanimously issued a declaration calling for the creation of an independent Palestinian state and recognizing the Palestine Liberation Organization as the "sole legitimate representative of the Palestine people." The decision was a victory for Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. [Page 1, Column 8.]
Environmentalists ?? have opened a fight with the Army over a plan to kill 14 million blackbirda this winter by spraying them with a chemical that will cause them to freeze to death.

Davey Vasquez of the Bronx, the eighth - ranked bantamweight in the world, survived a knockdown in the opening minute of the first round last night at the Felt Forum to score a unanimous 10-round decision over Earl Large of Clovis, New. Mexico.

James Earl Ray returns to the stand tomorrow in his bid for a new trial in the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Contending that he was forced by "greedy" lawyers into pleading guilty to the slaying in April, 1968, Mr. Ray has not yet told his version of the murder.
Al Carmines's musical version of Gertrude Stein's "Listen to Me" is a play on words, particularly on words of one syllable, as in the statement--not a question--"What is a word of one syllable."

To the Editor: While everyone recognizes that an anti-inflationary program will require suffering, all potentially effective programs are enmeshed in controversy over how the suffering is to be shared. To overcome this impasse, both Congress and the President should make clear that the first priority is to stop the inflation with a minimum of overall suffering, and the second is to allocate that suffering fairly.

In the darkness before dawn, when ordinarily only the textile factory workers are laboring here, George Foreman will defend his world heavyweight championship against Muhammad Ali at 4 o'clock Wednesday. morning. Each gladiator has been assured $5-million to alter his sleeping habits.

SWEET HOME, Ark.-The house was a faded gray, squatting in the dust beside a crumbling macadam street. In one of its two rooms Mrs. Luteller Peters, 84 years old, her eyes fiercely bright in a face deeply seamed like black leather stitched loosely over bone, sat under a sign that said in crude red letters:

More than 250 angry parents picketed the Board of Education headquarters here this afternoon demanding that the city's 10 public schools be closed until a strike of teachers, secretaries and custodians was settled.

For the first time since the start of school decentralization in 1970, the city's central Board of Education is planning to take over the fiscal management of at least three local districts because of abuses and loose practices that, it says, may have resulted in the waste or misuse of millions of dollars.

Government energy experts believe that a strike by coal miners this winter would lead to a worse fuel crisis than. the one caused by last year's oil embargo, according to a memorandum made public today by a public interest group.

MONTAUK, L. I.--Red as fire, the sun was slipping behind a low, narrow band of dark clouds in the west when Al Ristori and I pounded out of the Montauk Basin in his 22-foot Mako and headed for Shagwong Reef.
Elton P. Hall, publish- si er of the Traverse City RecordEagle and a vice president of Ottaway Newspapers, Inc., died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

About Pro Hockey- Suddenly, there's Orr! And Esposito! Last week, when National Hockey League fans looked at the scoring leaders, the familiar names of Bobby Orr and Phil Esposito were hardly to be found. But then the Boston Bruin stars went on a rampage, Orr get ting three goals in one game and 10 points while Esposito tallied 6 points.
The Federal Energy Administration published today two regulations that could force some international oil companies to reduce gasoline and oil prices temporarily by a penny or two a gallon.

As Secretary of State Kissinger arrived for lunch at the United States Ambassador's residence here, he was asked jokingly by an American newsman whether the rumors were true that he had been meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev for the last three days.
The George Foreman-Muhammad Ali fight in Zaire tonight will make the Guiness Book of World Records as either the best or the worst in regard to the television gate.

The board of trustees of the American Medical Association has voted to recommend to the A.M.A. House of Delegates that all advertising be discontinued in the association's 14 journals, magazines and newsletters.

After forty years, there is a strong chance that Congress will change but. not necessarily raise the standards for granting Federal franchises to privately owned radio and television stations. The Broadcast License Renewal Act would amend the 1934 law by extending the present three-year license term to five years and establishing other criteria for serving the public interest.
President Ford signed a motor vehicle and school bus safety bill today that does away with the mandatory seat-belt interlock system, which has been a source of controversy.

Pakistan asked today that the General Assembly declare South Asia a zone free of nuclear weapons and invite the countries in that region to meet promptly and agree on arrangements for putting the declaration into effect.

As Roy Hilton rumbled toward the Dallas goal after recovering a fumble last Sunday at Yale Bowl, a wall of blue-shirted bodyguards formed on each side of him. "That's the best blocking the Giants have had all sea son," a cynic observed, after Hilton scored the New Yorkers' only touchdown in a 21-7 loss to the Cowboys.
The Rev. Billy James Hargis, the evangelist who has devoted himself since 1948 to his anti-Communist "Christian Crusade," is giving up most of his work because of failing health.

Governor Wilson and hundreds of police officers from throughout New York and several surrounding states led mourners today at a funeral service for a state trooper who was killed in the line of duty last week.

Gas flares light up the evening sky around Villahermosa like the camp fires of a besieging army. But this sleepy town in southeast Mexico maintains its tranquil pace, the people seemingly unmoved by the threatened invasion of oil men and oil money.

Four convicts holding hostages in the chapel of Scheveningen Prison tonight released another of their prisoners and appeared to be under increasing pressure to give up their escape attempt. The wife of Daan Denie, one of the four, was allowed to enter the chapel,
An agreement has been reached with the Chinese Government to allow a party of about 500 Western tourists to visit the Canton area next spring, the Cunard Line announced tonight.

Should the New England Patriots reach the Super Bowl in January, and they appear to have as good a chance as anyone right now they are sure to vote a full share of the spoils to Bob Windsor, their tight end who will not be with them that day.

Amid growing doubts about how much further the rise could go, there was another upsurge in world sugar prices yesterday. The London sugar market again set the pace as a British sugar trade house estimated a deficit in sugar supplies for the coming year.

President Ford signed a bill today that provides for comprehensive studies of foreign investments in the United States. In a statement, Mr. Ford emphasized that the mpasure was intended "to gather information only."

Dr. Sheldon Weiss, a past president of the Nassau County Dental Society, and presidentelect of the Tenth District Dental Society made up of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 223-03 56th Road, Bayside, Queens. He was 52 years old.

The California Golden Seals, who fought the Philadelphia Flyers for a 4-1 victory last Friday night, amassing a record - breaking 232 minutes of combined penalties, lay dead for the New York Islanders tonight with hardly a punch. The Islanders beat them. 10-1.

The wife of the campaign chairman of Senator Peter H. Dominick, Republican of Colorado, announced Sunday that she had formed a group of 20 Republicans to back Gary Hart, the Senator's opponent on Nov. 5.
Two suspects in the theft of $4.3-million from a vault here were indicted today by a Cook County grand jury on charges of having participated in a multi - million - dollar stolen goods ring.

The parents of Patricia Hearst rejected an offer to have underworld figures bring the young fugitive back by force because they had found the plans too dangerous, an attorney for the Hearst family said today.

When World War II ended, Washington embarked on an unusual and far-reaching program to feed millions of hungry people overseas, most of whom paid little or nothing for the basic foodstuffs they received.

Senator William Proxmire, Democrt of Wisconsin has denounced the bill recently approved by the House Ways and Means Committee that would permit taxpayers to deduct up to $1,000 of interest earned on savings accounts. He called it "another new tax loophole."

Governor Wilson and hundreds of police officers from throughout New York and several surrounding states led mourners today at a funeral service for a state trooper who was killed in the line of duty last week.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 28--Former President Richard M. Nixon will undergo "urgent" surgery at 5:30 A.M. Pacific standard time (8:30 A.M. New York time) tomorrow to clamp off a vein in his thigh, and thereby prevent a clot from running away and lodging in his lung, Mr. Nixon's doctors said tonight.
Buffalo's unemployment rate is likely to fall below 7 per cent this month, a drop from the 9.4 per cent level of July, according to State Labor. Department estimates.

A survey by the Conference Board reported yesterday that exports from the United States to the Soviet Union jumped from $162-million in 1971 to $1.2-billion last year. Exports to Communist China in 1972, following detente with Peking, were above $60-million and rose sharply to $680-million last year.

6-7 A.M., WNYC-FM: Sunrise Symphony. First Caprice, Lalande; Organ Concerto No. 16 in F, Handel; Symphony for Double Orchestra in D, Bach. 9:06-10, WQXR: Piano Personallties. Nadia Reisenberg. Six Piano Pieces, Tchaikovsky. 10:06-Noon, WQXR: The Listening Room. Robert Sherman, host. Guests: Marjorie Hayward Madey, soprano; Lark Wind Quintet.

Arab heads of state, including King Hussein of Jordan, called unanimously today for the creation of an independent Palestinian state "on any Palestinian land that is liberated" from Israeli occupation.

Jorge Bolet's standing among connoisseurs of pianism is so exalted these days that his recitals take on the air of lecture-demonstrations by a renowned surgeon. One almost expects to see people pull out clip boards and take notes.

The California Golden Seals, who fought the Philadelphia Flyers for a 4-1 victory last Friday night, amassing a record - breaking 232 minutes of combined penalties, lay dead for the New York Islanders tonight with hardly a punch. The Islanders beat them, 10-1.

As Roy Hilton rumbled toward the Dallas goal after recovering a fumble last Sunday at Yale Bowl, a wall of blue-shirted bodyguards formed on each side of him. "That's the best blocking the Giants have had all sea son," a cynic observed,

Vice President - designate Nelson A. Rockefeller disclosed today that he made $507,656 in loans during the last 17 years to friends, associates and family members--including his wife--of which $147,733 has not yet been repaid.

Unable to take off weight without getting dizzy, Laffit Pincay Jr. has decided to stop fighting the "sweat box" at Aqueduct. Unless his doctor can pinpoint the cause of the problem, the nation's top money winning jockey may take the rest of the year off.

Leonid I. Brezhnev the Soviet leader, today warned Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany against seeking a more favorable interpretation of the 1971 four-power agreement on West Berlin and demanded instead its strict observance.
Secret Service agents have confiscated more than $8-million worth of bogus $100 bills in what they called the largest seizure of counterfeit money in American history.

Friends and admirers of Anne Sexton, the poet who committed suicide at her home in Weston, Mass., on Oct. 4, will give readings from her works and recollections in a program entitled "A Tribute to Anne Sexton" at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, tomorrow at 5:45 P.M.

Mayor Beame yesterday signed into law a bill raising by $15 a day the $100 per diem pay of members of the Board of Education and the maximum compensation to $29,000 a year. This was the first salary increase for Board of Education members in five years.

a dolphin was sighted in the harbor here at 9 A.M. today, and by late this afternoon, grownups and children on Main Street and nearly everywhere else in this small village on Long Island's North Shore were asking, "How is he?"
An Israeli military court today sentenced two Dutch women to prison for three and a half months for having smuggled a letter written in invisible ink to Arab guerrillas.
In a reversal of strategy, Governor Wilson yesterday taped a new spot television commercial telling the voters that he had no responsibility for Watergate, the Nixon pardon or the Rockefeller gifts.
Secretary of State Kissinger tonight called on India, as the newest nuclear power, to join the United States and other nations in an effort to prevent
Authors and publishers are locked in a battle with the country's libraries over the photocopying of copyrighted materials, and both sides agree that the outcome will be felt for years to come.

Most major Italian banks are raising their prime lending rates by one percentage point to around 18.5 per cent because of the liquidity squeeze, banking sources said. The rates were last increased in early September after a one-point rise to 15.5 per cent on June 7.

The fortunes of Parsippany High's football team have taken a dramatic upswing since the arrival of its head coach, Bob Martin, three years ago. Football there is fun again. A victory Saturday over unbeaten West Essex would clinch the first winning season in eight years for the Morris County club.

About 150 people, including Mayor Paul T. Jordan, trudged through the streets of this city today in a march against hunger, and raised more than $4,000 to provide food for elderly residents and for supplemental feeding programs for low-income pregnant women and infants.

Career education is creeping into the nursery schools and kindergartens, somewhere between show and tell and juice and cookies. At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Day School, an audience of 5-year-olds litens to a construction superintendent in a hard hat, followed by an artist with a sketch pad, an editor with a manuscript page and a psychiatrist without a couch.

The adoption last week of a bill to regulate migrant-worker crew leaders has set the/stage for a showdown on a more sweeping measure that would place ultimate responsibility for crew leaders' activities on the farmers who employ them.

Dr. Alan D. Miller, the State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, acceded yesterday to the demand of a statewide mentalhealth task force that he appear on Thursday before an emergency meeting scheduled by the task force without permission of the state agency.

For the second time, the official physician for the final candidates match for the world championship granted Anatoly Karpov a postponement. Thus the game between Karpov and Viktor Korchnoi, which had been scheduled for 5 P.M. today was reset for the same time Wednesday.

Even in the light of extreme budgetary stringency, the threatened closing of three major neighborhood branch libraries raises serious questions concerning the city's approach to fiscal planning and public service policy. At a time when the improvement of urban education is a matter of the highest priority, the curtailment of library services would be a calamity.

It was front-page news the other day when Henry Kissinger arrived in Moscow, although at the time he had not done anything but, arrive, which a lot of other people do every day without getting a line in the papers. There was nothing surprising about Mr. Kissinger's Moscow arrival.

The New York Mets pushed their goodwill tour of the Orient to the far North of Japan tonight after another diplomatic success in Tokyo earlier in the day. They lost a two-run lead in the last half of the ninth inning to the Yomiuri Giants, settled for a 4-4 tie in the 10th and left town with no victories in their first two appearances in Japan.

The Loews Corporation said yesterday that over the weekend its Lorillard division sent notice to its customers that it would raise the list price of all its domestic tax-paid cigarette brands by 70 cents a thousand, effective next Monday.

NEW HAVEN-From the first day of a month-long trip to China this summer, ten student leaders and I were aware of a tremendous presence: Chairman Mao. One cannot walk a block without seeing his words or face painted on colossal billboard displays.

In the face of newsprint shortages, rising production costs and the concern of the Justice Department about the concentration of newspaper and broadcast ownership in many cities, a broadcaster in Wichita, Kan., has founded a weekly newspaper specializing in the coverage of local issues and events.
On the surface at least, the 65th annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers that started here today is no different than others held in recent years except that the weather is great.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 28 (UPI)--Hundreds of parents, waving flags and signs reading "teach English, not revolution," marched through this city to day in a protest against a series of textbooks introduced into schools this fall.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland--The people of Belfast are buying picture postcards of their city's torment by the hundreds. The most popular shows a boy throwing a stone at a British armored car.
Repre sentative James J. Howard, Democrat of the Third District nursed a cold for several day after Congress recessed this month and kept his campaign talks brief.

Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, charged here yesterday that the Interstate Commerce Commission, Congress, the Administration and business were pursuing and advocating restrictive practices that hamper full food production and the stabilization of food prices.

There is a healthy fresh glow to the dances and dancers of Agnes de Mille's Heritage Dance Theater. This may not necessarily be to everyone's taste. "Too apple pie," a member of the audience was overheard to remark when the young company appeared in Great Neck, L. I., Sunday night under the auspices of the North Shore Community Arts Center.
The city's Department of Consumer Affairs has proposed a regulation that would require merchants to give Spanish-speaking customers a written explanation in Spanish of all credit transactions.

On a garden path, 10 yards from where four leopards paced their cage, Zaire President Mobutu Sese Seko met for small talk this morning with George Foreman and Muhammad Ali on the eve of their world heavyweight championship fig ?? tomorrow night.

Florence Colebrook Powers is 89 years old, and her two tiny rooms in a residence hotel here are cluttered with mementos. There are newspaper clippings of her performance as a ballroom dancer at President Franklin D. Roosevelt's first inaugural ball in 1933.

For the first time since the start of school decentralization in 1970, the city's central Board of Education is planning to take over the fiscal management of at least three local districts because of abuses and loose practices that, it says, may have resulted in the waste or misuse of millions of dollars.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy says that one of the worst results of the Chappaquiddick incident has been "ugly speculation" about conduct between him and Mary Jo Kopechne.

EAGLE BAY, N. Y., Oct. 28 (AP)--Two white persons, including a 9-year-old girl, were shot and wounded tonight after Indians occupying a camp near here shot at passing automobiles they claimed had fired at them.

BOWERY BONANZA The Off Off Broadway season is off to a gallop, judging by three early entries. In addition to the Corner Loft's trio of short works by Michael Shurtleff and the WPA Theater's smashing revival of
A Newark urologist has obtained 8,300 registered voters' signatures on petitions calling for a referendum on raises recently voted the Mayor and the ninemember City Council.

When President Ford was House minority leader, he supported 86 per cent of the measures that increased spending above the amounts sought by the Republican Administration, the Democratic Study Group staff said today.
Two established stars teamed with four lesserknown young experts to win the Metropolitan Regional Knockout Team Championship at the New York Hilton Hotel here Sunday.
A few days ago some Spanish commentators on business affairs discovered to their shock that the giant Ford Motor Company had actually borrowed money from a Spanish bank.

Paul Jacoos nas long been respected as one of the leading new-music pianists in town. Last season he added some indefinable combination of fame and notoriety to his reputation by selflessly informing the world, publicly and persistently, of the inadequacies of one Marie-Francoise Bucquet, a French specialist in contemporary piano literature, who had four lavishly publicized Tully Hall recitals.

Polcemen used tear gas against 2,000 students today as thousands of other protestors demonstrated against the Government.' injuries or arrests were reported. The outbreaks followed protests by newsmen across the nation last week against Government suppression of the Dress.
A move to deport 800 Haitian immigrants who are in Canada illegally has touched off an angry controversy from the back streets of Montreal to the floor of the House of Commons.

James Napoli, reputed to be one of the five leading Mafia chieftains in the Metropolitan area, was sentenced to six months in prison and a $1,000 fine for criminal contempt before a Manhattan grand jury that five years ago was investigating the fixing of fights at Madison Sauare Garden.

When World War II ended, Washington embarked on an unusual and far-reaching program to feed millions of hungry people overseas, most of whom paid little or nothing for the basic foodstuffs they received.

The CNA Financial Corporation of Chicago, a holding company for insurance and real estate operations, said yesterday that its directors had decided to recommend that shareholders accept the offer from the Loews Corporation to buy 20 million shares at $6 a share for the common stock and $8 a share for the preferred.
Rabbi Jechiel M. Charlop, spiritual director of the Bronx Jewish Center for 46 years until it closed in 1971, died yesterday at his home, 190 East 206th Street, the Bronx. His age was 73.

Should the New England Patriots reach the Super Bowl in' January, and they appear to have as good a chance as anyone right now, they are sure to vote a full share of the spoils to Bob Windsor, their tight end who will not be with them that day.

A three-judge Federal court heard charges today that Mississippi gave a new interpretation to Its election laws to deny James H. Meredith, the civil rights figure, a place on its Nov. 5 ballot. Mr. Meredith,

Richard M. Nixon is not only out of the White House; he is out of the green book The 1975 edition of "The Social List of Washington, D.C.," which the former President has led every year since he was inaugurated in 1969, is out a month late because of the change in Administrations.

Just three days after taking office, President Ford told his former colleagues in the Congress, "I do not want a honeymoon with you. I want a good marriage." In the 11 weeks since that night in mid-August, the relationship between the new President and Congress has had its shaky moments.

The Board of Higher Education last night approved, by a vote of 6 to 3, the appointment of Dr. Elba Lugo de Luis-Deza as head of the department of Puerto Rican studies at Brooklyn College. Three members abstained.

Controller Arthur Levitt issued an audit report yesterday indicating that the state was losing hundreds of thousands of dollars a year because of sluggishness by the State Bank of Albany in processing income tax withholding payments.

One year after last winter's gasoline shortages began to be felt across most of America, the unthinkable has happened. Many of those who had to desert their automobiles and turn to mass transit have remained as transit riders, even though gasoline is plentiful again (probably not for long).
The wife and son of a British Government minister were badly shaken by a bomb that exploded tonight in a car outside their home in Birmingham, 110 miles northwest of here.

Dr. Edward James McCabe, a New York surgeon for 40 years, died yesterday of a heart attack in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old. Dr. McCabe had been attending surgeon at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals and Doctors Hospital,

Before the National Basketball Association season began this year, Bill Walton had been conceded rookie-of-the-year honors. The big red-haired Portland Trail Blazer was a household word in college basket ball last season when John Edward brew was a sophomore tucked away at.
Saudi Arabia plans to announce shortly a modest reduction in the price of her oil and the freezing of the price at the new level for a year, an informed Arab source said here today.

ATLANTA -- The nation's largest black enterprise, the Nation of Islam, is advocating the pooling of resources within the black economic community, regardless of religious viewpoints, as an alternative to possible closing of black businesses at a time of general economic problems.

Helen G. H. Estelle, former New York State president and world vice president of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, died Sunday in Elmhurst (Queens) General Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.
A Roosevelt pharmacist asked the Nassau County Board of Supervisors today to investigate the search of his home by 11 county policemen last Friday without a warrant.

Doctors said today that a paralyzed Texas Christian University running back, Kent Waldrep, had more sensation to touch, but that he had no more "motor power" than before his surgery Saturday night. Waldrep, 20 years old, was injured in T.C.U.'s 41-3 loss to Alabama. He landed on his head after being tackled in the second quarter and was instantly paralyzed from the neck down.

After months of pessimism about the future of the European Common Market, high West German officials have welcomed recent French proposals for closer political ties within the community as potentially a historic turning point.

Representative Robert H. Steele, who has sued the United States to equalize oil prices in various parts of the country, said he expected the Ford Administration to announce tomorrow a program doing just that.

Anna Langwell and Bertha Bailyn could not see each other very well, but the trip was a long and a strange one, so they kept saying each other's names so that one would always know the other was nearby.
Premier Kakuei Tanaka departed today on a 12-day journey to New s Zealand, Australia, and Burma -- leaving behind growing a doubts that he will survive in i office much longer.
The largest telescopic eye ever opened on the southern heavens has produced its first Photograph as a prelude to observations that are expected to broaden understanding of the universe.

The sunny skies and warm temperatures made it a glorious day for a parade yesterday, but there were no marching bands, streaming flags or cheering crowds along Fifth Avenue in New York City to celebrate Veteran's Day.

A 69-year-old retired kitchen worker was beaten to death today by robbers in his apartment and his bed-ridden wife was critically injured the police said. The body of John Levendusky, a retired employee of Jack's Kosher Deli in Ewing Township, was found by his son.

New York's next Governor will face demands that easily approximate 100 - million a year or more in new state and local costs for the 10 per cent of the people who are poorand at the same time Federal action to slash welfare reimbursement by millions of dollarn.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28--The General Assembly opened a debate on the Cyprus issue today, and the Cypriote delegate urged the assembly to demand the immediate withdrawal of all foreign armed forces from the island.

After three days of play in London in the finals for the world cup for backgammon, the Americans yesterday won 24 to 12. England nearly caught up with the Americans halfway through, but finally admitted defeat in the sixth round.

Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, Today warned Chancellor HelmIt Schmidt of West Germany against seeking a more favorble interpretation of the 1971 our-power agreement on West berlin and demanded instead is strict observance.

Would paying artists royalties on the resale of their work adversely affect the market for their art? Lawrence Fleischman, head of the Kennedy Galleries and a well-known dealer, said yes to that question last evening, and Robert Scull, the collector, said no.

Arab heads of state including Jordan's King Hussein have unanimously issued a declaration calling for the creation of an independent Palestinian state and recognizing the Palestine Liberation Organization as the "sole legitimate representative of the Palestine people." The decision was a victory for Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. [Page 1, Column 8.]
An Israeli soldier was wounded today by small-arms fire from southeast Lebanon, an army spokesman said. Israeli forces returned the fire, he added.

President Ford said today he was ordering Federal agencies to hire at least 70,000 Vietnam war veterans, whom he described as America's "silent heroes" in a Veterans Day address at the Arlington National Cemetery.
Two British soldiers were killed and 31 persons injured by a bomb that exploded in a parked truck near an army camp at Ballykinler, 20 miles south of here.

An international, live radio "call-in" show, termed the first of its kind, in which listeners in New York and London will be able to participate, will have its premiere tomorrow night on WMCA here and on the British/ Broadcasting Corporation in London.

A new rule to make It easier for stockbrokers to deal in gold and silver was proposed yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. Present rules would require a broker selling bullion on credit to charge the full amount of the transaction against capital--a provision, the exchange said, that would require firms to obtain payment unless a firm's capital were sufficient to absorb the charge.

The Treasury, preparing for its quarterly refunding cycle, disclosed yesterday that it would raise an extra $200-million in cash at its next bill auction, the date of which has been changed to Friday instead of next Monday.

A new theater is a cause for joy, and when that theateris a transformed cinema, the joy, at least for theaterlovers, is tinged with a certain sense of irony. So many theaters across the city have been cannibalized into cinemas, it is interesting to be reminded that such transmogrifications can be a twoway traffic.

The chief danger of a turn from "stagflation" to world depression lies in the temptation for the oil-consuming countries to try to export their collective $60- to $80billion in oil-payments deficits to each other. Adoption of import curbs, export subsidies, currency devaluation or domestic deflation by an oil -importing country to balance its trade is possible but it could only lead to retaliatory trade restrictions and a shrinking volume of world business.

A series of propane explosions ripped through an oilcompany distribution center in Enfield, Conn., yesterday afternoon, touching off a fire that critically burned two employes and melted cars in a nearby parking lot.

James A. Cullen, chairman of the King Kullen Grocery Co., Inc., and son of its founder who originated the supermarket style of grocery store, died yesterday at his home, 40 Thornhedge Road, Bellport, L. I. He was 62 years old.

The Soviet Union launched Today another in its series of unmanned spaceships, the press .agency Tass reported. It said the Luna-23, put into pace to continue scientific exploration of the moon and its vicinity, was functioning northally and maintaining stable radio contact with ground confrol.
A European Community report predicted today, the economic growth of the nine member countries could be somewhere between 4 per cent and 4.5 per cent for the period from 1973 to 1978.

ADLER-Murray. Beloved husband of Renee, devoted lather of James and John, dear brother of Solomon, Louis, Isaac and Bella; cherished grandfather of Nicole. Funeral services Wed., 10:30 A.M. at the I. J. Morris, Inc. Funeral Home, 9701 Church Ave. (cor. Rockaway Parkway), Bklyn. Please make contributions in his name to the Sloan-Kettering Cancer Research Institute.

There were so many admirable qualities in the playing of Robert Brooks, a young midwestern pianist who made his New York debut at Town Hall on Saturday, that it almost seems petulant to carp about his limitations.

When Mayor Richard G. Lugar of Indianapolis was introduced last week to the 200 members of the Southern Indiana Home Builders Association, they applauded loudly and a third of them rose and applauded even harder.

Although a mild afternoon recovery enabled the stock market to erase some of its earlier losses yesterday, prices closed lower in the slowest trading in more than four weeks. The late buying was attributed to investor encouragement over the continued decline in the prime lending rate.
Gold continues its week-long climb today, soaring to another five-month high on the London bullion market, where it closed $4.50 higher than Friday, at $168 an ounce.

The attorney for Paul J. Sherwin, the former New Jersey Secretary of State, plans to go to Federal Court in Trenton tomorrow in an attempt to overturn his client's conviction on bribery-conspiracy charges.
The Mississippi supreme Court refused today to overturn the murder conviction of a member of the Republic of New Africa, a black nationalist group, in the 1971 slaying of a Jackson police officer.
The Federal Energy Administration published today two regulations that could force some international oil companies to reduce gasoline and oil prices temporarily by a penny or two a gallon.

The Moscow press is suffering from a credibility gap that points up the problems of a closed society where unfavorable news is normally suppressed and people are inclined therefore to believe the worst.
Rodney Jenkins arid Number One Spy got the United States off to a fast start in the international open jumper class at the Washington International horse show today.
Saudi Arabia plans to announce shortly a modest reduction in the price of her oil and the freezing of the Price at the new level for a year, an: informed Arab source said here today.
Westchester County government and labor leaders moved today to find jobs for the 2,000 automobile workers in North Tarrytown who will be unemployed after Nov. 11.

In a display of force, uniformed and plainclothes policemen cordoned off three blocks of downtown Tu Do Street today with barbed wire and jeeps in anticipation of demonstrations that never materialized.

E. Howard Hunt Jr., one of the seven men who were allegedly paid off to keep silent about the Watergate break-in, testified today that he had continued to withhold the "entire truth" until his appearance in Court this morning.

A widespread feeling that crime has become worse in the state and that the state administration has not acquitted itself well on law-and-order matters is indicated by a survey of voter attitudes commissioned by The New York Times.

The American public believes it was wrong of the United States to intervene in Chile and try to destabilize the Government, a Harris poll survey yesterday indicated. Sixty per cent of a sample opposed the action,' 18 per cent supported it. and the rest had no opinion.

CAIRO, Oct. 28 (AP)--The Soviet Union, Egypt's major military and economic backer until a year ago, has agreed to resume a leading role in the Egyptian economy, Planning Minister Ismail Sabry Abdullah said today.

Developing countries increased their exports to apparently unprecedented levels last year, but it is questionable whether they can maintain such progress in the face of world economic difficulties, a major international trade organization said today.

Like the leaves on the trees, two issues that were heatedly debated at the height of the' summer gubernatorial primary have dropped away in the fall campaign. The issues - Governor Wilson's law practice while he was Lieutenant Governor and Representative Hugh L. Carey's ties to the oil industry-had been repeatedly raised by Howard J. Samuels during his unsuccessful bid for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

The West German Government's plan to create a giant new national oil and energy concern took shape today with the announcement of terms of a merger between the big power combine, Veba, A.G., and the oil company, Gelsenberg, A.G.
A 31-year-old counterman at a pizza-and-fried-chicken stand in the Bronx was shot to death yesterday afternoon by two young robbers he thought were joking when they demanded money, the police said.

Two men with a camera walked into a topless bar here this afternoon, and in the style of campaign dirty tricks, began taking pictures of a topless dancer seated next to a campaignn poster of Denis Dillon, the Democratic candidate for prosecutor.

A wave of telephoned bomb threats, attributed by the police to cranks inspired by Saturdays bombings in Manhattan, bedeviled precinct policemen and members of the bomb section and emergency service section yesterday.

A broad revision of United States agricultural policy, including provisions for Government-controlled stockpiles of key foodstuffs, was proposed today by a national organization of high-level business and university executives.

"As long as we find four walls and a roof to shelter the kids, that will be enough," said Panayotis Prokopiou as he gazed out at the rain-spattered deck. "We do believe there's no place like home-no matter what the home is like."

The Times begins today its election-year endorsements of Congressional candidates in the tri-state metropolitan area. Today's listing is for the five boroughs of New York City; tomorrow's will cover Suffolk, Nassau, Westchester and other nearby counties and neighboring districts in Connecticut and New Jersey. Districts are omitted where there is no contest or where no candidate is endorsed.

A 28-year-old police officer goes on departmental trial today charged with defacing the lavatory walls of a Brooklyn police station where he was said to have been caught pen in hand by detectives stakedout round the clock by the precinct commander.

The Saudi Arabian Government has offered $800-million to complete a take-over of the Arabian American Oil Company, according to a Beirut newspaper, Al Anwar. However, a spokesman for Aramco here said, "We have never heard of such an offer."

Sidney Baumgartner, a suspended assistant to Mayor Beame, was cleared yesterday in State Supreme Court, Queens, of charges of election law violation. In dismissing the charges, Justice Thomas S. Agresta said

Dr. Seymour E. Harris, an influential political economist and adviser to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, died yesterday at Veterans Hospital in San Diego. He was 77 years old. Dr. Harris, who taught at Harvard University for more than 40 years, had been emeritus professor of economics at the University of California at San Diego since 1963.

Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican Representative who was Richard M. Nixon's most pugnacious apologist, is in serious danger of being unseated in next week's Second Congressional District election because of his defense of the former President.

a dolphin was sighted in the harbor here at 9 A.M. today, and by late this afternoon grownups and children on Main Street and nearly everywhere else in this small 'village on Long Island's North Shore were asking, "How is he?"

The Jets have completed the first half of their dismal season and the most depressing prospect facing them is they have another half to go. When the season began, the Jets had what was potentially one of the easiest schedules in the National Football League.

Two Manhattan candidates, candidates, whose victories in the September Democratic primary were voided after legal challenges, won their races by increased margins yesterday in special court-ordered elections.
The political trust run by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has spent $1.4-million on politics this year, its latest campaign finance reports show.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday as the index and the price of an average share rose but declines outnumbered advances. In the over-the-counter market prices dropped. Trading was light on both markets because of the observance in some states of the Veterans Day holiday.

The proposed sale of Hialeah's racing dates to Gulfstream Park took a complex and confused turn today. State Attorney General Robert Shevin - has issued an opinion in Tallahassee that the sale is illegal, but the written opinion will not be available until tomorrow.

New York State is becoming] overdependent on foreign-born and foreign - educated physicians, many with inadequate medical ability, the State Board of Regents declared in a report yesterday that recommended steps to reverse the trend.

Albert Keep, headmaster from 1959 until his retirement in 1967 of the Antilles School in St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, died today of cancer in the North Adams Regional Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Williamstown.

William L. Called Jr. asked thee Supreme Court today to order his release from a military prison. His conviction on charges of murdering South Vietnamese civilians was overturned on Sept. 24 by United States District Judge J. Robert Elliott of Columbus, Ga.

Gary Davidson resigned today as commissioner of the World Football League after an apparent showdown with Tom Origer, owner of the Chicago Fire, who had threatened to withdraw his team from the league.

At a time of considerable instability in the democratic countries of Europe, even state and local elections take on heightened interest. There was unusual curiosity in European Community and NATO capitals about the effect of last weekend's state elections, in Bavaria and Hesse on Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's five-month-old West German coalition.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y.-Last weekend, a group of hearty men in blue blazers returned from Vienna to a hero's welcome in this tiny upstate resort. The townspeople gathered to escort their automobiles, press their hands and murmur "Great job."
Danny Gruen scored at 4:22 of sudden death overtime tonight to give the Michigan Stags a 4.3 World Hockey Association victory over the Minnesota Fighting Saints.

The second phase of Robert A. Maheu's defamation suit against Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive industrialist, opened today. The first phase of the trial took four months, ending in June.
President Giovanni Leone tonight asked Foreign Minister Aldo Moro to attempt to form a new cabinet to solve the country's government crisis.

The Warner-Lambert Company, the diversified pharmaceutical giant, yesterday reported the highest quarterly results in its history in the three months ended Sept. 30, lifting the ninemonth figures to a record.

The head of South Vietnam's largest labor union today shifted away from his usual pro-Government position and issued an appeal for the eradication of corruption, the implementation of the Paris truce agreements and the establishment of democratic liberties.

The State Department announced today that an exhibition of Chinese art and archeological artifacts, ranging from a jade-and-gold shroud to a bronze "flying horse," will go on display at the National Gallery of Art here Dec. 13.

Only a few hours before the Muhammad Ali-George Foreman heavyweight title fight in Kinshasa, Zaire, early tomorrow, the West German television system purchased the rights for live coverage of the bout.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29--Lawyers for the special prosecutor's office said today that former President Richard M. Nixon's assertion that he needs his original tapes and documents to prepare for his possible testimony at the Watergate cover-up trial was baseless.

The Board of Education moved yesterday to strengthen its depleted audit staff as part of what it called a new gettough policy to curb financial abuses and irregularities by some community school districts.

The Hirschfeld Bank of Commerce, a bank being organized in tidewater Virginia with ambitious plans to raise as much as $76-million in initial capital, has run into a storm of opposition from corporate executives and regulators.

Silverius C. McCaffrey, retired general superintendent of station construction and shops department of Consolidated Edison, died Monday at St. Johns Hospital in Yonkers. He was 76 years old and lived at 65 Lefferts Road' in Yonkers.

Phil Chenier and Elvin Hayes combined for 47 points tonight to lead unbeaten Washington to its sixth consecutive National Basketball Association triumph as the Capitals crushed the sagging Chicago Bulls, 96-80.

Harry Kalven Jr., a professor of law at the University of Chicago and an authority on the First Amendment and the American Jury system, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Chicago. He was 60 years old.

Spurred by a continuing decline in short-term interest rates, the stock market ignored some bearish news yesterday and registered its biggest gain in almost three weeks.

Judge Merrit Lane Jr. today lifted his earlier order that striking Long Branch school employes and the Board of Education hold nonstop negotiations until a settlement is reached.

The United States Steel Corporation yesterday reported net income for the September quarter soared by 144.7 per cent on a gain of 38.9 per cent in sales.

City detectives from the bomb section are continuing their investigation of the five bombings of banking and corporate centers in Manhattan early last Saturday, for which a Puerto Rican nationalist group said it was responsible.

Under an African moon in the darkness before dawn today, a bee battered a lion as Muhammad Ali registered an eighth-round knockout of George Foreman and regained the world heavyweight title at the age of 32 after a lapse of more than seven years.

Participants in a conference of institutional money managers and securities firms with the Securities and Exchange Commission appeared agreed today that fixed minimum commission rates on brokerage transactions had little or nothing to do with profits or losses of brokerage firms in the last few years.

Police Officer Stephen Lucadamo, accused of "defaming" his commanding officer, two sergeants and a woman officer with "obscene and scurrilous" graffiti on the lavatory walls of a Brooklyn station house, pleaded no defense at a brief departmental trial yesterday at police headquarters, 1 Police Plaza.

The Social Committee gave unanimous support today to a move backed by the United States urging the United Nations to take action in helping account for missing and dead in wars. About a thousand Americans are still missing in Indochina.

The dissolution of the Seattle Kings football club was announced today by Hugh McElhenny, the general manager. McElhenny said Wayne Field, the president of the group, had written to Pete Rozelle, the National Football League Commissioner, telling him of the action.

Freight rate increases totaling more than 20 per cent in the last year helped the Union Pacific Corporation, parent of the railroad of the same name, to report record revenues and earnings for the third quarter and first nine months this year.

Unless they find a miraculous formula in the next week, California Republicans are expected to take a beating on Election Day. The dimensions of their problem are as follows: Only one of the six officers of the state government who are elected statewide is currently a Democrat, but it is expected that only one will be a Republican after next Tuesday's elections.

There is an unwritten law that New Yorkers should suffer a. lot. The ultimate torture is transportation. Buoyed by a continued decline in interest rates, the stock market yesterday made its best gain in almost three weeks, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average up 25.50 points.

Stockholders of Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., approved yesterday a previously announced proposal to reduce the par value of the company's common stock to 10 cents a share from $2.50 and the preferred stock to 10 cents a share from $1.

An expert in the field of early child development yesterday strangely critized the educational program at the Willowbrook State School for the Mentally Retarded, on Staten Island, and said the institution's "barren physical and psychological environment" led to regressive development among residents.

The price of gold soared to over $170 an ounce on the London market today for the first time in six months, but later fell back because of profit taking, and closed at $167.75 in both London and Zurich.

The National Republican Congressional Committee said today that a last-minute appeal for big campaign contributions had brought good results. However, David Cole of the committee's finance division said that no figures would be available for several days.

The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the minimum fees that many bar associations have for years required lawyers to charge their clients are a form of illegal price-fixing.

John R. Bunting, vice chairman of the Delaware River Port Authority, said today that if the authority was required to roll back tolls on its three bridges between New Jersey and Pennsylvania it would block the order in court.

Puerto Rican advocates of independence fur the island expect to get another hearing today before the United Nations' special 24-nation Committee on Colonialism, amid widely differing views of their following at home and on the mainland.

William J. Sheehan, a retired vice president and regional manager in Boston for Doremus Co., advertising and public relations agency, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Newton Centre, Mass. He was 72 years old.

Willard M. Bright, who joined the Curtiss-Wright Corporation Feb. 1 as president and chief operating officer, has resigned as an officer and director of the New Jersey-based company, which holds exclusive rights to the Wankel engine in North America.

James Earl Riy testified today that he had "addresses and telephone numbers" of others-involved in events leading to the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968, but that he had never given most of this information to his lawyers.

The Philadelphia Daily News endorsed Gov. Milton J. Shapp today for re-election. In an editorial, the newspaper said that Governor Shapp, a Democrat, "was not without blemishes but when they are compared to his accomplishments we will take him over Republican Drew Lewis."

Robert Gardner's stunning documentary, "Rivers of Sand," operates on two levels at once: It educates us about the daily life of the Hamar people of southwestern Ethiopia, and, while exploring an utterly alien culture, the narrative also dwells on a phenomenon that everyone knows well-that is, male supremacy.

With Congressional elections just one week away, Senator Walter F. Mondale is campaigning as if he were one of the candidates up for election. The Minnesota Democrat is putting in long days on the campaign trail, but the race in which he is really interested won't be held until 1976; the Senator is seeking the Democratic nomination for President.

A tour with President Ford of the Presidential retreat at Camp David, Md.,, which was filmed last weekend as an episode of ABC-TV's "The Reason. er Report," has been withheld from broadcast this Saturday on the ground that its political overtones might be considered an influence on Tuesday's elections.
The interest rate on passbook savings accounts at the European-American Bank and Trust Company will be increased to 5 per cent from 4 1/2 per cent, effective tomorrow, the bank announced yesterday.

President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam removed three army corps commanders accused of corruption. This apparent bow to opposition pressure was spurned by Rev. Tran Huu Thanh, a Catholic priest who has been spearheading an opposition coalition.

The National Football League yesterday went for more. The 26 owners sold an expansion franchise to Tampa, Fla., and to Tom McCloskey, a Philadelphia builder, for $16-million and the league indicated that it would do more.

Hugh G. Bergen, a lawyer who had been president of the Nassau and Queens Counties Bar Associations, died yesterday at his home, 5 Robbins Drive, East Williston, L. I. He was 75 years old.
Inez Goddin Freeman, widow of Douglas Southall Freeman, the historian and Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer, died yesterday at her home in Richmond. She was 83 years old.

Jurors and defendants walked across the Kent State University campus today, retracing the steps of the National Guardsmen and student antiwar protesters who clashed there early 4 1/2 years ago.
The United States Amateur champion, Jerry Pate, shot a oneover-par 73 today to help the United States take a oneshot lead in the first round of the world amateur golf championship.

Jeb Stuart Magruder testified at the Watergate cover-up trial today that he was informed in the summer of 1972 that President Richard M. Nixon was pleased with his efforts to keep the truth about Watergate from coming out.

Henrich (Han) Jordan, retired executive vice president of the Slavenburg Corporation, a commercial financing house, died Sunday at United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. He was 72 and lived at the Orienta Point Apartments, Mamaroneck.

Former President Richard M. Nixon-his finances deteriorating, according to aides-faces a large personal medical bill for his phlebitis treatment.

The Black Theater Alliance, an association of 30 independent black theatrical groups, will hold its fourth annual festival of plays at the Harlem Cultural Council, Seventh Avenue and 137th Street, from next Wednesday through Dec. 8.
Spokesmen for livestock producers caught in a cost-price squeeze urged President Ford today to cut meat imports and give them a bigger share of the meat sold in American supermarkets.

Robert I. Postel, a former City Councilman who lost a Democratic primary election on Monday for nomination to the Assembly in the 68th Assembly District on the Upper East Side, was served with legal papers in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday in a case arising from his alleged interference with the distribution of a weekly newspaper that backed his rival, Alexander B. Grannis.

Doris Kiene Padley, a retired member of the staff of Mount Holyoke College, died Monday at he Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N. Y. She was 75 years old.

The cost of feeding a family of four went up eight-tenths of a per cent last week in New York City, compared with the week before. The City Department of Consumer Affairs reported yesterday that its 39item Market Basket cost $63.89 up 52 cents.

Representative Hugh L. Carey's campaign is running $700,000 in the red despite polls that show him the frontrunner and despite an acceleration of major contributions in anticipation of victory, according to the last pre-election financial reports compiled by the candidates.
The Chicago Bulls, helped by Chet Walker's 8 second-quar ter points, built a 19-poin half-time lead tonight and held on to beat the Boston Celtics, 105-104.

Underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation marketed yesterday 4 million new common shares of the Southern California Edison Company common stock at $17.75 per share. Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market rose again yesterday for the second straight session.

All the Irish Rovers had to do to get an enthusiastic response from their audience after they bounced out on the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening was to mention anything pertaining to Ireland. The audience clapped for Ireland.

The undefeated Washington Bullets ran their winning streak to seven games tonight in a contest with the Knicks that began as a comedy of errors and wound up in a close, physical defensive struggle.
