Police officials said yesterday that they did not feel that the murder Monday night of a Brooklyn man with mob consections was a gangland execution.
A young man accused of mugging John F. Kennedy Jr. told the police he had sold the boy's bike to buy two bags of cocaine, a policeman testified at a pretrial hearing yesterday.

World sugar futures contracts rose the 1-cent-a-pound limit yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange--as they have each day this week. Each day a record high has been set for the March delivery. Yesterday is was 44.97 cents a pound.

Ramsey Clark, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, told a luncheon meeting of labor leaders yesterday that the Nixon-Ford Aministration, and Senator Jacob K. Javits, the Republican-Liberal whose seat he seeks, "have forgotten the working people who built this country and all countries."

To the Editor: Accepting your own premise that "the critical issue" of this gubernatorial campaign. is the capacity of the candidates to "demonstrate leadership and imagination," it is incredible to me that The New York Times could have gone so far wrong as to endorse Mr. Carey. The Times editorial [Oct. 28] is governed neither by logic nor by reason.

The Ford Motor Company announced today that its earnings for the third quarter of this year were off 50.1 per cent from the same quarter last year despite a massive effort by the company to capitalize on the smallcar market.

A one-hour demonstration by 75 to 100 people protesting traffic conditions on West Side streets in the area from 72d to 79th Street caused by detours on the Henry Hudson Parkway led to the arrest of three men yesterday.

An immediate halt to the purchase of spray cans using a propellant that some scientists fear may threaten the earth's protective ozone layer was recommended yesterday by the chairman of a committee appointed to assess the alleged threat.

Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany wound up three days of negotiations with Soviet leaders today amid indications that Moscow might be making some adjustments in its intransigence over West Berlin.

H. Virgil Sherrill, president and chief executive of the brokerage house of Shields Model Roland, Inc., was named here yesterday to serve as board chairman of the Securities Industry Association, the investment community's trade group.
Republican and Democratic politicans agreed today that former President Richard M. Nixon's grave illness was unlikely to change radically the outcome of Tuesday's elections.

The majority of textile and L dye workers in the metropolitan area will return to work today, ending a 25-day strike that has virtually shut down the Industry in the area.

A three-judge Federal court accused James Meredith today of trying to abuse state election procedures and denied a petition to place his name on the ballot in the fourth Congressional District race.

The latest turn in the health of former President Richard M. Nixon has added new elements of uncertainty to the Watergate cover-up trial. It has raised the possibility that Mr. Nixon may not be well enough for months, or perhaps ever. to testify as a witness.

The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized the nation's airlines yesterday to raise domestic air fares by 4 per cent Nov. 15 and made permanent a 6 per cent surcharge imposed on travelers last spring as an emergency measure to offset higher fuel bills. The surcharge had been scheduled to expire last night.

State Transportation Commissioner Alan Sagner announced today that agreement had been reached on a $6-million Federal subsidy for the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey to enable it to continue freight service through June 30, 1975.

Charles S. (Buddy) Myer Jr., the 1935 American League batting champion, died today at a hospital here. He was 70 years old.
An eminent Buddhist scholar, Bidiya D. Dandaron, has died in a Soviet labor camp less than two years after being sent there to serve a five-year sentence, a friend of his said here today.

Black singers are moving with ever-increasing numbers and ever-increasing authority into the middle-of-the-road repertory that used to be dominated by white singers. Sometimes they do it so successfully that they become firmly identified with such material to the exclusion of almost everything else-Roberta Flack, for instance.

Pete Beathard hit Rufus Ferguson with two touchdown passes in the first half and the Portland Storm went on to a 14-0 victory over the Shreveport Steamer in a nationally televised World Football League game tonight.

New gasoline taxes of as much as 45 cents a gallonmore than the total price of gasoline a few years ago-are outlined as a possible oil conservation measure in an analysis that is expected to go to the Ford Administration soon.

The The National Football League announced yesterday that none of its 26 teams would be able to sign players from the rival World Football League for the remainder of the season.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation rounded up today the last of the suspects in the record $4.3-million Chicago vault burglary, bringing two deported men back to the United States from the British West Indies and arresting another man here.
Postrace blood testing of thoroughbreds, a procedure designed to tighten security against the use of drugs and illegal medications, will begin today at Aqueduct.

Former President Richard M. Nixon's doctors said late today that they expected gradual improvement in his condition, but that they remained concerned over postoperative complications and "dangers lurking in the background."

The president of the parents' association of the Willowbrook State School for the Mentally Retarded testified yesterday that a 25-year-old male resident choked to death last Tuesday evening after finishing a "substitute meal" of bread and potatoes.

African delegates said today they might ask the General Assembly to adopt a resolution deploring yesterday's vetoes of a Security Council motion calling for the expulsion of South Africa from the United Nations.

The United States moved to a commanding lead in the 16th Washington International Horse Show at the D.C. Armory today, winning two international jumper classes. More companies announced layoffs yesterday as slumps in major industries are beginning to affect employment in smaller, dependent secondary industries.

President Ford summoned the top negotiators for the coal industry to the White House today to receive an updated report on efforts to avert a miners' strike, which could begin in nine days. The news he got was guarded but good.

Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity signed today a "final order" instructing the Boston School Committee to develop a citywide school integration plan by Dec. 16.

Yugoslavia has formally accused Austria, her neighbor to the north, of harboring Nazis and tolerating activity hostile to Yugoslav interests.

Some bearish economic news and profit taking ended the stock market's two-session sharp advance yesterday as prices finished mixed in slower trading. The Dow Jones industrial average finished off 7.51 points at 665.52, its low for the day.
High officials of the Ford Administration announced two new actions today, both aimed at dealing with the possibility that business misconduct is playing a major role in rising prices.
The New Jersey Turnpike Authority today approved and sent to Governor Byrne a proposal to increase tolls by 37 per cent for trucks and passenger cars on the 142-mile highway.

To judge from Queen Elizabeth's speech opening the new British Parliament, Prime Minister Wilson's Government intends to push hard for enactment of Labor's entire election platform, including outright nationalization of several industries and an extension of public ownership in others. The United Parcel Service threatened. last night to close its entire New York metropolitan operation permanently if Local 804 of the teamsters union did not accept what was termed a "final" offer to end the 65-day-old strike by 4,500 employees.

In her return yesterday. to her official duties as White House hostess, Betty Ford served punch and cookies to a witch, a ghost, Dracula and three other scary-looking characters raising money for the United Nations Children's Fund.

Chapter XI petition for an arrangement by: WILLMARK SERVICE SYSTEM INC., a shopping service agency, at 443 Park Ave. South, N.Y. Signed by Robert M. Bernstein, president. Liabilities, $90,594; assets, $53, 700.

CLEVELAND (AL)--Signed Mike O'Keefe right-handed pitcher, and assigned him to Sarasota of the Gulf Coast League. PHILADELPHIA (NL)--Waived Frank Linzy, right-handed pitcher, and Pete Richert, left-handed pitcher. Purchased Quency Hill, Larry Kiser, left-handed pitcher; Fred Andrews.

Chris Evert broke service in the second and sixth games of the opening set today and went on to beat Virginia Wade of England, 6-1, 6-3, in the final of the women's singles in the $135,000 World invitation tennis tournament.

The Federal Government's chief mediator, W. J. Usery Jr., agreed yesterday to step into the two-month-old United Parcel Service strike here in an effort to break the deadlock before the pre-Christmas rush further pyramids delivery problems.
National Airlines' passenger jets operated today for the first time since July 15.

When it became apparent in Los Angeles last night that President Ford would pay a hospital visit to his ailing predecessor, a campaign aide to Houston I. Flournoy, the Republican candidate for Governor, groaned and said, "We can't get rid of this burden."

A former Kent State University student who was wounded by Ohio National Guardsmen testified today that a single guardsman fired into a group of students on May 4, 1970, and "within a tenth of a second" a number of other guardsmen turned and fired into the crowd.
The death was reported here today of Baroness Moura Budberg, author, translator and production adviser on plays, movies and television. She was 82 years old.

Brooklyn Tech and Van Buren won Public Schools Athletic League cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx, yesterday. Tech scored 80 points to win the Brooklyn championship, defeating South Shore (106), New Utrecht (178) and Sheepshead Bay (181).

Superior Court Judge Merritt Lane Jr. today ordered striking Long Branch teachers, custodians and clerks to return to their jobs Monday and issued strict requirements to the employe associations to notify members about the order.

James Earl Ray killed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. believing he would be the "champion of the white race," and then readily pleaded guilty because he was confident no prison could hold him, his former attorney testified today.
Bullet Joe Bush, a major league pitcher who won 193 games for seven baseball teams, died today in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 81 years old and had lived here many years.
The cost of a cab ride here went up an average of 17.5 per cent yesterday, but most New Yorkers-passengers and drivers alike-seemed to accept the increase philosonhically.
Tickets for six National Football League games scheduled for tomorrow have been sold out and the contests will be offered for local telecasts, a league spokesman said yesterday.
The. Harirs County medical examiner said today that an 8-year-old boy had died of cyanide poisoning from eating Halloween candy.

Justice Peter T. Farrell of State Supreme Court in Queens has dismissed the attemptedmurder indictment against Joanne D. Chesimard, an alleged member of what the police call the Black Liberation Army, because of insufficient evidence.
Women's multifarious part in history, long neglected or underestimated by traditional historians in the West-mostly male--is now being uncovered, publicized and promoted with extraordinary zeal.

President Ford has named Rabbi Murray Saltzman of the Indianapolis Hebrew Congregation to the United States Civil Rights Commission, Representative William Hudnut, Republican of Indiana, announced today.

There is something almost archetypal about the career Josee de Creeft, the American sculptor who will be observing his 90th birthday Nov. 27, but the archetype is not that of a representative modernist.
Unemployment increased to 6 per cent of the work force in October, its highest level in nearly three years, according to Labor Department figures made public today.
Mayor Beame told city agencies yesterday that they would have less money to spend on new construction in the fiscal year that will begin next July 1 than in any of the last seven years.
The regular body of musicians that makes up the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center was supplemented last night in Tully Hall by no less august a personage than Rudolf Serkin.
William A. Healy, former assistant commissioner of labor for New York State and former chief clerk of the State Senate, died Thursday at his home, 132 Monroe Street. He was 84 years old.

Retarded children crawl, or just sprawl, on corridor floors. Their infirmary is a small room without medical instruments or an examining table. Children who were placid now have tantrums and fight. They have regressed badly in many ways.

Ending 10 weeks of recuperation from a heart attack, Premier Souvanna Phouma returned today from Paris to find his coalition Government still intact and apparently durable. The absence of the 72-yearold neutralist had presented the coalition with its greatest risk so far, for Souvanna Phouma is a symbol of reconciliation to both the Communist-oriented Pathet Lao and the pro-Western Vientiane side.
An election watchdog commission said today that more than onethird of the 2,738 county and local candidates in Tuesday's election had failed to file their first campaign finance reports on time.

The Toho School of Music in Tokyo is one of the world's foremost institutions of its special kind, and the Toho String Orchestra dramatized that fact breathtakingly at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night.

Along with all the other gloom in this troubled province, there is a growing feeling these days that British Government policy is approaching bankruptcy. To many Roman Catholics land Protestants, it appears that British officials have run out of ideas and perhaps even interest in Northern Ireland and its sectarian violence.
Miami fullback Larry Bates scored on an 18-yard pass in the third quarter tonight to give the Hurricanes a 14-7 victory over stubborn Virginia Tech.
A political crisis involving his running mate posed a mounting threat today to Republican Gov William G. Milliken's shaky chances for re-election.

Elizabeth Ann Grumbach, who is with the commercial lending department of the Bank of New York and Lewis Turner Jr., a member of the corporate lending department of the Bankers Trust Company, were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George J. Grumbach in West Orange, N.J.

The housing complex of four U-shaped, dark brick 'steppeddown buildings on the East River between 107th and 111th Streets--known as 1199 Plaza--was formally dedicated yesterday morning by Mayor Beame.

The State Thruway Authority has adopted a resolution that could minimize Republican losses in terms of political patronage in the event the Democrats take over the state government in next Tuesday's election.

Left without a scoring forward since Willie Wise quit the team because of a contract dispute, the Utah Stars yesterday attempted to fill the need by purchasing Roger Brown from the Memphis Sounds for an undisclosed amount of cash and a future draft choice.

Inflation, escalating salaries and the soaring cost of steel have put a new price tag of $5.98-billion on the trans, Alaska pipeline, up from the previous estimate of $4.5-billion, a company official said today;

Former President Richard M. Nixon's doctor said today that he "is slowly and steadily improving" and had less pain, although he still needed "critical care" for complications resulting from an operation last Tuesday.

The owners of the Detroit Loves have received offers by groups in three cities to buy the World Team Tennis franchise, Marshall Greenspan, the team's executive vice president, said today. In making its pitch for the 1975 national women's and girls' outdoor track and field championships, the city of White Plains offered more than a $15,000 guarantee to the Amateur Athletic Union.

Turkish Cypriotes are resettling in large sections of Cyprus that were occupied last summer by troops from Turkey. One of the key issues in any discussion about the future of Cyprus is whether the Greek-Cypriote refugees who fled the Turkish Army troops will be allowed to return to their homes.

A Presidential commission on Venezuela's oil industry proposed today a further reduction of output. Venezuela has reduced production by 10 per cent to three million barrels daily since President Carlos Andres took office last March.

Andre, Jr. Also survived by one grandson, William Floyd-Jones, Jr. Funeral services on Saturday, Nov. 2 at 11 A.M., Heavenly Rest Church, 5th Ave 90th St. In lieu of flowers contributions to The Community Hospital, at Glen Cove, N.Y. would be appreciated.

The on-again, off-again traffic pattern to ease vehicular problems on the Upper West Side is on again. Two lanes of the Henry Hudson Parkway between 72d and 79th Streets will once more accommodate both northbound and southbound traffic-but at different times of the day.
Herbert Kuhl, a 41-year-old mason, lost his job last week and came to the union office to find, for the first time in. his experience, that there' were no jobs immediately open.

Paul J. Sherwin, the former New Jersey Secretary of State, lost another round in court today when United States District Court Judge Clarkson S. Fisher refused to free him pending decision on his appeal for a new trial in the state courts.
The First National City Bank, New York's largest bank, announced yesterday that it would lower its prime rate on corporate loans to 103/4 per cent on Monday.
Capitalizing on four Columbia fumbles and a blocked kick for its first five touchdowns, the Army lightweight football team routed the Lions, 61-0, yesterday at Baker Field.

Some of the most sumptuous of all European paintings were painted by Matisse before 1914. They had as their subject matter the painter's own studio. Anand and Vijay Amritraj said today they wold not represent their country again in Davis Cup competition following India's refusal to play South Africa in the 1974 fi nal.

Three Bronx youths were indicted yesterday in the murder of a 70-year-old woman and the robbery of three other elderly women, one of whom was also raped.

To the Editor: Your Oct. 25 editorial endorsement of Senator Javits, while not unexpected, was nevertheless disappointing. After carefully reading the editorial several times, my disappointment was all the greater.

Rudolf Smutny, a major figure in investment banking circles for many years, died Thursday of a heart attack inNassau Hospital, Mineola, L. I. He was 76 years old and lived at 85 11th Street, Garden City, L. I.
Muhammad Ali, the heavyweight boxing champion again, landed in style here today with the comment: "Yes, I've given thought to retirement. I'm getting old."

To the Editor: Peter Edelman's review of "Serving Justice" (Oct. 6) contains a serious error. An in forma pauperis petition to the Supreme Court is "automatically denied" unless at least one Justice asks that it be placed on the weekly conference list for discussion. But, contrary to Mr. Edelman's suggestion, precisely the same procedure is followed with respect to "paid petitioners."

George Bush, the new chief of the United States liaison office in China, met with Deputy Premier Teng Hsiao-ping in Peking today, a Chinese broadcast said.

IT was a typical morning at Elhae. Peering out from my plaid hammock under the magnificent thatched dome of the Oyana Indian guesthouse, I saw a bare-breasted maiden in red loincloth with matching red elastic garters, her body tinted red with vegetable dye, stoking the breakfast campfire. Meanwhile, one of the boatmen shot a green parrot for his lunch.

Once upon a time the Carnegie Institute in Pittsburgh was the American museum that European artists most longed to know about, to talk about, and eventually to hear from. That night on the shore of Lake Van I was grateful for a few hours to myself.

Bobby Smith flipped in a 15-footer with 58 seconds left and Jim Cleamons made a pair of foul shots with three seconds to go tonight to give the Cleveland Cavaliers a 104-101 National Basketball Association victory over the Phoenix Suns.

Secretary of State Kissinger announced that he would visit Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Jordan, Syria and Israel next week to explore "the possible next steps toward a Middle East peace." He arrived in Bucharest.

Players in New York clubs will Have two unusual opportunities this month. They will be able to take the first step on the long road to international honors and, more significantly for the great majority, they will be able to fight for the red points that are needed for life master rank.
" It's surreal," said one of the lawyers in the Watergate cover-up trial. "I sit in court and I listen and I want to stand up and say, 'Hold it, stop this trial, what's going on here?'"

Although there has been much talk and some modest action on reforming the electoral system in the wake of Watergate, there is one ultimate reform without which all other efforts to strengthen the democratic process will have been in vain. That is a radical change in the abominable voting habits of American citizens.

At an annual cost of 62 cents a person-the price of a pack of cigarettes-New York State residents are promised a big package of railroad improvements if they vote for the $250million rail bond issue on next Tuesday's ballot.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y.--Judy Blau regarded the sea of bagels in the bathtub and allowed as how her family would be taking no baths for the next two days. "But there's a shower in the other bathroom," she said, brightening, "and when these bagels come out we have three more days for baths before the next shipment comes in."

Arthur D. Shaw, owner of Erlandsen, Crowell Shaw, civil and land surveyors, Jamaica, Queens, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L.I. He was 68 years old and lived at 92-27 215th Place, Queens village, Queens.
Boston's calm continued over the weekend as a contingent of National Guardsmen, on alert for 20 days, was reduced by twothirds.

The Public Schools Athletic League settled its final football division title yesterday and set up the quarterfinal playoffs, to begin Saturday. The three-team tie in Queens Division II was broken in favor of August Martin, which had allowed the fewest points in division games. Martin had allowed 12. The other contenders, Jacksonand Springfield Gardens, had given up 14. Martin faces Bayside at Memorial Field, Flushing.

Dr. Erwin Fletcher Smith, for many years director of obstetrics and gynecology in the City Hospital Center, Elmhurst, Queens, died Saturday at his home in Old Brookville, L. I. He maintained offices here and in Manhasset, L. I.

On election night, the cliche that most often sails through the television tube is "tantamount to election." No commentator will ever say "equivalent" or "as much as"; only "tantamount" will do, apd its certain reappearance every two years may light the way to other bromides we may expect to hear Tuesday night.
Dominick Barbaro was recently browsing in the showroom of Herbert Rosenstock, Inc., Oldsmobile dealer on the West Side of Manhattan, looking for a car for his son.
A farmer found the bodies of a Texas couple today in the wreckage of their singleengine plane, which apparently crashed attempting a landing in a field during a severe snowstorm.

Two senior members of the Senate Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights have asked the Justice Department to delay action on a Federal Bureau of Investigation communications plan that critics have said might lead to Federal control of local police.

" Peter, have you forgotten? You've got to drive now," called out Billy Haughton to his 20-year-old son, who was talking in the paddock. "Gotta run," said Peter Haughton as he headed for the track at Roosevelt Raceway late last night.

The debate about casino gambling in New Jersey went down to the wire yesterday with a lot of questions unanswered-who would run the casinos, who would profit from them, where would they be and how many of them, and how much good or harm would they do the state.

The board of directors of the Advertising Research Foundation had a very busy session Friday electing a new, full-time, paid president, a chairman, and for the first time in its 38-year history an executive director.
A landlord and his son were arrested yesterday on charges of setting a two-alarm blaze in their Lower East Side tenement in which they were burned badly, authorities said.

Three persons, including an 1l-year-old girl, were killed today in a gun battle in a crowded Thai cafe. Two persons were injured.

Taking no chances tonight against the aspiring New York Islanders, the Philadelphia Flyers brought out Kate Smith, kept their sticks and fists down and presented the sellout crowd of 17,007 with a 3-1 victory.

How did it happen here? How did our beautiful block, West 77th Street, become notorious as the scene of nine murders? And why should anybody besides the thousand of us who live here care? Because the trouble. and tragedies that have come to this street make us a microcosm of New York City.
Many large contributors to Republican Congressional campaigns two years ago are giving nothing or relatively little to candidates this year.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos today offered a sweeping amnesty to those persons the Government regards as ideo logical subversives.

The State Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, has sent out a personal letter to 600 county committeemen in his district, jogging them to get out the Republican vote and prevent defeat in what politicians say is the toughest fight of his 20-year legislative career.
Governor Byrne urged New Jersey residents yesterday to approve $590-million worth of bond issues on the Tuesday ballot, saying that they would help revive the state's declining economy.

VILNA, U.S.S.R. -- This Lithuanian capital won the Lenin Prize for architecture this year for its effort to relieve the sameness of Soviet public housing with the design of an apartment house subdivision.

Puerto Rico's government is carrying on a vigorous program of offering free--but voluntary-sterilization to cope with a population problem that it calls "the most critical in the Americas" The island has a higher population density per square mile than Japan, India or China.
An Attica trials defendant, Frank Tmith, pleaded not guilty today to charges of felony possession of three and a half ounces of marijuana, the police said.
Sundays in Germany are a family affair, and the traditional rituals--the Sunday roast and the afternoon walk, followed by coffee and cakes--are still being observed with rigorous determination.

The Bergen County Office of Consumer Affairs and Protection has tallied up its case load for the first six months of this year and produced a cross section of the major complaints that seem to be bothering consumers everywhere.

In Western Europe, which many would consider a densely-populated area, there are now about 85 people per square kilometer. South Asia, on the most cautious estimates of population growth, will add 140 people per square kilometer over the next 25 years.

Most of the superior officers in the Suffolk County Police Department were back on duty yesterday following the suspension of 93 sergeants and lieutenants who called in sick Thursday and Friday in a job action related to a salary dispute. The job action was called after it was learned that there would be a delay in a decision by a panel arbitrating the dispute.
A young woman and an absent-without-leave sailor, both prisoners in the Suffolk County jail in Riverhead, L.I., hanged themselves Saturday in cells there, the police said.
Striking teachers, custodians and secretarial personnel today approved a new two-year contract with the Long Branch Board of Education, ending a two-week strike.

WASHINGTON-President Ford has attempted the difficult feat of turning the Congressional election into a referendum on his anti-inflation program. Since local and state issues and personalities always create innumerable crosscurrents and since his own name is not on the ballot, it is hard for any President to structure the debate in a mid-term election.
With the final tour event completed, it is now official that Johnny Miller set a Professional Golfers' Association record for earnings with a total purse of $353,030 for 1974.
A 70-year-old magistrate was fatally shot as he presided over night court last eveing in Wanaque, N.J.

Bob Stallings of Freeport, L.L. scored the biggest. victory of his 10-year pro career last night when he scored on a unanimous decision over Earnie Shavers of Warren, Ohio in a 10-round heavyweight fight at the Felt Forum.
Collectors from the United States took the lion's share of awards as Exfilmex '74, the fifth InterAmerican Philatelic Exhibition, came to a close here.
Five Canadian companies have joined to study the feasibility of building a new pipeline to carry oil from the Mackenzie Delta and Beauford Sea areas, Imperial Oil, Ltd., said today.
Two major banks reduced their prime rate to 10 3/4 per cent from 11 per cent yesterday, matching Friday's move by First National City Bank, the biggest in New York.
Delaware obtained custody today of Juan Guzman, a 14-year-old Newark boy who came here five weeks ago with a chicken farmer.
Unglazed, terra-cotta casseroles have been big sellers in housewares departments for several years, but after they're used a couple of times many have been relegated to the attic or the top shelf.
Maj. Gen. George A. Horkan, Quartermaster General of the Army from 1951 to his retirement in 1954, died Saturday in Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 80 years old.
Steel production for the week ended Nov. 2 slipped by 1.3 per cent to 2,814,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel In. stitute reported yesterday.
The value of construction for which contracts were awarded in September rose 4 per cent from September, 1973, to a total of $8.35-billion, the McGraw-Hill Information System reported yesterday.

OUR Government, designed to serve thirteen former Colonies in 1789, needs a twentieth-century updating. Not new goals, but new methods are needed: methods by which government can be made more responsive to its citizens.

Members of the Red Bank Regional football team make a minimum of noise in the fieldhouse Saturday mornings as they make final preparations for the afternoon game. They leave the noise to the stereo cassette player.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, says an overwhelming victory by Democrats in tomorrow's elections would be "bad for the party and also bad for the country."

Secretary of State Kissinger's visit to the Indian subcontinent has begun the long-overdue process of restoring American priorities in South Asia to their proper order. The Nixon Administration's pro-Pakistan "tilt" in 1971, during the war that resulted in the creation of Bangladesh, left New Delhi alienated, most American aid suspended and normal relations virtually severed.

The depressed housing industry may be in for something of a pickup next year--at a time some other industries are encountering their own lean times.

The Rev. Francis T. Brennan, a former superior of the community of the Congregation of the Blessed Sacrament here and for more than 50 years a priest at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church, 184 East 76th Street, died Thursday in the rectory.

Now that Craig Morton has pumped confidence, enthusiasm and points into the New York Giants' offense, Coach Bill Arnsparger is shifting his attention to solving the last soft spot on the club, pass defense.

53 black are running for seats in the House of Representatives tomorrow and three are running for senate seats. The total is .nine more than the number seeking congressional election two years ago.

Former President Richard M. Nixon's "gradual improvement" from post-operative complications reached the point today where his doctor allowed him to begin walking a few steps with nursing assistance around his bed in an intensive care unit at Memorial Hospital Medical Center here.

The nation's major coal-burning utilities reported yesterday, that their stockpiles of coal have improved in recent weeks and they indicated that a short coal strike-three weeks or less--could be sustained with few problems. Steel producers, on the other hand, said they would encounter almost immediate difficulties.

Joseph K. McGowan of Hillsdale, N.J., a former science teacher in the Tappan Zee, N.Y., school system, was sentenced to life imprisonment for the slaying last year of Joan D'Allesandro, a 7-year-old Brownie scout. Superior Court Judge Morris Malech handed down the sentence in Hackensack after rejecting a 45-minute argument by Mr. McGowan's attorney, Donald R. Conway, that his client should be punished for second-degree rather than firstdegree murder.

Most Greek and Greek Cypriote leaders agree that the only feasible solution to the Cyprus problem would be to divide the island into separate but federated regions, part administered by the ethnic Turks and the rest by the ethnic Greeks.

Scores of bribery and conspiracy indictments against city officials, businessmen and union representatives will be sought over the next few months as a result of a city investigation of corruption in the construction industry.

Anna Moffo, soprano with the Metropolitan Opera, and Robert W. Sarnoff, board chairman and chief executive officer of the RCA Corporation, will be married here next week.
Post time at Madison Square Garden today is 10 A.M. when 19 hunters will be led into a ring and judged for conformation to signal the start of the eight-day 91st National Horse Show.

A lawyer challenging a North Jersey high school's regulation demanding prior approval for student distribution of leaflets that might induce violence argued today that it would be better to close the school or call in the police in the event of violence rather than infringe on the students' constitutional right of free expression with such prior approval.

Secretary of State Kissinger, seeking to prevent a cutoff in American military aid to Turkey next month, announced today that he would wind up his current trip with two days of talks on the Cyprus crisis with Turkish officials in Ankara.

Delegates from more than 100 nations gathered here today for the opening tomorrow of the World Food Conference, under the sponsorship of the United Nations.

When Joanne's Fling captured the fourth race at Aqueduct yesterday, Frank (Pancho) Martin set a record for most winners in one year by a trainer in New York State.

William L. McKnight, a former board chairman of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, and a member of his family plan to sell 1.2 million shares of 3M common stock before the end of the year. Mr. McKnight said he would retain 3.7 million shares of 3M common stock.

To the Editor: President Ford's economy proposals may have been a master stroke intended to prepare Americans for the rigors of government controls rather than to cure inflation by themselves. The authority, aware of the Governor's intentions, withdrew the request for his approval for the increase, which would have gone into effect on Jan. 1.

An embattled school board decided today to return the controversial textbooks it had previously removed from local classrooms, but it also promised that those who object to their content would not be forced to read them.

With a healthy Joe Namath at quarterback, the saying went, the Jets could win any game. So much for the saying. Unlike three of the previous four years, the Jets have had a healthy Joe Namath all this season and all they have won is one game.

In a season that has had its troubles, two positive features for pro football have been the unexpected advancement in the standings of the New England Patriots and St. Louis Cardinals, both exciting, offensive-minded teams. In addition each features a little man, Mack Herron and Terry Metcalf, playing a key position-halfback-and playing it very well.

James B. Dancer, a dairy farmer and father of the harness-racing Dancer brothers, died yesterday at Freehold Area Hospital. He was 89 years old.

Let's hope that the folks watching "Willie Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" Thanksgiving night on the NBC-TV network aren't too excited to notice the first commercials for the Old Country, the third amusement, or theme, park to be built by Anheuser-Busch, Inc.
Thousands of chanting, flag-waving Cuban refugees from at least 35 organizations marched through this city in orderly fashion to protest a proposed detente with Fidel Castro's Government.
A hint to the housewife: If your husband tries to justify his hunting trips this year by citing the high cost of meat, smile indulgently and don't expect any reductions in your food budget.
The New Republic will start publishing in January a biweekly newsletter by Tristram Coffin called The Washington Spectator.
The Little League world series, which has been won the last four years by teams from Taiwan, will be limited in the future to teams from the continental United States.
YOUTHFUL BULLSEYE There can't be anything seriously wrong with show business, not with six young performers like Gail Johnston, Maureen Maloney, Nancy Reddon, Don Bradford,

As I had earlier seen William Congreve's "Love for Love" only twice in 31 years, it came as something of a shock to see the same play twice in the space of three days. Especially since both performances took place at the Helen Hayes Theater and were productions by the New Phoenix Repertory Company.

The New York State Insurance Department disclosed here yesterday that it was willing to grant insurance companies a certain amount of freedom to deal in stock options. This is now prohibited by state law.

Following are the pledges that President Ford's Citizen's Action Committee suggested today for local committees around the country to use to enlist business people, consumers and workers in the fight against inflation:

The United Parcel Service told its striking drivers and inside workers yesterday that it would cease operations in the metropolitan New York area on Nov. 20 if they failed to accept the company's "final contract offer." The strike is now in its 77th day.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it had fined Icahn Co., Inc., a member brokerage firm, $25,000, for violation of Federal securities laws and Carl C. Icahn, president, $10,000 for violation of rules of the exchange. Both the company and its president admitted the charges, the exchange said, to settle the proceeding.
A wave of automobile-radiator thefts is plaguing car owners and the police in the Forest Hills and Jew Gardens sections of Queens.

The White House formally agreed today to let Henry S. Ruth Jr., the special Watergate prosecutor, have access to all of former President Richard M. Nixon's records that relate to cases under investigation.

Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer announced today an engineering firm had been hired to examine five county-owned bridges into Paterson after structural flaws and gaping holes were found in the supports of two other bridges.

Ohrbach's has come a long way, baby. Back in the Depression and the war years, there was the exhilarating rough-and tumble of the Union Square store, when shoppers shoved their way past Ida, the pretzel vendor outside its door, and pounced on tables helterskelter with bargains.

Israel's representative at the United Nations, Yosef Tekoah, said today that the cards were stacked against his country in the forthcoming General Assembly debate on Palestine. "The Palestine Liberation Organization has the delegations of the 20 Arab states at its disposal,"

Channel 13 plans to televise Yasir Arafat's speech to the United Nations General Assembly, tomorrow morning, according to a spokesma for the station. He said the live coverage would begin at 10:30 A.M.
James Lewis Skerritt, a retired New York lawyer who had specialized in trust and estate cases, died Saturday here. He was 76 years old and ?? at 1125 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

The Academy of Political Science is preparing a statement at the request of theSenate'RulesCommittee and the House Judiciary Committee concerning the $89,952 gift from Vice President-designate Nelson A. Rockefeller to the academy and the academy's publication last May of a book lauding Mr. Rockefeller's governorship.

The Board of Public Utilities Commissioners has hired a consulting firm to look into the way fuel is purchased by the utilities and the impact such purchases have on what customers are paying for electricity.

Carpon copies of the "J. Hawker" letters involved in a $1 -million extortion plot against the Bonneville Power Administration have been found in the home of a young couple charged with sending one of them.

Three leading Fifth Avenue stores and two executives pleaded not guilty yesterday in the United States District Court to charges of conspiring to fix prices in women's clothing. Judge John M, Cannella said he would give the defendants 10 days to file motions.
Former Gov. William T. Cahill today defended his efforts to effect a greater involvement of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in mass transportation during his term in office.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said yesterday it had been advised over the weekend that the Jamaican Government was not planning a tender offer for shares of Kaiser or the Reynolds Metals Company. Later a Jamaican spokesman said the statement had been released in Jamaica on Friday.
Five Federal regulatory agencies have failed to carry out their responsibility to erase employment discrimination in the industries they regulate, the Commission on Civil Rights charged today.

Profits for most of the nation's coal producers soared during the third quarter this year as a result of the lifting of wage and price controls last spring and near-panic buying by utilities and exporters scrambling for coal in anticipation of. the, nationwide coal strike.
Increased bargain hunting enabled the stock market to register a moderate gain yesterday in quiet semiholiday trading. The market ignored the news announced late in the session by Arnold R. Miller,
The United Brands Company, whose operations include the United Fruit and John Morrell meat packers plunged deep into the red in the third quarter with a net loss of $47.2-million.

The United States Equestrian Team, with a perfect performance in Madison Square Garden last night, triumphed in the Nations Cup. Buddy Brown, aboard Sandsablaze, Thom Hardy, riding Coming Attraction, and Dennis Murphy, with Do Right, each covered a testing course of 16 jumps without a hobble to-give the United States the victory.

President Valery Giscard d'Estaing appears to be signaling that he is moving back to some Gaullist positions. On Saturday, in a symbolic gesture, he attended a ceremony at the grave of General de Gaulle in Colombey-les-Deux-Eglises marking the fourth anniversary of the general's death.

President Ford's CitizensAction Committee to Fight Inflation moved today to set up voluntary, grass-roots anti-inflation programs across the nation and warned that mandatory wage and price controls would "almost inevitably" follow if voluntary action failed.

Michael Goldenberg, an assistant branch librarian of the Brooklyn Public Library and former children's librarian, died yesterday of a heart attack in Trafalgar Hospital. He was 38 years old and lived at 40 Clinton Street, Brooklyn.

A three-judge Federal panel struck down as unconstitutional the state's requirement of a 75-day waiting period for those who voluntarily left their jobs to qualify for home relief or aid to families with dependent children. In the view of the court, the State Legislature erred when it set up regulations on the presumption that poor people left jobs for better benefits on welfare.
Cost overruns - on everything from warplanes, tanks and ships to civilian airports and Albany Malls--have become a painful governmental commonplace in the last decade.

The State Department of Transportation proposed today that the Byrne administration institute a maximum 25-cent bus fare for passengers as well as free rives for the elderly on all intracity bus service in New Jersey.
With less than one week remaining until the Greek national elections, the biggest issue appears to be whether voters have confidence in Premier Constantine Caramanlis.
The Boston Ballet closed its season here yesterday at the Music Hall with the world premiere of Ron Cunningham's "Tubby the Tuba" and the company premiere of "Gluck Melody,"

The likely duration of the national coal miners' strike was stretched from two weeks to at least three today by the failure of industry and union negotiators to approach a final settlement on a new contract.

The White House formally agreed today to let Henry S. Ruth Jr., the special Watergate prosecutor, have access to all of former President Richard M. Nixon's records that relate to cases under investigation.

The Securities and Exchange Commission suggested for comment today a series of revisions in its proposed net capital rule designed to measure the. liquidity and financial responsibility of brokerage firms.

Chapter XI petition for an arrangement by: C. J. I. iNDUSTRIES INC., 396 Fifth Ave., N.Y. Signed by Allan H. Rozner, president. Liabilities $2,115,024; assets $2,763,222. The concern is a converter, jobber, and supplier of textiles and other fabrics. Other corporations controlled or held by Petltlon er are Cyndy Joy Industries, Inc.; Jacob Yams, Inc. and Fllspun Yams, Inc. Bruce Jacob, is vice president.

Community School District 9 in the Bronx, whose management and financial practices have been sharply criticized in recent state and city audits, has 144 school neighborhood workers on its payroll, three and a halt times as many as any other district.
Bradley B. Hammond Jr,m a marketing consultant, died Saturday in a boating accident in Ossining, N.Y. He was 51 years old and lived on Lodge Road in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

SHERLOCK HOLMES, performed by The Royal Shakespeare Company, based on the Arthur Conan Doyle and William Gillette story, music by Michael Lankester, directed by Frank Dunlop, at the Broadhurst Theater, 6:15.
Today for the first time Germany participated in Armistice Day ceremonies at the tomb of France's Unknown Soldier, symbol of millions of victims of two World Wars with the old enemy.
Dr. Ralph Colp, a surgeon who was president of the medical- board of Mount Sinai Hospital from 1950 to 1954, died there yesterday. He was 81 years old and lived at 100 West 57th Street:

6-7 A.M., WNYC-FM: Sunrise Symphony. Ballet de la Merlaison, Louis XIII; Concertino No. 6 in B flat, Pergolesi; Variations on a Theme by Handel, Brahms. 9:06-10, WQXR: Piano Personalities. Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale. Concerto for Two Solo Pianos, Stravinsky.
The Carmel town dump rises in soggy and stinking majesty over Route 6 just south of here, resplendent in moldering rust and rot, a gathering point for rats and scavenger birds.
Birgit Nilsson and Placido Domingo have never sung "Turandot" together at the Metropolitan Opera, but they did so tonight at Symphony Hall here, with predictably exciting, results.

Howard B. Williams, a vice president and design director of The Sea Pine Company of Hilton Head Island, S.C., and a former interior designer here, died Friday of a heart attack at Hilton Head Island. He was 54 years old and lived in Hilton Head.

A spreading pall of idleness began falling over the already sick economy with the formal start last night of a national coal strike. The initial layoffs of workers in tributary industries were small, confined for the most part to train-crews on coal-carrying railroads, but the total will rise sharply if the tie-up goes beyond the two or three weeks that now seem its irreducible minimum.

Discrepancies have been uncovered involving a major piece of evidence used in the trial that resulted in the conviction of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, the former boxer, and a co-defendant in a triple murder.
The law of averages and the persistence of Francis Tarkenton caught up with the St. Louis Cardinals here tonight as the Minnesota Vikings beat them, 28-24.
To the Editor: Your Oct. 30 news story on the Government's plea for a 40 per cent improvement in gas mileage by 1980 is the latest act in a farce that has been running for the last five years.

India called today for a comprehensive ban on the testing of nuclear weapons in any environment and advocated an international agreement on the regulation of underground nuclear explosions for peaceful purposes.
Food scarcities and the anti-Government movement. led by Jayaprakash Narayan, the disciple of Gandhi, dominated the stormy opening session of the Indian Parliament today.

PARTICIPANTS: The United Mine Workers of America, the 84-year-old coal miners' union representing 120,000 men in underground and strip mines in 25 states, and the Bituminous Coal Operators Association, an industry bargaining group representing most major producers in the Eastern Appalachian and Midwestern coal fields.
Parts of the three White House tape recordings that led to Richard M. Nixon's resignation from the Presidency were played today to the jury in the Watergate coverup.

President Ford's Citizens Action Committee to Fight Inflation moved today to set up voluntary, grass-roots anti-inflation programs across the nation and warned that mandatory wage and price controls would "almost inevitably" follow if voluntary action failed.
Winning the World Series was worth $22,219 to each member of the Oakland A's who was voted a full share, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday.

For more than half a century, making water safe for drinking has consisted primarily of controlling a variety of disease producing bacteria that can cause epidemics if they contaminate public water supplies.
John W. Davis, the 86-yearold educator, diplomat and civil rights activist, was honored last night at a dinner in the grand ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel.
About 1,000 family members and supporters demonstrated near the White House today seeking to persuade the administration to demand an accounting of servicement not accounted for in Southeast Asia.

In the years before World War II, there was little doubt that the strongest cities in terms of bridge ability were New York and Philadelphia. In post-war years, Philadelphia declined, and the strongest challenges to New York came from Los Angeles and Dallas.
The Royal Shakespeare Company, practiced from five weeks in Washington, fresh from the last century on London's Baker Street, opens here tonight in "Sherlock Holmes."
Tonight at 8:30 on NBC TV, "Brief Encounter" is turned into a seemingly endless confrontation with tedium. The Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation arrives with intriguing credentials.

KALMAR, Sweden -- Two years ago a group of engineers and managers from Volvo spent three weeks of intensive work in, a garage carrying out an order of their company president to find an alternative to the assembly line.

The Supreme Court took the following actions today: ARMED SERVICES Affirmed a decision sustaining the Government's right to declare servicemen dead after they have been missing. in action if their next-of-kin are given notice and an opportunity for a hearing. (No. 73-1929, Wright v. Malloy).

The Defense Ministry said today that 12 Israeli Phantom jets had attacked targets in southern Lebanon, killing two Lebanese farmers and two Palestinians. A communique said jets had bombed and rocketed villages, roads and bridges in the Arkub area, where Palestinian guerrillas have camps.

The school-busing issue is moving to a critical impasse. Opposition to busing has been building up-built up deliberately might be a more accurate description- since former President Nixon discovered and exploited the issue's political potency.
No one can reasonably deny that shameful discrimination on grounds of religion, race, sex and national origin has occurred in the past. To a lesser extent it exists in the present.

In one of their most chaotic meetings on record, the foreign ministers of the nine European Common Market countries failed to make progress here today on any of the major points slated for discussion at a summit meeting of the countries' heads of government in Paris next month.
At least seven miners were killed today by tons of muddy slime that washed' down a shaft at the Impala platinum mine at Bafokeng, 100 miles northwest of here.
The chances of children getting pneumonia or bronchitis in the first year of life nearly double when both parents smoke, a group of medical scientists has warned.
A hint to the housewife: If your husband tries to justify his hunting trips this year by citing the high cost of meat, smile indulgently and don't expect any reductions in your food budget.

Leaders in the turkey industry yesterday gave President Ford two frozen turkeys for Thanksgiving and threw in a gift to the American consumer--a prediction that the price of turkeys this Thanksgiving will be down 20 to 25 per tent.

Improvement in former President Richard M. Nixon's condition means he can go home to San Clemente later this week if blood and lung tests detect no additional complications and he responds well to anticoagulation therapy, his doctors said here today.

The oil industry adopted a united- front yesterday on major tax issues, including con tinued support for the controversial depletion allowance. In recent weeks there have been indications of a possible split between the domestic independent oil producers and the larger companies over the question of the depletion allowance.
A White House spokesman said today that the controversial nomination of Andrew E. Gibson as Federal Energy Administrator was still "under review."
Robert Simpson, a former track star at the University of Missouri and coach of the first combined United States armed services team, died yesterday. He was 82 years Old.

The effort to lift a political and economic blockade imposed on Cuba a decade ago by the Organization of American States Verged on collapse to day. Latin-American foreign ministers advocating a rapprochement were two votes short of the two --thirds majority necessary the government of Premier Fidel Castro.

The 26th Army Band and the John Philip Sousa Post 1112 Band stepped out as proudly and played as stirringly yesterday as if hundreds of thousands of people had lined the Fifth Avenue parade route to welcome a victorious army home.

Dr. Francis Lee Weille, a Boston otolaryngologist and former assistant professor at Harvard Medical School, died Sunday at his home in Needham, Mass. He was 75 years old and had practiced in Boston from 1929 until last summer.
Underwriters will set tentative terms late today on a $600million financing by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in what ranks as the largest straight debt borrowing on record.
The 30 to 40 radical leftists in the BaaderMeinhof gang have succeeded, through a hunger strike in which one of them died Saturday, in dramatizing their twoand-a-half-year pretrial imprisonment.

Thanks to a twenty-mile belt of ozone beginning about ten miles above the earth, this planet is shielded from the direct ultra-violet rays of the sun. Without that screen, all animals, including the human species, would be subject at the least to an increased incidence of cancer and at worst to disruption of the plant-animal food chain which could "shatter the ecological structure that permits man to remain alive on this planet."

President Ford urged citizens today to remember on Thanksgiving Day that they still have "massive challenges" to meet and to pray for the strength they will need "to continue America's saga of progress"

Secretary of State Kissinger will fly to Peking for four days of consultations with Chinese leaders on Nov. 25, one day after the conclusion of President Ford's meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader.
Former Gov. William T. Cahill today defended his efforts to effect a greater involvement of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in mass transportation during his term in office'
Senator Walter F. Mondale cautioned a select Soviet audience today that Soviet- American trade would suffer if Moscow tried to take advantage of the current disarray in the West.
The Supreme Court removed today the last obstacle to continued prosecution of the Watergate cover-up case by refusing to hear a major legal objection raised by H. R. Haldeman, one of the defendants.
A Federal appeals court blocked a Texas judge today from mounting a special prosecution of the Government's prime witness against John B. onnally, one-time Presidential aspirant.

About 90,000 commuters tormea car pools, hitchhiked and sought other ways to get to and from work here today as a bus strike entered its third day. The strike by 1,500 members of the Amalagamated Transit Union idled 600 Metro Transit buses serving Seattle and surrounding King County.
Tonight in Tchaikowsky Hall, Viktor Korchnoi achieved what had eluded him throughout 20 games of his final candidates match for the world championship with Anatoly Karpov-a smashing attacking punch.

When a performer has finally reached the upper rungs of fame, what then? Some simply hold on tight and try to play it safe, repeating over and over the same few works that brought them attention. Eventually even their fan clubs lose interest in that.
For Papilion, Ltd. it has meant having to ship a single $140 dress in a parcel-post package instead of five to 10 at a time--because Postel service insurance only goes up to $200.

In none of the West European countries or Japan, over the last decade, has there been a drop in commitments to research and development comparable to that in the United States, according to an analysis by the man who formerly bore chief responsibility for such efforts in France.
The 139-year-old mace, symbol of authority in the House of Representatives, has been returned to the Capitol after being repaired at the Smithsonian Museum.

The South Carolina Electric and Gas Company disclosed yesterday that because it anticipated a drop in sales. it would trim its 10.year construction program by one-half -- from $2.7-billion originally ear- marked for spending through 1983 to $1.3-billion.

Frank Yablans, the 39year-old motion-picture executive who was superseded seven weeks ago as the active head of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, has resigned as president and chief operating officer.

In letters to Mayor Beame and the trustees of the New York Public Library, Greenwich Village civic and political leaders yesterday called upon the library to rescind its decision to close three branches later this week.
The international Business machines Corporation said yesterday it filed a motion in United states Court for the southern District of new York opposing the justice Department's

A New Hampshire marine biologist who apparently fell to his death in the Virgin Islands has been buried at sea near St. Thomas. The St. Thomas coroner said today that the biologist, David Drew, 23 years old, of Dover, N. H., had suffered a brain concussion.

The price of oil in the Persian Gulf is a complicated mixture of two kinds of oil and two kinds of prices. The two kinds of oil are equity.. oil, that owned by the , producing companies, such as the Exxon Corporation and Texaco, Inc., and participation oil, which is owned by the producer countries, such as Saudi Arabia or Iran.
Senator Henry M. Jackson proposed tonight that oil-consuming nations establish a Special Council of Economic and Financial Ministers to take dramatic steps to meet the energy crisis.

Britain's Joe Bugner, the European heavyweight champion, needs an impressive victory over Jimmy Ellis of Louisville toning in their fight at Wembley Pool, London, to rate a shot at the world title held by Muhammad Ali.
The special sound and ensemble personality of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra would be welcomed in many: kinds of music, of course.

The United States Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that it had asked 250 of the nation's largest aerosol spray makers to tell how consumers are bing invited to request refunds for products containing the cancer-causing chemical vinyl chloride.

Vietnam-era veterans receiving education benefits to attend schools in the East or Midwest may be getting shortchanged under the G.I. Bill, according to a report prepared for the National Conference of Mayors.

The United States now is using its surplus food more nearly for international political purposes than for humanitarian assistance. That is basically why there is less than meets the eye to the news from the World Food Conference at Rome that American food assistance to hungry nations may be doubled.
Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that the National Science Foundation spends "tens of millions of dollars without coordinating their work with other Federal agencies."
The Jets will practice this week not in Hempstead but in Euphoria. Undoubtedly they will remain all week on the "high" induced by their stunning conquest of the Giants.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the counter market closed mixed yesterday as volume rose slightly on the Amex and fell somewhat in the counter market.
Mayor Beame formally proposed yesterday that the New York State Sports Authority consider building a 15,000-seat indoor arena in Brooklyn.
The British pound toppled to a 10-month low against other major currencies today in anticipation of new budgetary measures that the Government is scheduled to announce tomorrow.
A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday handed up an indictment against a debt collector who had allegedly threatened the life of a man who was $5,060 in debt from a gambling junket.

CPC International, Inc., announced yesterday that its industrial division, effective today, would increase its sugar price by $11 per 100 pounds to $63.95 for bulk granulated sugar and industrial liquid sugar and $64.25 for extra fine granulated sugar.

Discrepancies hive been uncovered involving a major piece of 'evidence used in the trial that resulted in the conviction of Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, the former boxer, and, a co-defendant in a triple murder.

Dvorak's Requiem (Op. 89) is hardly a war horse, yet for no obvious reason it seems to be turning up relatively frequently these days. Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall it turned up again, in the secure hands of 'Antal Dorati' and his National Symphony Orchestra.
President Ford and his family will vacation at the spacious mountain home, of Dick Bass, president of a Dallas oil company, when they spend the Christmas holidays at Vail, Colo.
Old people at the supermarket make you feel what's the use. Staring at 90-cent peanut butter. Taking down an orange, looking for its price, putting it back.
The Cleveland cavaliers lave hit the jackpot with Bingo Smith. A loser during his five-season pro career, smith has become a hotshooting property,

"No player is an individual," growled Fred Shero four years ago. "Hockey is a team game and the players must conform." He was talking as-the new coach of a groveling team called the Philadelphia Flyers, another joke in the City of Brotherly Love's sports stories. Mustaches, long hair-never, shouted Shero, his close-cropped hail virtually bristling. In addition to hair being nonconformist, Shero had another reason:

Britain's Joe Bugner, the European heavyweight champion, needs an impressive victory over Jimmy Ellis of Louisville tonight in their fight at Wembley Pool, London, to rate a shot at the world title held by Muhammad Ali. But Ellis has similar--and conflicting--aims.
For the first time since the sharp rise in oil prices began two years-ago, three producer countries have broken the united front of the oil exporters' ?? cartel on the so-called posted price system.
They come from states like Pennsylvania, Iowa and Illinois, from cities like New York, Los Angeles, Ottawa, London, Copenhagen, Budapest and Cairo.

Two businessmen whose evidence helped lead to the resignation of former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew pleaded guilty today to obstructing tax laws by delivering cash kickbacks to Mr. Agnew while he was Governor of Maryland.

Bobby Dotter did the right thing in switching dates for Mrs. Nelson Asiel's Crafty Khale. The trainer had the 5year-old son of Crafty Admiral entered for the Jockey Club Gold Cup last Saturday, but thought better of it.

The state's investigation of alleged political corruption and mob influence in New Jersey's garbage industry has begun to focus on charges against Anthony J. Grossi, president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

Two studies released here yesterday show that private foster-care agencies handling black children receive and spend 42 per cent less public money than agencies handling Jewish children and 19 per cent less than agencies handling Roman Catholic Children.

Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, has alleged in documents lodged with a Milan Court that losses on certain large foreign-exchange operations undertaken by Banca Unione, S.p.A., and Banca Privata Fianziaria, S.p.A., should be attributed to the International Westminster Bank, Ltd.

When Secretary of State Henry Kissinger spoke at Rome in moving and somber tones about the world's food plight, his speech was long on proposals for organizing international efforts to combat the crisis over the next several years but short on specifics about what the United States intends to do to help feed the world's hungry over the next few months.
Half of the additional food supplies needed to stave off widespread famine will have to be found in the United States, an official of the World Food Conference secretariat said today.
Herbert von Karajan, still icily handsome at 66 years of age, has long been one of the world's most honored condoctors. Yet his reputation in America lags behind his reputation in Europe.
George G. Benedict, dean of students at Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass., from 1943 to 1967, died Sunday in Providence, R.I., where he lived. He was 73 years old.
Players on at least four World Football League teams haven't been paid lately. One team is begging for food, and another is missing a set of uniforms.
The Little League world series, which has, been Won the last four years by teams from Taiwan, will be limited in the future to teams from the continental United States.

A national coal miners' strike began at one minute past midnight today and its likely duration was stretched from two weeks to at least three by the failure of industry and union negotiators to approach a final settlement on a new contract.

The effor to lift a political and economic blockade imposed on Cuba a decade ago by the Organization of American States verged on collapse today. Latin-American foreign ministers advocating a rapporachement were two votes short of the two-thirds majority necessary to life the sanctions agains the government of Fremier Fidel Castro.

Thousands of chanting, flagwaving Cuban refugees from at least 35 organizations marched through this city in orderly fashion today to protest proposed detente with Fidel Castro's Communist Government.

Thomas P. F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art; Richard D. Aurelio, former Deputy. Mayor, and J. James Akston, director of the Art Museum in Palm Beach, Fla., have joined the board of The Lambs, the century-old theatrical club, which is being reorganized under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
Electricity and gas cuts, reductions in hospital and socialsecurity services and yet another radio and television stoppage loom this week as strike action across France intensifies.
Toward the end of 1973, it appeared that the nation's trucking industry was headed for deep trouble as a result of the fuel crisis.

Premier Kakuei Tanaka tried to shore up his eroding political position today by promising a report to the nation on his finances, by appointing new officials of the governing party and by naming a largely new Cabinet.

A West German monetary expert is looking toward increased .exports to oil-producing countries as the best way for the industrialized world to solve balance-ofpayments problems caused by higher oil prices.
The Rev. Hunter Guthrie, a member of the Jesuit order who was president of Georgetown University in Washington from 1949 to 1952, died today at the Novitiate of St. Isaac Jogues. He was 73 years old.

Steel production for the week ended Nov. 9 fell by 1.2 per cent to 2,780,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was the third consecutive weekly decline and compared with the 2,814,000 tons poured in the week ended Nov. 2.
The Commerce Departmeni reported today that retail sales declined in October for the second straight month, giving further evidence to a weakening of the nation's economy.

RANGOON, Burma--They may have pedaled bicycle rickshas for a living, planted rice or served as clerks in Government offices. Whatever they did, so long as they were never lawyers, they are qualified to serve as "people's judges" in a revamped judicial system that is charged with dispensing "socialist justice" in Burma.
An old railroad lantern glowing underwater in a silt pond near an abandoned coal breaker kept this rural eastern Pennsylvania community talking of unidentified flying objects over the weekend.
The results of elections in six states remain in doubt pending recounts. The Veterans Day holiday observed in many states yesterday delayed some checks.

The Giants may have lost more than defensive pride and perspective in last Sunday's 26-20 sudden-death defeat to the Jets at Yale Bowl. A sprained back will sideline Doug Kotar, the rookie running back, for perhaps two games, Coach Bill Arnsparger said yesterday.

The United Nations headquarters was like a citadel awaiting a siege yesterday as the first contingent of the Palestine Liberation Organization arrived in the city for the General Assembly debate on Palestine, Which begins tomorrow.

The United Parcel Service told its striking drivers and inside workers yesterday that it would cease operations in the metropolitan New York area on Nov. 20 if they failed to accept the company's "final contract offer."
Margaret Holland, emeritus professor of physical education at Barnard College, died Saturday in Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 76 years old and lived at 56 Seventh Avenue.

Jane Ace, whose malapropisms in radio shows with her husband, Goodman Ace, delighted national audiences in the nineteen-thirties and forties, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived at the Ritz Tower Hotel.
KENSINGTON, Md. - To the motorist passing on Interstate 495, the fantasy form of the new Mormon Temple here appears to rise out of the woods like a mirage.
For Papillion Ltd., it has meant having to ship a single $140 dress in a parcel-post package instead of five to 10 at a time--because Postal service insurance only goes up to $200.

About 10,000 people jammed East 62d Street yesterday as members of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America across the nation protested the importing of cheaply produced foreign-made apparel. The importts, the union says, have resulted in loss of about 11,000 American jobs in the last four years.
After early-morning strength, soybeans and the grains moved sharply downward yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, one of the few major commodity exchanges open on the Veterans Day holiday.

A Federal judge yesterday rejected a prisoner's contention that his constitutional rights were being violated because he was not allowed conjugal visits while in jail and because he needed such visits as a "medical treatment" for alleged homosexual tendencies.

Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, told a Veterans Day observance today that an increase in educational benefits was an important step toward repaying the nation's debt to Vietnam, veterans.

The Venezuelan Treasury and, the Mines and Hydrocarbons Ministry are studying the possibility of lifting taxes paid by foreign oil companies operating in the country, the newspaper El Nacional reported today.

For the second consecutive week, the Rahway High football team averted defeat with seconds remaining. And, once again, the "coach" was a dramatic hero. GREENPORT, L.I. -- The scallop-harvesting season is under way on the eastern end of Long Island, and Ed Kruszeski, who is one of about 120 baymen in Suffolk County who make their living by shellfishing, says the hauls of bay scallops so far are very good.

The Soviet Union said today that it had surpassed the United States as the world's leading oil producer but that it still sought American technology to resolve continuing inefficiency in oil extraction.

Five of the twelve jurors who served in the trial of Dennis J. Banks and Russell C. Means, the American Indian leaders of the 1973 armed takeover of Wounded Knee, S.D., appealed to the Justice Department today to drop charges in the remaining Wounded Knee cases.

A payroll-processing company that has received more than $2-million from the Board of Education over the last four years has been accused by the State Commission of Investigation of illegally giving money, gifts and the services of call girls to employes of the board.

Jim Egli of Slippery Rock was named today the 1973 soccer coach of the year by the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics. Egli, who led his team to an 11-4-1 won-lost-tied record last year, will be honored at the N.A.I.A. soccer dinner at Florissant, Mo., Nov. 26.

A 20-yar-old man pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to having raped a woman in her apartment after he trailed firemen who were fighting a blaze nearby.

Joe Bugner, European heavyweight champion, pounded out a 10-round decision over Jimmy Ellis at Wembley's Empire Pool tonight, but did little to enhance, his claim to a shot at Muhammad Ali's world title.

Norton Simon, Inc., announced yesterday that it was raising its quarterly dividend to 10 cents a common share from 7 1/2 cents, payable Feb. 28 to shareholders of record Feb. 7.

Their strength is estimated at 10,000.

DACCA, Bangladesh, Nov 12--The fear of widespread famine that haunted Bangladesh a few weeks ago has become reality. Officials here concede that they were not prepared for the widespread devastation that has occurred despite a substantial flow of foreign food and economic aid.

The Government of Prime Minister Dom Mintoff published a bill tonight proposing withdrawal from the British Commonwealth and making Malta a republic. Mr. Mintoff had previously announced plans to sever allegiance to the Queen, but today's bill provided the frist detailed outline.
