Vittorio De Sica, the director of such film classics as "Schoeshine" and "The Bicycle Thief," died here today at the age of 73.
The New York City Ballet returned to the State Theater Tuesday night for its fallwinter season with the invigorating freshness of a cold shower.
The Federal Reserve Board announced today a broad restructuring of its reserve requirements, which will eventually release about $750-million into the banking system.

Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton, President Ford's energy chief, expressed strong interest today in a big increase in the Federal gasoline tax to help discourage consumption, reduce oil imports and drive down world oil prices.

An Elmwood Park man was held in Bergen County Jail pending a hearing on charges of murder after a 15-year-old boy he is accused of having assaulted on Halloween night died in a hospital. The police said the suspect, Leo Smith, 44, was being held in connection with the death of Paul Litter, who died at Barnert Memorial Hospital in nearby Paterson, where he had. been in coma following the assault on Oct. 31.

The American Stock Exchange, which reported a seat sale a month ago as low as $38,500, said yesterday that it had sold a seat at $60,000--only $35,000 less than the last seat sale on the New York Stock Exchange.
Having experienced atleast three familiar and uncomfortable sensations, the New York Knicks finally took off. .for home today, where they will play their next three games- and 10 of their next 15.

The book of the month the fruit of the month, etc., may be old hat now, but the flower of the week idea is as freshg as the mass of seasonal blossoms subscribers to Petal Pushers receive each Monday morning.

The Delta Rho Chapter of the Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity at Monmouth College here was suspended today by the national fraternity in the wake ofuhazing incident that resulted in the death of a fraternity pledge and the arrest of seven fraternty members on manslaughter charges.

" We feel proud," said the man who asked to be called only by his first name, Abdullah, after watching Yasir Arafat speak to the United Nations yesterday on the television set in the back of his Brooklyn grocery.

Gen. George S. Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, expressed regret today for comments that he made a month ago in which he suggested that Israel had undue political influence in Congress and that Jews controlled the newspapers and banks' in this country.
Israeli protests continued today against the price rises decreed by the Government through its devaluation of the Israeli pound and its reduction of subsidies for staples.

The head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, told the United Nations General Assembly today that his organzation's goal remained a Palestinian state that would include Moslems, Christians and Jews.

The Delta Rho Chapter of the Zeta Beta Tau Fraternity at Monmouth College here was suspended today by the national fraternity in the wake of a hazing incident that resulted in the death of a fraternity pledge and the arrest of seven fraternity members on manslaughter charges.
Pointing out that soaring sugar prices can provide earnings of as much as $54 a share this year, the Great Western United Corporation said yesterday in a letter to shareholders that the offer
Lielf Rosanoff, a cellist and teacher of the cello, died Tuesday night at a nursing home in Austin, Tex. He was 96 years old and until four years ago made his home here.

A police officer in Greenwich Village suffered thirddegree burns of the face yesterday morning when he slid behind the driver's wheel of a police van and dislodged a pint of sulphuric acid from atop the sun visor, causing the acid to spill across the upper part of hib body.
E. I. du Pont de Nemoures Co. says it has been issued a one-year permit to continue dumping liquid acid waste in the Atlantic Ocean off the Delaware coast.
The executive committee of radio station WRVR-FM has issued a statement denying reports that it was "engaged in negotiations with any prospective purchaser, including WNET." The Riverside Church
President Juan. Velasco Alvarado said tonight that his Government had quietly expelled- several agents of the Central Intelligence Agency from Peru, including a senior United States Embassy official.

William Flowers, the 19-year-old Monmouth College freshman who suffocated in a "grave" he had to dig on a rainswept beach as part of his initiation into a fraternity, is at least the fourth student within the past year to die as a result of such senseless rites on American campuses.

Controller-Harrison J. Goldin reported yesterday that as of July 30 the city had $165-million outstanding in uncollected violation summonses and that the uncollected backlog was growing at a rate of $3-million to $4-million a month.
The graphically oriented members of the stock market community are watching the market with great interest these days.
The mood of France, particularly Paris, could be compared these days to the great liner named after this country, whose passengers ate and drank her out of existence.

Research undertaken by women members of the Screen Actors-Guild Indicates that females have a decided minority role in television commercials. The Women's Conference Committee unveiled at the Lambs Club yesterday its findings -culled from a random sampling of about half of the 656 commercials entered for the 1973 Clio advertising awards competition.
An angry Al Arbour refused to go into the New York Islanders' dressing room to-. night after they were routed, 8-2, by the Pittsburgh Penguins. "They are old enough

Norway is favored to win an upset victory in the European championships here. The Scandinavian stars trail France, the defending champions, by one victory point going into the final two matches, but have an easier schedule.

The food middleman's margins, widening at a record rate, will expand another 1.4 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1974 and continue to advance at a slower pace in 1975, the Agriculture Department predicted today.

James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said in an interview yesterday that he was "seriously considering" a compromise proposal to the Securities and Exchange Commission to get the Government agency to postpone the imposition of price competition on Wall Street.

Five of the perjury counts in an indictment pending against Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo were dismissed by the Appeliate Division yesterday, a rulling that leaves only one perjury count standing against him for possible retrial.

The State Commission of Investigation is looking into possible corruption in the awarding by the Board of Education and local school districts- of $25-million in contracts -for program evaluations and other services.

J. Grossi, president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, admitted under questioning here today that he met with a man now under state indictment the night before that man allegedly perjured himself before a state grand jury investigating political corruption.

Favorites swept all nine races at Aqueduct yesterday, and even the oldest racetrackers on the premises could not remember when that had ever happened here. With the last race of Tuesday's card added to the list, the favorite string reached 10.
Bobby Clarke, the superpesky captain of the Philadelphia Flyers, blocked a Ranger shot last night and turned it into a breakaway goal with 15 seconds left to beat New York, 3-2.

King Hussein of Jordan decreed an amnesty today for about 100 political prisoners, most of whom are Palestinian guerrillas, in an gesture of apparent support for Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader who addressed the United Nations General Assembly.

two people were killed and fire injured this morning when Israeli artillery shelled Nabatiye, southeast of here In southern Lebanon. Local residents said Nebatiye had been shelled and rocketed for 40 minutes.

The Common Market is expected to have a 1974 trade deficit with the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countires of $25-billion to $30-billion, the European Economic Community Commission said today.

One of the sidelights to the George Foreman-Muhammad Ali main event that couldn't be reported from Zaire at the time was Bula Mandungu's losing fight with a stubborn fact: Foreman's cut over his right eye.

Rita D. Howes, a copy editor at Consumer Reports magazine since 1967, was found dead Tuesday at her apartment at 2 Washington Square Village. She was 48 years old. The New York City medical examiner's office listed the cause of death as an apparent overdose of ??arbiturates.
The American Motors Corporation reported today a loss of $7-million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, and said that the loss reduced the company's earnings for its fiscal year by 38.2 per cent.

ABC-TV announced yesterday the cancellation of three more prime-time programs, "The Sonny Comedy Revue, "Nakia" and Paper Moon," in its second revision of the prime-time schedule that will be effective after the first of the year.
Alfred Hayes, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said yesterday the private banking system may need assistance in trying to cope with the heavy flow of oil money.

Six members of an Amityville family were found slain here tonight. The police said the only surviving member of the family, a 23-year-old man, reported that he returned to the home and discovered the bodies of his parents, two brothers and two sisters.

David L. Part of Noth Little Rock says that his employers at Associated Milk Produers, Inc., including the board of directors, authorized him to make the illegal campaign contributions that theassociation is trying to recover from him.

The jury at the Watergate cover-up trial heard lengthy testimony today that linked former Attorney General John N. Mitchell with secret payments of thousands of dollars to the seven Watergate burglary defendants.
Today skies will be mostly clear across northern New England, and mostly cloudy throughout the remainder of the Northeast.
The Fedeal Government yesterday dropped its effort the courts to force New York City to abandon its stringent quota system for minority hiring in the construction industry.

Christmas has come early to this Bergen County residential town of 13,000 residents. The 10-block shopping street, Broad Avenue, was lighted tonight with strings of bulbs, Christmas-tree lights and electric candles.
The board of trustees of the New York Public Library agreed last night to keep open the three branches that it had threatened to close next Monday because of budget cuts.

The boyish grin is still there, and some boy still temains in Jim Chones, the man. Missing are the pressures on a a young man forced to grow up too swiftly because he had been sized up as a valuable commodity. The Chones who left Marquette in 1972 during his junior year to sign a five-year, $1.5-million contract with the New York Nets of the American Basketball Association has disappeared.

Dr. Leroy Buttolph, a retired research engineer with the General Electric Company whose major work was in the early development of quartz mercury light sources, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home in Snyder, N. Y., a suburb of Buffalo. He was 83 years old.
Harry Kalcheim, who retied in 1971 after 29 years as an executive agent with the Willam Morris Agency, died Tuesday at a nursing home here He-was 73 years old.
Nelson A. Rockefeller confronted directly today the underlying issue that has stalled and perhaps imperiled his confirmation as the next Vice President of the United States
The stock market finished lower yesterday although it managed to reduce some of its earlier losses on expectations that the nationwide coal strike could and shortly.
A well-to-do car dealer, his wife and four of his five children were found murdered in their beds tonight here on Long Island's south Shore.

Royal Willis Leith, a founding partner in the investment banking firm of Burgess Leith in Boston, died there yesterday at the New England Baptist Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Dedham, Mass., and Fortunes Rocks, Me.

Scientists at Purdue University have produced a high-protein variety of sorghum, the world's fourth largest cereal grain crop, that they say "has great promise" of improving the diet in some poor countries.

The inexorable demise of unbeaten football teams will continue at an accelerated pace this week, mainly because four of the remaining undefeated in New Jersey schoolboy competition will be meeting one another. West Essex (7-0) at Morristown (7-0) and Randolph (7-0) at Morris Knolls (7-0) are two games that will have a major effect on the final state ratings.
Efforts to recover at least part of' the $4.3-million taken in the largest cash theft in American history have been hampered by a judge in the British West Indies.

Kuwait's attitude toward its sterling reserves will not be altered by the British Government's decision to end its sterling guarantee arrangements at the end of the year, authoritative official sources said today.
Portugal expects to establish diplomatic relations with Peking "in the near future," a Portuguese diplomat said today.
Two groups of Japanese youths hurled Molotov cocktails at the United States and Soviet Embassies, compounds today and were arrested on the spot, the police said.
Swissair accused Washington today of turning its back on the principle of free competition by attempting to exert pressure on European airlines to reduce the number of their North Atlantic flights.

Gen. George S. Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, expressed regret today for comments that he made a month ago in which he suggested- that Israel had undue political influence. in Congress and that 'Jews' controlled the newspapers: and banks in this country.

One of the sidelights to the George Foreman-Muhammad Ali main event that couldn't be reported from Zaire at the time was Bula Mandungu's losing fight with a stubborn fact: Foreman's cut over his right eye. .

Rene Robert achieved the second three-goal game of his career tonight and added an assist as the Buffalo Sabres downed the Montreal Canadiens, 8-6, to stretch their National Hockey League undefeated streak to nine games.

courting a school -bus loaded with children was struck by sniper fire today in the Kanawha County textbook dispute. Another state police car was fired upon, but not hit, in the shooting incident, the county's fourth in three days.

Violence in Northern Ireland intensified today with five killings in 24 hours. British Army sources said they believed that the violence stemmed from a campaign by recently released leaders of the Irish Republican Army to force the British Government to end the policy of internment without trial.
Aformal last-ditch effort to block the 4 per cent domestic air-fare increase due to go into effect tomorrow has ben initiated by a group of 25 Congresmen led by Representative John EnMoss.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, one of the world's largest conglomrates, reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter of 1974 declined 12.9 per cent to $1116-million from year earlier levels.

An olive-green Army helicopter flew Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, from Kennedy International Airport to the United Nations headquarters after his predawn arrival yesterday in an exceptional security effort.

More than six and one-half years after the massacre of civilians at My Lai 4 in South Vietnam, the Army formally released today a report telling how that crime was covered up throughout the military command structure.

A 21-year-old messenger who admitted raping and robbing three women at knife-point in midtown office buildings last, winter was sentenced to up to 15 years in prison yesterday. "These are most serious acts which require substantial punishment." Acting Supreme Court Justice Irving Land said.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market fell again yesterday as bullish news continued to be scarce.
Gov. William A. Egan issued a directive to his Lieutenant Governor today ordering the state election office to hand-count 60,000 computerized ballots cast in last Tuesday's state-wide election.

Gen. Paul Stehlin, the former French Air Force chief of staff who raised a political storm with a report that United States warplanes were superior to French jets, was retired from active reserve today.

The State Commission of Investigation is looking into possible corruption in the awarding by the Board of Education and local school districts of $25-million In contracts for program evaluation and: other services.

Turkey has withdrawn about 5,000 of her 40,000 troops on Cyprus, Western diplomats said today. The diplomats said they were uncertain whether the withdrawals were specifically designed to forestall the cut-off of American aid to Turkey.
Philip I. eisenmenger, retired vice president of the Standard Brands Sales Company, died Tuesday apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived at Manhattan House, 200 East 66th Street.

Consumers' complaints about; warranties are on the rise at the regional office of the Federal Trade Commission at 26 Federal Plaza-an increase that is attributed to growing cost consciousness on the part of buyers.

During the first nine months of this year the retail cost of an year's supply of farm-produced food went up $197 from its 1973 average, with higher middleman charges accounting for 84 per cent of the incrase, new figures by the Agriculture Department showed today.

Paine Webber, Inc., holding company for the brokerage firm of Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, Inc., reported here yesterday that it lost $885,000 in the fiscal quarter ended Sept. 27 even after an extraordinary gain of $143,000.

Ponuguese negotiators, working on plans for granting independence to this African colony, have put aside for the present a proposal for an interim coalition Government that would include guerrilla movements.
At a public conference today with the Food and Drug Administration, Abbott Laboratories defended the artificial sweetner cyclamate as being safe for reinstatement as a food additive.
Dr. Thomas F. O'Dea, a former professor at Columbia and Fordham universities in New York, died last night at his home here of complications connected with Hopkins disease. He was 58 years old.

She grew up poor in a Pennsylvania mining town, escaping on a scholarship that, along with cocktail waitressing, took her through Boston University.

President Ford strongly urged the Governors of the nation's coastal states today to. back offshore drilling as the solution to "one of the most serious problems we face"--the lack of domestic petroleum supplies.

Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has cautioned Cabinet ministers against accepting free rides on company-owned jets. He reminded them that their travels should be paid, for by the Canadian Government.

The mind often has difficulty comprehending tragedy in the mass. One death means more to us than numbers. That may help to explain the slowness of reaction to the world food crisis, with its terrible statistics: 400 million people hungry now, thousands and millions likely to starve to death unless helped.

District Attorney Nicholas Ferraro of Queens announced yesterday the re-indictment of the Lee Myles Corporation, a transmission - repair company; its president, Charles George, and three other persons, charging criminal possession of stolen property.

The administrator of the Marcus Curry Building at Greystone Psychiatric Hospital, which was rocked recently by allegations of sexual and physical abuse of patients, was relieved of his duties today by Ann Klein, Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies.
The nation's energy problems have been studied and talked to death, but very little has been done to alleviate them, according to a number of top oil industry executives.

The British trade deficit climbed above the $1-billion mark again in October and approached a rocrd level, the Government reported today, as the financial markets reached nervously to the new economic measures announced in yesterday's budget.

With the industry's slump in newcar sales in early November even worse than expected, the General Motors Corporation announced today that it was closing thres small-car assembly plants next Monday for a week.

The Administration expects to give its "response" by the first of the year to a r request of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad for a $100-million Federally guaranteed loan for rehabilitation of its 7,500-mile roadway, Edward G. Jordan, president of the United States Railway Association, said today.
Irwin Silberg, a founding partner of Sweet Co. Advertising, 845 Third Avenue, died Tuesday. He was 45 years old and lived in Livingston, N. J.
The State Education Department is ordering the termination of some doctoral programs at four universities on the ground that the programs are of "inadequate quality."

By extracting a contract from the coal industry that union officials are conservatively calling "hefty," Arnold Ray Miller, the president of the United Mine Workers of America, has surprised his closest associates, who thought him weak, and stepped out of the shadow of Joseph A. Yablonski, the slain union insurgent whose standard he picked up.

Over protests by Israel, the General Assembly voted 75 to 23 to limit each nation to one major speech in the current debate on Palestine. The decision was denounced by Yosef Tekoah, the Israeli delegate, who said it was clearly a move to "muzzle Israel's freedom to speak." It was believed to be the first time that such a restriction had been approved in the history of the United Nations. [Page 1, Column 5.]
Over protests by Israel, the General Assembly voted today to limit each nation to one major speech in the current debate on the issue of Palestine. The vote was 75 to 23 with 18 abstentions.

MarilynVonderschmitt Rogers, wife of Richard C. Rogers, general services manager of The New York Times, died yesterday at United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y., after a brief illness. She was 51 years old and lived at 313 South Barry Avenue, Mamaroneck, N.Y.

The suspension of South Africa from the current United Nations GeneraL Assembly is illegal and dangerous. It is a disastrous precedent for an organization that cannot be effective unless its membership is universal. It is a grim irony that virtually the same Assembly majority that suspended a founding member of the U.N. one day could on the next enthusiastically welcome the leader of a terrorist organization whose goal is destruction of another member state.

The New Jersey Conference college fottball title will be decided at Giassboro tomorrow night when MOntclair State meets Glassbore State, but another important contest will be a nonconference game at Seton Hall on Saturday between Kean Colege and Set on Hall.

The jury deliberated six hours today without reaching a verdict in the case of Dr. William R. King, charged with trying to arrange a triple murder while he was chief psychiatrist at Trenton State Prison last year.
Chief among the civic notabilia is the Mayor's foray or razzia among the unhappy fallen women who perambulate Broadway, the noctivagous strumpetocracy. Its legality is much debated.

Edith Ehrman, manager of the foreign-areas materials center of the New York State Department of Education and a well-known collector of Japanese prints, died Wednesday in New York University Hospital. She was 42 years old and lived at 139 East 35th Street.

The panel of three physicians appointed by Judge John J. Sirica is waiting to hear from the court whether former President Richard M. Nixon will agree to the examination the judge has ordered to determine if Mr. Nixon is physically able to give testimony in the Watergate cover-up trial.

Britain's price Commission announced Yesterday it was rejecting 30 applications for price increases from oil companies. This was one of a number of developments in various countries affecting oil prices.

Ferguson Jenkins, who helped the Texas Rangers become a pennant contender last season by winning 25 games, was named yesterday major league baseball's comeback player of the year by United Press International.

Genesco, Inc., the major manufacturer and retailer of apparel and footwear, reported yesterday declines of 36.4 per cent in earnings and 3.4 per cent in sales for the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31, reflectig the slowdown in consumer spending.

A group of Manhattan videotape enthusiasts, who gained entry into Cuba last spring, have sold to WNET/13 and the Public Broadcasting Service a cinema verite documentary on the people of Cuba and their living standards that the three commercial television networks had rejected.
Like many Africans here, Monya Tshuapa dates most happenings from "the events," but she does not talk much about the events themselves.
The former teamsters union president, James R. Hoffa, said today that he would accept a nomination for the presidency of Detroit Local 299 if he was nominated at a meeting of the local.

The Consumers Power Company informed the Michigan Public Service Commission yesterday that it would be forced to cut back its 1975 construction program. The big utility said the latest move would cut "about $147-million-about 36 per cent" from the $413-million construction budget.

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday a 25 cent quarterly dividend, payable Jan. 15 to stockholders of record Dec. 10. The company last paid a dividend in 1972 at a rate of 12 1/2 cents a share.
The Siberian meeting between President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev on Nov. 23-24 will take place in the newly built guesthouse of a sanatorium north of Vladivostok.

The Court of Appeals yesterday denied workmen's-compensation death benefits to the widow of an editorial writer for a Yiddish-language newspaper who died shortly after defending, in an argument, his paper's policy of supporting Israel during the Six Day War of 1967.

Egypt stated unequivocally today for the first time that unless Israel agreed to another major military withdrawal on the Sinai front, the Suez Canal would remain closed to international shipping after clearing operations are completed next spring.

"They charged Butch." These were the words of a 16-year-old girl three doors from the brightly lighted DeFeo home shortly after 9:30 tonight when word was received that 23-year-old Ronald DeFeo Jr. had been charged in the slaying of six members of his family.

Leaders of New Jersey's construction trade unions, alarmed by what they have described as "our highest unemployment rate since the Depression," said today that they were considering using their multi-million-dollar pension funds for low-interest loans to contractors to stimulate building in the state.

The United Nations Educational, Ecientific and Cultural Organization will swear in Amadou Mahtar M'Bow as "its first black director general today. Mr. M'Bow, a 'Senegalese, was elected to the post yesterday by the UNESCO general conference, by a vote of 123 to 1.

President Ford personally rebuked Gen. George S. Brown, today for his critical comments about American Jews but said tonight that he had no intention of replacing him as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

The Suffolk County police announced tonight that they had arrested 23-year-old Ronald DeFeo and charged him with murdering his parents and four brothers and sisters Tuesday night at the family home in Amityville.

A plentiful supply of gasoline in and around New York City at. the higher prices of the energy crisis era has led to a return of price-cutting competition among many retrailers and is encouraging bargain-hunting among inflation-conscious motorists.

The jury at the Watergate cover-up trial was told today that Nixon campaign officials gave hundreds of thousands of dollars to the Watergate burglars to meet "commitments" to the burglars without ever knowing who had made the commitments.
The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today a plan designed to save at least $89-million a year in prescription drug costs to Federal, state and local governments.
The Beame administration has decided to seek Federal funds for the reconstruction of the West Side Highway between the Battery and 42d Street as an Interstate route.

Dr. Jerome Pierce Webster, an internationally known plastic surgeon and professor emeritus of clinical surgery at the Columbia University. College of Physicians and Surgeons, died yesterday at Harkness Pavillion; Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, after a brief illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.
Airlines flying the North Atlantic today recessed until next Wednesday their deadlocked talks on how to capture a larger share of the low-budget travel market from the charter operators.

President Ford, faced with a Congress heavily dominated by the opposition party, will make major changes in the staff on which he relies for politically sensitive relations with Senators and Reresentatives.

President Ford will make personal telephone calls to Congressmen to help pass legislation for mass-transit, his Secretary of Transportation today assured a delegation of 14 Mayors, including Mayor Beame of New York.
An Albany County grand jury has voted to indict the Dairylea milk cooperative on charges of conspiracy and filing false and misleading reports with the Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.

China's leadership acknowledged early last summer that the anti-Confucian political campaign had created "major weaknesses" in the economy, according to exprets from a secret document that were published here-today.
Four: children were killed yesterday. morning in a onealarm fire, listed as suspicious by fire officials, in a two-family house in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

The controversial issue of "affirmative disclosure" was not included in the proposed trade regulation published recently by the Federal Trade Commission because the commission's staff couldn't produce a test commercial that meaningfully communicated all of the necessary information.

Has any artist since John J. Audubon been so obsessed with birds as Olivier Messiaen? Mr. Messiaen, the French composer who has been cataloguing bird calls for many years with a devotion that long ago edged into pure mysticism, continues to find both raw material and inspiration in his collections.
The National Archives and CBS Inc. have announced the establishment of an archive of television news broadcasts, in which CBS will give the National Archives videocassettes of news broadcasts.

Ferguson Jenkins, who helped the Texas Rangers become a pennant contender last season by winning 25 games, was named yesterday major league baseball's comeback player of the year by United Press International.

A battle is building over the complicated question of the Government's right to keep secret its secrets. The participants are Congress and much of the national press, on one side, and the White House, the Justice Department and the Central Intelligence Agency on the other.
Members of the House Judiciary Committee who reviewed raw F.B.I. data on Nelson A. Rockefeller expressed concern today over his nomination as Vice President.

Twenty-two-year-old Kathleen Beth Moore resigned her Miss Washington title in protest yesterday after pageant officials decided that she was overweight. Miss Moore, a size 10, said she was asked by the state pageant board last month to lose the 10 pounds she had gained since being named one of the Miss America finalists last September.
Officia at the University--of Rhode Island campus here have called off all classes until Monday because of a break in the campus water system that has shut off the flow of water since early Tuesday.

The exiled author Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn has joined a halfdozen dissident intellectuals within the Soviet Union in publishing a forthcoming anthology of critical essays on aspects of Soviet life, a dissident here disclosed today.
The National Transportation Safety Board recommended today that military jets be barred from practicing interception missions in air lanes used by civilian aircraft.

A two-day holiday Craft Fair by employes for.. employes got underway yesterday at J. Walter Thompson, the nation's largest advertising agency. The faith's purpose, according to planners who had run the idea up the flagpole and gotten many salutes, was to help the company's 1,200 employes "get to know each other."

Sworn testimony yesterday by Vice President designate Nelson A. Rockefeller on how he dealt with a $100,000 possible bribe offer to L, Judson Morhouse conflicts with another account and raises new questions about a race track bribery case, that is still mysterious after 15 years.

The trustees of Monmouth College have reserve scholarship for the brother of William E.'Flowers, a freshman student at the Jersey college who died early Tuesday' during a fraternity hazing. Or. Richard Stonesifer, president of the college, said yesterday that the truestee scholarship would be reserved for 16-year-old Curtis Flowers, the younger brother of the victim.

The State Department of Environmntal Protection promised today that "rejuvenation of older cities" and programs to stimulate employment would be given priority in the expenditure of funds provided by the $200- million "Green Acres" bond issue approved by New Jersey's voters last week.

Public companies that repurchase their own stock to "go private" and escape Federal regulation are inviting prosecution on fraud charges, a Securities and Exchange Commissioner, A. A. Sommer, warned today.

O. J. Simpson and Sonny Jurgensen, pro football's most noted cripples this week, are both expected to play on Sunday in key games. Simpson, favoring a sprained ankle all season, will start for Buffalo against Miami, while Jurgensen, handicapped by a damaged thigh muscle, will be ready if the Redskins should need him against the Dallas Cowboys.
Former President Richard M. Nixon's lawyers today asked a Federal court to block Watergate prosecutors from conducting a "freewheeling rummage" through his personal files.
The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it was suspending trading in the stocks of four companies as a result of the companies' failure to file required reports with the commission.

Even before President Ford chose Las Vegas as the place to make his straight-faced forecast yesterday that inflation would turn down and the economy up, the country needed no confirmation that the Administration's economic analysis has about the same scientific basis as a gambler's approach to the roulette wheel.

Guyana would like to see members of the International Bauxite Association develop "a bauxite unit of currency" in order to avoid the effects of possible devaluations and fluctuations of foreign currencies, Haslyn Parris, deputy chairman of the Guyana Bauxite Company, said in an interview here yesterday.
President Ford declared tonight that it was time for Congress "to fish or cut bait" in confirming his nearly three-month-old nomination of Nelson A. Rockefeller to be Vice President.
"The diet of the affluent countries should not be taken as a model for good nutrition," Norway told the World Food Conference today.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said yesterday that an alleged planner of the murder of the United States Ambassador to the Sudan in 1973 had accompanied Yasir Arafat, Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, and left with him for Havana yesterday.

The Soviet leadership today signaled a tougher, more orthodox line in cultural affairs with the appointment of Pvotr.N. Demichev as Ministe of Culture. Mr. Demichev, for nearly a decades the party's ranking
The Abitibi Paper Company announced yesterday in Toronto a tender offer for 49 per cent of the outstanding shares of the Price Company of Quebec City at a price of $18 a t share.

Black Democrats and the newly powerful upstate Democratic bloc joined suburban Democrats this week in pressing for major roles for themselves in' the Assembly Democractic leadership, until now the exclusive province of New York City.
The "Nova" series has returned to public television, on Sunday at 7:30 P.M., and is quite nicely living up to its own billing as "science adventures for curious grownups."

President Ford said tonight that the question of negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian Liberation Organization was "the responsibility of the parties involved." "Our plans are aimed at trying to get Israel to negotiate a
Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell again yesterday in light trading while those in the over-the-counter market finished mixed in desultory trading.
Guy Lafleur scored two goals and Ken Dryden, the goalie, stopped all but one Boston shot tonight as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Bruins, 4-1, in a National Hockey League game.

Starting today, travel costs were up 10 per cent on most Amtrak trains. Family groups Will pay an even bigger increase. Amtrak's new schedule increases fares 10 per cent for individual passengers on all but few routes.

Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey has decided that dismissal of top officials of the State Department of Mental Hygiene will be only the first step in a sweeping overhaul of a system that has come under heavy attack from voluntary agencies, local officials, community leaders and legislators.

YAPHANK--After a century of providing food for the Suffolk Alms House and its successor, the Infirmary, the County Farm is expanding its mission. The 275-acre farm, which once boasted a prize-winning dairy herd, will shortly become a rehabilitation-educational center for inmates of the neighboring Suffolk County Honor Farm.

WASHINGTON -- It took years for the 25th Amendment of the Constitution to become law in 1967, and during that time a variety of alternatives was considered and discarded. But now that the amendment's machinery is at work for the second time in less than two years, doubts about its efficiency are again being expressed, and some of the doubters have gone back to the discard pile.
The mysterious disappearance of four employes of two different retail stores here within two weeks-two of whom were found murdered in gangland fashion--continued to baffle police investigators today.

The World Food Conference at the final session of its 11-day meeting in Rome approved the formation of a new United Nations agency that will supervise programs intended to give the world-particularly less developed nations-more and better food.

Richard Pousette-Dart is, in some respects, the odd man out of the New York School. Born in 1916 he is the youngest of the painters generally included among the first-generation abstract expressionists. (Robert Motherwell is one year his senior.) His first one-man show took place in 1941, when he was 25, and his work was first shown at the Museum of Modern Art three years later. He was anything but a late starter.
Hans Hellmut Kirst, whose "The Night of the Generals" attracted such attention some years back, is at work on a Munich trilogy. "Damned to Success," the first volume, came out here last year.

SKIERS are a stoic-some say masochistic-lot. They may endure, with relative equanimity, blizzards, below-zero temperatures, fourth-class accommodations and poorto-mediocre food. Some will drive 10 hours without complaint in order to ski on a Patch of slush.

Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn said today at his home here that an anthology of essays he had written with dissidents in the Soviet Union was meant to provide a basis for debate on a Soviet Union "Free of Marxism-Leninism."
NEW BRUNSWICK Grants and scholarship and fellowship funds received by Rutgers University from July through September totaled $4,315,231, an increase of nearly $85,000 over the same period last year.

In the 88th game of the oldest uninterrupted prep school rivalry in the nation, Germantown Academy won its third straight from Penn Charter today, 9-7. Andy King, a Germantown defensive end, nailed a Penn Charter halfback, Leo McClelland, in his end zone for the crucial 2 points.

Chris Kupec passed for four touchdowns, ran for one and set up another to lead North Carblina's Tar Heels to a wild 56-42 victory over Army today. A crowd of 38,900 saw the Sun Bowl-bound Tar Heels score two touchdowns in each quarter to run their season won-lost record to 6-4 as Kupec turned in a brilliant passing performance.
Arned with an one-game winning streak, the Jets clash tomorrow with the New England Patriots, who have a two-game losing streak.

"What is essential is invisible to the eye," and "It's only with the heart that one can see clearly." are two, of its zingers.

A worker who is receiving partial permanent disability compensation for the statutory period and who becomes totally disabled will be entitled to full disability payments, according to a New Jersey Supreme Court ruling. Torn by riots four years ago and recently described by a Federal judge as "a fortress in bedlam," the 33-year-old prison is a monument to the inhumane and ineffective lock-the-door-and-throw-away-the-key school of penology.

Variation's Pour Une Poreteet Un Soupir" is a tenacious trifle that has somehow remained in the New York City Ballet's repertory for a second season. Perhaps no one noticed how tedious it was the first time around.

American consumers are cutting back sharply on their personal spending plans for 1975, according to the latest monthly survey sponsored by-Citicorp.'and its principal subsidiary, the First National City Bank. Seventyone out of every 100 families in the October poll said that they were forgoing some luxury items, compared with 67 per cent in the previous month.

O. J. Simpson set groundgaining records for the University of Southern California and the Pacific-8 Conference, but both seem certain to be broken this weekend, only six years after being set.
Coal-dependent industries announced more layoffs and operations cutbacks yesterday, indicating waning hopes for any settlement in the nationwide coal miners strike in the near future.
Twenty-six of 31 suspects in an alleged southern New Jersey drug ring' were brought into court today for arraignment on charges of conspiracy and selling cocaine, amphetamines and barbiturates.

Stade singing together with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center--which they did on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall and which they will do again tonight-was clearly an enticing one for a good number of people. The hall was full and the cheers were frequent-and deserved.
Members of the Parliament today joined Canadian cattlemen in vigorously denouncing the United States' decision Saturday'to reduce sharply its imports of beef and pork from this country.

John J. Burke, who retired in 1969 as principal of the evening division of Charles Evans Hughes High School, died Sunday at the Todd Nursing Home in Southampton, L.I. He was 68 years old and lived in Hampton Bays. L. I.

The board of the Price Company announced yesterday in Montreal that it was advising shareholders who wish to sell their shares "to tender through their brokers with instructions to accept the best offer available."

The Coca-Cola Company announced plans today to sell its soda in recyclable plastic bottles. The company displayed samples of the bottles, called "the easy goer," behind plexiglass in an exhibit at the National Soft Drink Association Convention here.
The White House announced today a sugar import' quota for 1975 and urged Americans to reduce their use of sugar in cooking and to cut in half the amount used with coffee and tea.

Henriette Pascar Liberman, who formerly directed the State Theater for Children in Moscow, died yesterday in Paris, where she had lived since 1924 except during World War II, when she lived in New York.

Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180 day maturities. The average rate 'for the three-month bill was 7.528 per cent, down from 7.604 per cent for the preceding week.

Dennis Trujillo of Army, a 20-year-old junior from Pueble, Colo., ran an unorthodox -race yesterday that proved to be the winning formula in the I.C. 4-A cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park.

Five weeks after it gave final approval, Congress sent to the White House legislation to increase G.I. education benefits by 22.7 per cent for 10 million Vietnam-era and post-Korea veterans. It did so today in the face of a renewed threat by President Ford to veto it as inflationary.

A five-run ninthinning rally, highlighted' by home runs by Felix Millan and Teddy Martinez, gave the New York Mets a 9-5 victory over Tokyo's Yomiuri Giants today. It was only the Mets' third victory in 10 exhibition baseball games against the Giants. The two teams also have tied twice, Against all teams, including all-star clubs,the Mets have eight victories, six losses and two ties with two games remaining in Japan--one more against the Giants.

An unusual Government order that bars imprisoned smugglers from appealing to the courts and revokes their civil liberties for six months was fiercely denounced today in Parliament and the press and among opposition politicians.

The head of the organization that represents most of the city's principals and other school supervisors called yesterday for the State Legislature to investigate the alleged misuse of funds and mismanagement in some of the city's decentralized community school districts.

Richard M. Nixon agreed to a plan for clemency for E. Howard Hunt Jr., one of the Seven original Watergate defendants, on Jan. 8, 1973, the day .they went on trial, according to a tape recording played today in the Watergate cover-up case.

When Thomas S. Buechner quietly took command of Steuben Glass two years ago, he announced no changes and outlined no new design direction. But Steuben's wares have changed-and dramatically. Not the lead crystal itself, mind you, That sophisticated material, developed decades ago by technicians at Coming Glass Works, the parent company, is still possibly the purest ever produced. And it's not the craftsmanship either. The skills of Steuben's artisans remain the envy of artisans everywhere.

Paul S. Farley, a former president of the Atlantic County Bar Association, died yesterday in the Atlantic City Medical Center. He was 78 years old.

Clive Brook, the durable actor who epitomized British suavity and elegance in scores of portrayals on the stage and in silent and talking films on both sides of the Atlantic, died Sunday night at his home in London. He Was 87 Years old. old.

A young holdup man who told the manager of a Fifth Avenue bank that he represented a Puerto Rican nationalist organization escaped with $86,000 yesterday after threatening to blow up the bank, if the manager did not follow his precise instructions.

A pipe bomb exploded early yesterday morning in the doorway of the eight-story building of the Watchtower Bible and Tract Society, Inc., in Brooklyn Heights causing some damage. The Senate, in a show of sup port meant to impress the House of Representatives, voted 64 to 17 today to approve a six-year, $11.8-billion mass transit program.

Richard M. Nixon told two of his aides in April, 1973, that he would give "full pardons" to various Watergate participants before he left the Presideney according to a tape recording played today at the Watergate cover-up trial.
President Ford appealed to the Japanese people today to join the United States in an alliance that would provide a model for dealing with the new economic difficulties of inflation and recession.

The state's Department of Community Affairs announced today that it would strip Community Progress, Inc., a pioneering antipoverty organization, of its role as conduit for $1.5-million a year in state antipoverty funds here.

One of the nation's largest supermarket chains today disclosed its markups on the retail price of meat, to support its contention that the difference between what a farmer receives and a consumer pays "is not attributable to profiteering by supermarket chains."

With Northern Ireland wracked by bloody sectarian strife, the election last year of Erskine Hamilton Childers as President of the Irish Republic was a rare stroke of fortune. On its face, his candidacy seemed almost bizarre: born' in London, educated in England, possessed of a Cambridge accent but possessing only a smidgin of Gaelic, a naturalized Irish citizen.

The other panelists seemed to agree.

The Austrian city of Innsbruck is planning a simpler kind of program, laced with culture, for the 1976 Winter Olympics. Mayor Alois Lugger of Innsbruck said that the' games would "get away from the gigantic affairs of earlier' years." Besides' action on snow and ice, the games will feature performances by the Vienna Philharmonic, the Vienna State Opera and an international art exhibition with a sports theme.

Theater at Riverside Church, which last season presented the world premiere of Miguel Pifiero's prize-winning "Short Eyes," is again focusing this year on new playwrights, beginning with "Leaving Home," by a young Canadian writer, David French.

President Ford today brushed off an effort by the Governor of Tokyo to. get assurances that the United States was not bringing nuclear weapons into Japan, thus leaving unresolved an issue that rankles relations between the two countries.

A Woodside, Queens, man was killed and' anther man wounded yesterday in what the state police termed a hunting accident in this upstate Greene County 'town. A third man was arrested in the incident.

The announcement went against his original decision to retire from the House of Representatives in 1977, and it went beyond the statement he made after he got into the White House that he would "probably" run again.

Recent charges of cancer-causing chemicals in tap water supplies helped induce the House today to vote minimum Federal purity standards for drinking water under a bill that had been delayed for four years.

The Republic Steel Corporation declared today a special $1.40 dividend and a 40-cent quarterly dividend for the highest annual total per common share in seven years.
A West German 747 jumbo jet crashed today as it was taking off from Nairobit Airport, and eyewitnesses said they believed there was a heavy loss of life.
Volkswagenwerk, AG, the company that makes the widely sold Volkswagen cars, reported today a worldwide sales drop of $8.8-million during the first nine months of this year

The first round of play in the European championships in Tel Aviv earlier this month saw a clash between two old rivals, Britain and Italy. As the Italians had three newcomers to international play, and only Benito Bianchi from their world champion team, it seemed likely that the experienced British sextet would have the best of it.
Milton R. Young, the incumbent Republican Senator, defeated William L. Guy by 177 votes in the race for the Senate, the State Canvassing Board announced today.
Most Vietnamese-language newspapers resumed publishing today after a two-day halt to protest censorship, but anti-Government protests remained in a lull.

The House ways and Means Committee voted today to give some tax relief next year to nearly 40 million individuals and couples, about half of them with incomes under $7,000 and most of the rest with incomes between $7,000 and $15,000.
New Jersey state government may follow the lead of the Beatles, Mia Farrow, the actress, and a host of other followers of Guru Maharishi Mahesh Yogi if an Assembly resolution is passed.

Arthur W. Ponzio, former Atlantic City Public Works Commissioner, surrendered to authorities to begin serving a six-year Federal prison term for extortion. Mr. Ponzio turned himself in at the United States Marshal's office in Newark. He was one of seven former city officials convicted

First the good news. Dave Cowens, out of action since breaking a bone on his right foot during a preseason game, worked out with the Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Association yesterday under the watchful eyes of team officials and Dr. Robert Leach, a bone specialist.
The world's leading copper exporting countries today decided to enforce a quota system on copper shipments in an attempt to stabilize declining prices.
Broom Hilda, a Ranger 37 sloop, finished first overall today in the 1,023mile Los Angeles to Mazatlan yacht race, winning with the slowest elapsed time in the history of the event.
The pressure to return to the football field has been gnawing at John Riggins but he'll judge his readiness by a prescription he once received from an old druggist back home in Centralia, Kan.
The report on housing development and rehabilitation that Mayor Beame's Policy Committee issued yesterday proposes housing goals that many housing. experts would

The State Commission of Investigation asserted yesterday that officials of a Queens-based labor union had "improperly and irresponsibly" invested more than $8-million of members', pension and welfare funds in highly speculative land and shaky stock ventures, resulting in the loss of more than $5-million.

A retired assistant chief inspector of the city's Police Department, Arthur B. Hill, denied yesterday that he had ever received $2,000 a month in payoffs for protecting gamblers while he served as commanding officer of the old 13th Division in Brooklyn.
John C. Sawhill, outgoing Federal Energy Administrator, said yesterday that the oil industry exerted much more influence in Washington than he hard imagined.

A seemingly harmless safety opened the way for a 19point third quarter for Kansas City last night, leading the Chiefs to a National Football League victory over Denver and wrecking the Broncos' playoff hopes.

During a period when there appears to be no hope of any real relief from the burden of taxes imposed at any level of government, taxpayers must be content with modest blessings. One such blessing would be Governorelect Hugh L. Carey's campaign proposal, now picked up by Mayor Beame, to have the state take over the collection of city Income taxes.

A three-judge Federal District Court upheld yesterday the right of New York's private foster-care institutions, nearly half of them Roman Catholic, to receive state support despite the constitutional prohibition of state aid to religion.
John J. Gilhooley, who was recruited for the presidency of the New York Racing Association by the country's top executive-search agency, yesterday turned the job down.
Former Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany suggested today that the march toward a united Europe could be much accelerated if those who dragged their feet were left behind.

The coordinator of the newly formed Government Women's Coalition has asked the State Senate to block the nomination of Penelope L. Kuykendall, named by Governor Byrne to head the recently upgraded Division on Women.
District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn announced yesterday the indictments of 157 persons who he said were part of a vast criminal network with illegal gambling at its hub.
About 3,000 college students and religious demonstrators staged anti-Government rallies and prayer meetings today calling for the return of democracy to South Korea.
For the first time in Japan's recorded history, the Japanese people were invited inside the Imperial Palace tonight, while their Emperor was having dinner with Gerald Ford.

Nelson A. Rockefeller for 13 years was a secret major stockholder and financial force behind a small California newspaper published by his friends, Thomas W. and Joan Braden, according to persons familiar with the arrangement.

The deepening recession is cutting employment opportunities so sharply, here that college graduates now are competing with school dropouts and people on welfare for a shrinking number of low-paying entry-level jobs, the New York Board of Trade reported yesterday.
President Ford appealed to the Japanese people today to join the United States in an alliance that would provide a model for dealing with the new economic difficulties of inflation and recession.

It was on a raw, blustery afternoon in 1935 that Frank LiCausi, a 21-year-old clerk at a Lower East Side welfare office, moved with his wife and infant daughter into the trim brick apartment house that was being dedicated that day.
Fifty-nine persons on a West German jumbo jetliner died here today but the 98 others aboard survived when the plane crashed and burned shortly after take-off.

President Ernesto Geisel's commitment to lead Brazil in "gradual but sure progress toward democracy" will be put to its most severe test to date by his Government party's unexpectedly heavy losses in this week's congressional and state elections.

The South Bronx was once a lush green area. It was first settled by a few influential families with significant I and holdings. In the area of Melrose, Mott Haven and Port Morris, Jonas Bronk in 1.64i purchased 500 acres which he then subdivided and leased to individual farmers on a threeyear basis.

The Independent Stave Company of Lebanon, Mo., which manufactures charcoaled barrels for whisky distillers, was convicted today on criminal charges of violating the Clean Air Act and faces-possible fines of $3.9-million.
Italy announced today their support of a Middle East settlement that would enable Israel to live peacefully within the frontiers she had before the 1967 war.
The New Jersey Supreme Court upheld today a lower court ruling that permitted parents to sue their son for injuries in an automobile accident.
The House Rules Committee, with Presidential intervention, reversed itself today. and cleared the way for a six-year, $11.8-billion transit bill to reach the floor of the House of Representatives.
Ronald Robert Carey, president of Local. 804 of the Teamsters Union has been-a part of the parcel delivery business for as long as he can remember.
In 'grief mingled with anger and shame,- the people of this israeli town today burLed the four civilians slain yesterday by three Palestinian in??iltrators from Jordan.

The Health Department has released the names of 10 more restaurants and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted through two inspections.

A City Council committee was unable yesterday to vote on top- priority legislation, which would permit the city to recoup $17.5-million from landlords for emergency housing repairs, because only four of its 11 members showed up for a scheduled meeting.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market continued to slide yesterday as bullish news remained scarce.

Experts in the field of farm fertillizers warned here today that rising costs, unless eased, would cause lower crop yields next year, increasing farmers' expenses and consequently resulting in higher prices for food.

Britain, France'and Italy urged a Middle East settlement enabling Iseael to live peacefully within her pre-1967 war borders. In the United Nations General Assembly debate on the "Question of Palestine," they reflected the position taken by the European Economic Community and first stated by West Germany in Tuesday's debate. Britain's delegate stressed that the right of Palestinians must not infringe or challenge the right of Israel to exist as a state. [Page 1, Column 5.

A three-judge Federal panel has struck down as unconstitutional sections of the law providing benefits to miners with black lung. The ruling could make it more difficult for some coal miners or relatives of deceased miners to obtain benefits.

The leadership of the United Mine Workers Union disclosed tonight that it had failed to win the first step in approval of the tentative labormanagement contract negotiated last week with the coal industry and would seek to return to the bargaining table.
Four Egyptian vessels today corn pleted the journey through the Suez Canal from Port Said to Suez, the first craft to do so since 1967, naval sources in. Suez reported tonight.

Sidney C. Moody, a retired executive in the chemical industry died yesterday at his home, 63 Leland Avenue Plain-field, N. J. He was 79 years old. Mr. Moody, who spent 40 years with the American Cyanamid Company, retired in 1960 as vice president in charge of international operations.
The Government filed an antitrust suit today to break up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on the ground that it illegally monopolizes the telecommunications business.

A 10-year "proposal for discussion" to build or rehabilitate 51,200 apartments in Harlem -- as much as one-fourth of its present supply -- and to develop sources there for 12,667 new jobs was made public yesterday by state and city officials.
The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation acknowledged yesterday that it had reached a settlement with the Government of Jamaica on its problems with bauxite operations in that country.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the nation's largest privately owned corporation, is a longtime darling of investors.

Striking employes of United Parcel Service in the metropolitan area voted overwhelmingly yesterday to accept a mediatorrecommended three-year contract and ended their 87-day walkout against the company.
Two persons were killed on the Long-Island Expressway yesterday in two accidents, involving five cars. Traffic was disrupted for nearly three hours.
Five Federal indictments unsealed yesterday in Brooklyn and Manhattan sketched out a global network of heroin and opium smuggling that allegedly operated between 1970 and 1972.
Consolidated Bathurst, Ltd., of Montreal, Canada's fifth largest newsprint manufacturer, has entered a competing bid to acquire the Price Company, Ltd., Canada's third largest newsprint producer.
Roger Lewis, who served as president of Amtrak during the stormy three-year revival of the United States passenger train system, will resign as soon as a successor can be found, Amtrak said to-day.
Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party chief, has expanded his coming trip to Egypt early next year to include two other Arab countries. .
Americans are being urged to fast today as a practical and symbolic gesture of concern over starvation that threatens more than 500 million persons in more than 30 countries.

HOT TO TROT. By John Lahr. 241 pages. Knopf. $6.95. When George Melish, a TV producer, tells his wife, Irene, that he loves her, he sounds like a commercial, not for the Coke or Pepsi but the egg-cream generation. "There's more to love than feeling," he warns.

The House of Representatives, dealing a serious blow to President Ford, overrode today his vetoes of two bills by overwhelming margins. With all but a few lame-duck Republican Representatives abandoning the President, the House voted, 398 -to 7,

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have been instructed to begin a preliminary investigation of the death of Karen G. Silkwood, a technician who had raised critical safety questions about an Oklahoma plutonium factory.
Judge Irving Lang issued a warrant in Criminal Court yesterday for a Queens woman who has dodged her sentence on a grand larceny conviction for two years by pretending to be terminally ill.

Once one of America's most vibrant communities, Harlem now finds its growth and development in peril. That is the statistical picture that emerges in the findings of a task force of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, a community -based state agency involved in the redevelopment of the area.
A joint state legislative committee yesterday became a sounding board for a series of attacks on the state's mentalhealth program and the State Department of Mental Hygiene.

Concanal, Ltd., a venture formed earlier this year by five Canadian companies, has been awarded a contract by Sonatrach, the Algerian state-owned oil and gas agency. Under the contract, Concanal would design and engineer the Algerian portion of a 300-mile natural gas transmission pipeline to supply gas from the Hassi R Mel natural gas field in Algeria to Italy. The value of the contract was not disclosed.

The price of sugar went up 7 cents a pound last week in the New York area's retail food markets, raising its cost in the last 15 months from 18 cents a pound to an average of 71 cents, according to the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.
The head of the Agriculture Department's sugar division said today, retail sugar prices eventually could decline to 20 cents a pound.

A Cornell University economics professor urged the Securities and Exchange Commission to-day to require "full disclosure" of brokerage transactions to assure that customers received the best execution. of buy or sell orders.
World sugar prices soared again yesterday to new high levels. In New York, the March world sugar futures contract jumped the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit to close at 65.20 cents a pound.

A state grand jury is expected to begin hearing evidence this week into charges that tax-collection agents of the Special Investigations Bureau of the State Department of Taxation and Finance had connived with cigarette bootleggers to smuggle untaxed cigarettes into the state.
The Arizona Supreme Court has ordered former United States Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst censured for a misdemeanor committed in Washington.
With the momentum of their 10goal walloping of California carrying over into tonight's game, the New York Rangers jumped off to a three-goal lead against Detroit.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange moved in a narrow range throughout the session yesterday and finished lower in slower trading.

A 10-year "proposal for discussion" to build or rehabil Rate 51,200 apartments in Harlem - as much as onefourth of its present supply - and to develop sources there for 12,667 new jobs was made public yesterday by state and city officials.

Striking employes of United Parcel Service in the metropolitan area voted overwhelmingly yesterday to accept a mediatorrecommended three-year contract and ended their 87-day walkout against the company.
Roland Robert Carey, president of Local 804 of the Teamsters Union, has been a part of the parcel delivery business for as long as he can remember.

Opera, the most prodigally expensive of the performing arts, is always first to feel the pain when the economic shoe pinches. And the Metropolitan Opera, oldest and by far the biggest of American companies, seems currently beaded into the biggest trouble.
The United States signed an agreement today to sell wheat and rice valued at about $22 million to Syria as a step toward economic cooperation.

The general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization adopted a resolution today to withhold aid from Israel because of what it called her "persistence in altering the historical features" of Jerusalem "by undertaking excavations which constitute a danger to its monuments."

President Nixon directed in April, 1973, that his aides put out a "line" in which they would all say that they had indeed raised money for the seven original Watergate defendants but that the purpose was to keep the defendants from talking to the press, not to keep them from telling the truth to the authorities.

Portuguese officials, while participating in negotiations for a new agreement on American use of air facilities in the Azores, are pressing the United States for a decision to accord, economic aid quickly.
A Superior Court jury convicted a fifth Philadelphia Black Muslim, today for the murder of seven Hanafi Moslems here last year.
The Federal Government has been petitioned the Natural Resources Defehse Council to outlaw spray cans using propellants suspected of breaking down the earth's protective ozone laver.
A Federal energy expert said yesterday that "based on historical experience, oil prices should significantly decline Within the next one to three years."

The NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., filed suit today charging the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Civil Service Commission with employment discrimination against blacks and women.

Louise Perkins Fitzhugh, author and illustrator of "Harriet the Spy" and other children's books, died Tuesday evening at a hospital in New Milford, Conn. She was 46 years old and lived in Bridgewater, Conn.
To the Editor: Whether or not Gen. George Brown is removed from his critical post as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff is perhaps the least important aspect of the ugly incident.

Never let it be said that the soft-drink industry is not responsiveto consumers. Stung by public criticism that the. prices.,o diet sodas have been climbing right along with the prices of sugared sodas, one major bottler has finally decided to give consumers a one-cent break on some diet drinks.

CLOTHES MAKE THE MET A calvacade of more than 100 costumes worn by movie queens of nineteen-thirties, forties and fifties is spread through the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum starting today as a golden-days reminder of Hollywood luxury and extraordinary craftsmanship.
