It would not be exactly correct to say that Henry Hobson Richardson, who died in 1886,. has never gotten the recognition he deserves. There is a growing body of scholarship about him, and architectural pilgrims frequently journey to the Boston area to see the large number of surviving Richardson buildings near here.
When he returned to the winner's circle after having guided the Hobeau Farm's Group Plan to convincing victory in the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday,

An all-male jury began deliberations yesterday afternoon in the eight-week trial of William R. Phillips, the suspended police officer accused of killing a pimp and an 18-year-old prostitute and of the attempted fatal shooting of a customer on Christmas Eve. 1968.

A Queens Congressman anbounced in Washington yesterday that the Federal Government had decided to deny Medicaid payments to five nursing homes in New York State that had violated the fire safety code. But the Department of Health, Education, and Welfare said it had not yet made up its mind.
President Ford's latest expression of opposition to increase the Federal gasoline tax has disrupted energy policy planning at a critical moment.
Bankruptcies, involvencies and simply poor financial management brought grief and suffering in recent years to thousands who thought that they were assured of pensions. in their "golden years."
The House of Representatives dealing a serious blow to Presi dent Ford, overrode today his vetoes of two bills by over whelming margins.
George F. Hull, chief photographer and garden editor of The Chattanooga Times, died Wednesday in a hospital here. He was 65 years old. Mr. Hull had been with The Times 46 years.

Only a few years after grade and academic success seemed to score somewhere below haircuts on a college student's scale of values, campuses across the country are worrying about a growing and often fearful obsession with grades.
The Minnesota pollution agency decided yesterday to authorize a lawsuit against the Army Corps of Engineers to force a court to determine whether the corps must meet state water quality laws.
It was a great day for long-shot players today as the Florida winter racing season got under way at Calder Race Course in bright, mild weather.

It was a hard night for a New York rookie, Bob Bourne, as the Islanders battled the goal judge, the referee and the Black Hawks to a 4-4 tie tonight before a full house of 16,666,persons in Chicago Stadium.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday announced that he had filed an action in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn against the Brooklyn Trade Waste Association, Inc.,/asking the court to dissolve the association and bar its members from doing business as private carters in Brooklyn.

Britain won only minor concessions from the Common Market partners on complex beef and sugar issues at a marathon meeting of the community's agricultural ministers that ended here at 6:30 this morning.

A Manhattan lawyer who allegedly arranged sham marriages between illegal aliens and United States citizens so that the aliens might remain in this country as permanent residents was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury.
Frederick D. Wilkinson Jr., a vice president of Macy's, was appointed yesterday to a newly created $50,000-a-year position to oversee bus and subway passenger safety and comfort.
Following is the text of the United States-Japanese communiqud issued today at the conclusion of President Ford's talks with Japanese officials:

Within the last eight to 10 days in which time tensions in the Middle East have increased, the oil exporting countries have diversified the flow of their' surplus funds into strong European currencies, according to an analysis at a meeting of.monetary experts here.

Ships from the United States, pritain, Iran, Pakistan ,and Turkey, including the 60,000ton American carrier Constellation, are participating in the largest naval exercise ever held in the Indian Ocean.
Victor Korchrroi was granted a postponement today of the 24th and last game of his final Candidates match for the world championship with Anatoly Karpov. The game.

On the basis of his performance against Detroit last Sunday in his first regular-season start as a New York Giant, Leon McQuay probably will be moved up from third - string running back to first string for Sunday's game against St. Louis in the Yale Bowl.

The military Government virtually swept away what was left of an independent press in Peru last night by closing two magazines, exiling 10 journalists and ordering the detention of five leading lawyers.
Five or six separate scuffles broke out today at South Boston High School-the first time fighting has occurred in several weeks in the desegregation of Boston schools.

A Federal judge ordered the Ford Administration today to surrender by next week any White House tape recordings involving the Government's controversial handling of the "Mayday" antiwar demonstrations here in the spring of 1971.

State Education Commnission Fred G. Burke ruled today that school teachers could not be required to wear neckties in class. The ruling struck down a section of the school board dress code in Atlantic County that was challenged by the local teachers union.

CBS-TV announced yesterday that the "Planet of the Apes" series has been canceled and that it will be replaced Feb. 7 by "Khan," a new one-hour series about an Oriental detective based in San Francisco. "Khan,"

The Board of Education voted last night to establish a powerful now office of auditor-general with a broad mandate-backed up by a $1.5-million annual budget-to audit not only the fiscal transactions of local school districts,
The National Cancer Advisory Board proposed today that President Ford make a personal public appeal to tobacco companies to market more lowtar and low-nicotine cigarettes.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation searched yesterday for four kidnappers who kept a Long Island man chained in an apartment closet for a week until his family paid a $750,000 ransom for his release Tuesday night.

With little exception, schoolboy football conference and sectional championships are settled in the final games of the season. So the customary interest is escalating for the 1974 windup, which takes form in a small schedule this weekend and a bigger one Thanksgiving Day.

Nearly a year ago the Department of the Interior announced its intention to curb the dangerously increasing importation of exotic pets. The instrument was to be the Lacey Act, which empowers the Secretary to ban the admission of animals considered harmful to this country's agriculture, forestry, wildlife or people. The sooner the department takes action to this effect, the better,

Heen Baba and his Dance and Drum Ensemble made their local debut Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall. If the name of the group does not set any chimes ringing, it is because this is the first time the beauties of the classical dance of Sri Lanka have received such prominent exposure here.

A second series of achievement tests administered to a cross shction of New Jersey's public school students show that a large number of students had failed to master basic reading and, mathematical skills and that these deficiencies were greater in predominantly urban areas.
The American Kennel Club has come up with a film on gait that should be a must for all judges to see Perhaps before the A.K.C. grants a provisional judge approval,

Fifty-nine persons on a West German jumbo jetliner died here today but the 98 others aboard survived when the plane clashed and burned shortly after take off. Most of the passengers were Germans, but the airline, Lufthansa, said the survivors included 12 Americans.

Hope for a quick end to the strike by faculty members of eight state colleges was abandoned abruptly today when both sides to of the dispute acknolwdged that a long "informal" meeting requested by the state had resulted in "no progress."

The Federal Bureau of Investigation searched yesterday for four kidnappers who kept a Long Island man chained in an apartment closet for a week until his family paid a $750,000 ransom for his release Tuesday night.
Attorney General William B. Saxbe asked Congress today to legalize the publication and broadcasting of information about state-sanctioned lotteries.

Richard H, Crowe, a Central Intelligence Agency official for nearly 15 years, died today. He was 63 years old. Mr. Crowe joined the C.I.A. in 1946, after attaining the rank of Lieutenant Colonel with the Army Air Forces in England. He resigned from the agency in 1969 because of illness.
The Government filed an antitrust suit today to break up the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on the ground that it illegally monop??lizes the telecommunications business.

The New York Department of transportation said yesterday that it had arranged for an emergency bus service to run the 98 miles between Binghamton and Geneva, N.Y., one of several upstate routes that have lost all public transportation because of a nationwide strike against Greyhound Bus Lines.

No, it is not necessary to totter around on heels 5 inches high to keep in the swing of fashion. In the last few weeks, many fashion designers showing their spring collections in both Paris and New York have resurrected comfortable looking low heel shoes for their mannequins to wear even with longer skirts.

While fun and games were being promoted in Central Park for the past eight years, the Parks Department has been sinking deeper into administrative and operational chaos. In spite of efforts at improvement made by earlier administrators, there is now a crisis situation that has the current regime on the ropes.

In the next decade, American newspapers will probably become smaller, easier to read and carry fewer advertisements, not necessarily because their publishers want it that way, but because they will cost more to produce.

Arived here in Japar's ancient capital today after concluding his talks with Japanese officials on a note of amity and with a broad, general agreement that the two countries would seek to strengthen their cooperation on economic matters.
A requiem eucharist for Presdent Erskine Childers of Ireland will be conducted today at noon at St. Paul's Chapel of Trinity Parish, Braodway at Vesey Street.
In grief mingled with anger and shame, the people of this Israeli town today buried the four civilians slain yesterday by-three Palestinian infiltrators from Jordan.

Billie Jean King, president of the Womens International Tennis Association, said yesterday that she would not fight the decision of the British Women Players Association to compete at Wimbledon next year, but indicated that without the participation of the W.T.A. the tournam.ent would carry very little importance.

The sale of the World Football League's Florida Blazers has been consummated and the new owners will deliver a partial payment of $2-million before halftime of tomorrow night's playoff game against Philadelphia, a team spokesman said today.

The shell corporation that holds all the stock of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company will hold its annual meeting in the Franklin Suite of Philadelphia's Benjamin Franklin Hotel at 11 A.M. Dec. 19.
In a move to halt the headlong rush of foreign-held funds into Swiss francs, the Government imposed today a 12 per cent annual tax on such funds deposited in Swiss accounts after Oct. 31.
A Chilean copper corporation official announced today that the country's fifth largest copper mine would cease operations for six months beginning Dec. 1.
After losing their 6-foot-; 9-inch rookie star, Marvin Barnes, who disappeared somewhere in Westbury, the Spirits of St. Louis almost managed to upset the Nets tonight.

A former law partner and close associate of William O. Bittman contradicted Mr. Bittman today and testified that the lawyer did, in fact, see a controversial memorandum from their former client, E. Howard Hunt Jr., shortly after it was written.

President Ford arrived here in Japan's ancient capital today after concluding his talks with Japanese officials on a note of amity and with' a broad, general agreement that the two countries would seek to strengthen their cooperation on economic matters.

A survey of the newly elected House shows that a big majority of Representatives are in favor of key reforms, including a move to strip the Ways and Means Committee chairman, Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, of control over committee assignments.
New York City, with its huge and diversified economy, used to think of itself as recession-resistant, protected against the worst downswings of the national economy.
A judge in Federal District Court gave conditional approval last night to plans by the city's Department of Correction to close its Branch Queens House of Detention today.

American television may finally be learning how to deal With American history. Tonight at 9:30 on CBS, a series of four 90-minute dramas about Benjamin Franklin is begun smoothly and impressively with "The Ambassador," written by Howard Fast.
The office of the City Clerk is under investigation, city officials said last night. They said that Herman Katz, who has held the post since 1958, resigned last week.
Four persons were killed tonight when a singeengine plane making its landing approach to Westchester County Airport crashed into a heavily wooded area here about two miles north of the runway.

Reliable sources disclosed today that American, and Soviet negotiators had recessed talks on an agreement to limit underground nuclear tests without resolving a deadlock over the inclusion of regulations on peaceful nuclear explosions.

The Senate voted today to deny all but $200,000 of the $850,000 recommended by President Ford to help, Richard M. Nixon return to private life. The transition funds were contained in an $8.3-billion catch-all supplemental appropriations brill.
Bob McAdoo scored 5 of his 27 points in the final minutes tonight: as the Buffalo Braves pulled away for a 115-104 decision over the Washington Bullets, their ninth straight victory.
"Western Electric is one of the best and most efficient manufacturing companies in the country," Paul Naughton, a First Boston Corporation securities analyst, said yesterday.
The General Assembly's Political Committee voted 82 to 2 today to approve a proposal by Pakistan that a zone free of nuclear weapons be established in South Asia.
An angry civil liberties debate has erupted here over a Government order to suspend the legal rights of smugglers.
Thought for the day: Although Tchaikovsky's "Swan Lake" was first produced in Russia in 1877, it was not known in its complete stage version in the West until 1934.
New York City has reached the fiscal "breaking point" in paying for things that should be the responsibility of Albany and Washington, Mayor Beame said last-night.
The Treasury sold today $2.25-billion of 134-day tax anticipation notes, maturing next April 16, at an average rate of 7.426 per cent.

The serious slump in textiles is causing widespread unemployment in the South's bellwether industry. Several thousand workers have been laid off and more thousands are expected to be furloughed as textile and related plants producing apparel and synthetic fibers cut production.

In his first appearance since his defeat by the voters, Governor Wilson said today he was no "Alibi Ike," and attributed the election outcome largely to "a national tide" of such forces as inflation and Watergate that were rooted outside the campaign, and the state.

The Associated Press Managing Editors Association presented its 1974 Freedom of Information Award to-day to The Honolulu Star Bulletin for "protecting and advancing the free flow of information from governmental bodies to the American public through, three legal actions within a year.
The first survey of deafness 'in the United, States in 40 years has found that the impairment is twice as prevalent among Americans as was previously believed.

Muharem Kurbegovic, the accused "alphabet bomber," wants to be deported to his native Yugoslavia, his attorney said today Mr. Kurbegovic, who is 31 years old, is scheduled to undergo a sanity trial starting Dec. 16.
Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., survived an early scare and came back strongly today to defeat Pat Cramer of South Africa, 5-7, 6-1, 6-0, at the South African tennis tournament.
Through the local United States Attorney here, the Department of Justice has made known that the crime of possession of small amounts of marijuana will no longer be prosecuted.
George T. Kinley, a hardwood merchant, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 275 Central Park Wesst.

Jonathan L. Goldstein, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, said the legal profession was responsible for much of the atmosphere of corruption in the United States, and he urged lawyers to clean up their "hired gun" image.

Pan American World Airways and Eastern Airlines disclosed yesterday that they had been holding "exploratory" talks on a merger. But they emphasized that the talks, paralleling others Pan American has been holding with Trans World Airlines, were still in an early stage.
A team of research experts, striking a blow at the belief that childless marriages are incomplete, reports the happiest married couples are' those without children.
The Navy has ordered a special court-martial for a Seabee who threw a chocolate cream pie in a warrant officer's face.

The soviet Union, which has reported to his people in detail on the energy shortages in the West, has begun somewhat more discreetly a domestic campaign to save fuel by reducing waste and inefficiency.

Four hundred fifty French mayors and deputy mayors broke through a police cordon here today, noisily protesting a Government decree transferring a regional capital-a move without precedent since the days of Napolean III.

Most people who live in Harlem see their neighborhood declining amid crime, drugs, poor housing, unclean streets and unemployment. Convinced that community services are inadequate and that they have little or no influence over what happens in Harlem, residents conclude they are trapped.

In the first test of a new United States policy aimed at curbing "excess" flights to this country by foreign airlines, the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday ordered KLM Royal Dutch Airlines to submit its trans-Atlantic schedules for approval by the board within seven days.
At 9 o'clock Tuesday night, Patrick J. McGrath, president of Case McGrath, was in his office wondering aloud why he had not heard from his mother. By 9:05 she had called.

Ruth V. Matheney, director of Curriculum, department of nursing, City College, died yesterday at Lydia E. Hall Hospital, Freeport, L..I. She was 63 years old and lived at 98-15 Horace Harding Expressway, Rego Park. Queens.

The best thing about President Ford's visit to Tokyo was that the worst didn't happen. There were no big anti American demonstrations, no incidents to threaten the President, no bombing of the American Club or of the Pan American World Airways office or other obviously American symbols, no tearing down of burning of the hundreds of American flags that decorated the Ginza.
Judge Irving Lang issued a warrant in Criminal Court yesterday for a Queens woman who has dodged her sentence on a grand larceny conviction for two years by pretending to be terminally ill.
Maj. Gen. Roger J Browne, U.S.A.F., retired, a former high-ranking city official, died Tuesday at Womack Army Hospital, Fort Bragg, N.C. He was 68 years old and lived at Southern Pines N.C.

Jeff Burroughs, the Texas Rangers' long-ball hitting outfielder, was named the American League's most valuable player yesterday. Burroughs, a 23-year-old who played only his second year in the big leagues in 1974, won handily over Joe Rudi of the Oakland A's and became the first player from an expansion club to win the award.

Premier - designate Aldo Moro tonight ended Italy 's longest postwar Government crisis when he formally agreed to from a Cabinet. The 58-year-old Mr. Moro announced his decision to President Giovanni Leone 49 days after the resignation of premier Mariano Rumor.

As children hurry to school here in the chilly mornings, Syrian Air Force jets whine in swift flight over this capital.

County Executive Alfred B. DelBello disclosed today that Joseph R. Schmitt, a high-ranking aide in charge of welfare fraud investigations, resigned last week because of his alleged involvement in a Yonkers taxassessment controversy.
Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey yesterday named a 14-member committee to recommend to him ways of improving the selection of judges and the functioning of the courts.

The older one gets in the pursuit of national and ethnic tastes, the more solid the thought that man is indeed what he eats. Among the most intriguing aspects. of exploring the foods of this lusty, proud and immaculately clean self-governed territory are the categories into which the island dishes fall-Chinese, Malayan, Indian and Eurasian.

Mayor Robert Cahill of Beacon, N.Y., said a curfew imposed Tuesday would remain in effect at least through this morning as "a precautionary measure" against further racial disturbances. Meanwhile, officials said about a third of the students were absent after schools reopened. They were closed Tuesday following racial disturbances. Eight persons have been injured in incidents that started last Friday. No new disturbances were reported.

Final work on a Federal strip mining bill stalled today over a surprise demand by Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, that HouseSenate conferees drop a key compromise on surface owners' rights.

Most people who live in Harlem see their neighborhood declining amid crime, drugs, poor housing, unclean streets and unemployment. Convinced that community services are inadequate and that they have little or no influence over what happens in Harlem, residents conclude they are trapped.

Prime Minister Nehru of India visited the United, States in 1961. When he was in New York on Nov. 9, Governor Rockefeller called on him for a private talk. Afterward J. K. Galbraith, the U.S. Ambassador to India, asked Nehru how the meeting had gone.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the nation's largest privately owned corporation, is a longtime darling of investors.

Police Chief Charles Makwinskiof Carteret and Borough Councilman Eugene DeVito, leaded not guilty in Superior Court in New Brunswick yesterday on charges stemming from' a four-month investigation 'into alleged ticket-fixing in the borough.

Attorney General William F. Hyland ruled yesterday that the state could participate in a Federal home mortgage program that allocates $47-million to New Jersey. Approval of participation in the plan had been held up because of the question of whether it was legal to charge percentage points above what is paid for interest on the loan.
Fritz Jahoda, a faculty member at City College, put together a most civilized progrham for his piano recital Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
Britain, France and Italy announced today their support of a Middle East settlement that would enable Israel to live peacefully within the frontiers she had before the 1967 war.

Harold Ballard, the president of the Toronto Maple Leafs, is an angry man. The 70-year-old- Ballard said of his losing hockey team "they should be ashamed to walk the streets of the city and face the people."

Kaleriya I. Fedicheva, a leading Leningrad ballerina who is trying to emigrate to join her American husband, said today that she had been badly beaten and kicked a few days ago by two unknown men in her apartment building.
About 2,900 striking workers have voted to end a widespread walkout against the General Telephone Company, a union official announced today. John Boswell, business representative for Loll 702.
The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the State Board of Higher Education had only limited authority to regulate outside employment by faculties of the state and county colleges.
Hofstra University announced today that it had decided to retain all major intercollegiate sports "as an integral part of a new athletic program that includes intramural and recreational programs."

Once one of America's most vibrant communities, Harlem now finds its growth and development in peril. That is the statistical picture that emerges in the findings of a task force oi the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, a community-based state agency involved in the redevelopment of the area.

A scheduled radio interview yesterday with Khalid Haled Al-Hasser, the Palestine Liberation Organization's representative to the United Nations, was prevented from taking place by the owners of the building in which the station leases space.
After nearly a year's deliberations the Senate Finance Committee voted today to approve the many sided trade reform bill, but the bill's final outcome in this Congress remained in doubt.

The overwhelming 64-to-17 vote for a six-year $11.8billion mass transit bill in the Senate conclusively demonstrates that the constituency for increased Federal aid for public transportation is nationwide and not just confined to New York and a few other large cities, That message and the sense of urgency it conveys was apparently not lost on the House Rules Committee, which, after stalling for months, cleared companion legislation yesterday.

The Ford Motor Company has increased the price of its average car by about $75, or 2 per cent, through a private letter sent to dealers. The increase is in addition to the average of approximately $900 added to new-car prices since the 1974 model year began.

Wait Frazier changed hats nighth, from rebounder to Scorer, and the Knicks attacked the Philadelphia 76ers from the backcourt. With the guards scoring 73 points, the Knicks ran up Weir fourth straight victory 1y defeating the 76ers, 10595.

If nothing else, there was color last night in Tully Hall, there the world premiere of Oliver Messiaen's "Des Cannons aux Etoiles" was celebrated. "Celebrated" is an apt word;

Hofstra University announced today that it had decided to retain all major intercollegiate sports "as an integral part of a new athletic program that includes intramural and recreational programs."
Lou Frankel, a public-relations executive with Doremus Co., died Tuesday of cancer at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 63 years old and lived in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

Legislation that would free any accused criminal in a Federal case who is not brought to trial within 100 days after his arrest was approved by the House Judiciary Committee today over scattered Republican opposition.
Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, proposed legislation today to reinstate standby authority to control wages, prices, profits, dividends and interest rates.
Underwriters for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $600-million financing said last night they expect to complete the terms of the offering.

The Northrop Corporation and a public interest law firm based here released today preliminary details of a settlement of a class-action shareholder lawsuit filed in Federal Court against Northrop for its illegal campaign contributions.
Community pressure has forced the local school board to outlaw an English textbook series containing profanity and selections from the writings of Eldridge Cleaver, Malcolm X and Woodie Guthrie.

A South Korean Marine officer was killed and five American military men seriously injured in the southern sector of the demilitarized zone this afternoon when an explosion occurred in a tunnel they were searching.

Only a few years after grades and academic success seemed to score somewhere below haircuts on a college student's scale of values, campuses across the country are worrying about a growing and often fearful obsession with grades.
Jess Solivan, vice president of the New York University Medical Center, was inaugurated last night as president of the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes of New York;
The Senate Rules Committee, due to vote today on the Vice-Presidential nomination of Nelson A. Rockefeller, delayed action until Friday because three of its members were unable to be present.

The first group of Representatives elect arrived on Capitol Hill today to learn the legislative facts of life and were quickly told that, in the judgment of their elders, the first and foremost fact, even in advance of being sworn in, was the need to win reelection.

More than 3,600 workers will lose their jobs before January in layoffs posted yesterday around the country. Auto companies and suppliers, continued to show some of the deepest losses of production and jobs.

In what was regarded as a setback for the nuclear industry and electric utilities, the Congressional Joint Atomic Energy Committee announced today that it had decided to postpone consideration of a bill extending the Federal nuclear insurance law.

A Manhattan lawyer who allegedly arranged sham marriages between illegal aliens and United States citizens so that the aliens might remain in this country as permanent residents was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury.

Horace Stoneham president and principal owner of the San Francisco Giants said today that if attendance did not improve next season he would give serious consideration to moving his baseball team again. The Giants drew slightly more than 500,000 fpns last season, the lowest total in the majors. and the lowest ever for a Giants' team either in New York or San Francisco.

The prices of the most common forms of energy for heating-natural gas and fuel oil-are higher in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area than in most of the rest of the United States, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.
Attorney General William B. Saxbe asked Congress today to legalize the publication and broadcasting of information about state-sanctioned lotteries.

The leadership of the United Mine Workers Union disclosed tonight that it had failed to win the first step in approval of the tentative labormanagement contract negotiated last week with the coal industry and would seek to return to the bargaining table.

Significant revisions have been agreed to in principle on the projected massive deal to restructure the deeply troubled Lockheed Aircraft Corporation with funds from Textron, Inc., according to industry sources.
The trustees of the New. York Cultural Center at Columbus Circle are actively seeking a buyer for the opulent marble building, erected in 1964 by Huntington Hartford.

William R. Phillips, the rogue cop who was a star witness at the Knapp Commission hearings into police corruption here, was convicted yesterday in his second trial of slaying a pimp and a young prostitute and of attempting to murder a customer on Christmas Eve, 1968.
Wilfred J. Lewis, a trainer whose main racing activity takes place in New Jersey, received a 30-day suspension yesterday by the stewards at Aqueduct for a violation of drug rules.
Ken Buchanan of Scotland, the European Lightweight champion, stopped Winston Noel of New York in the second round of a scheduled 10-round bout tonight.

Following several assaults and half a dozen incidents of exibitionism on the Princeton university campus a group of students here have formed a free escort service for women who are afraid to walk alone at night.

The Boston Celtics placed Dave Cowens on the active list yesterday and said there was a possibility the 6-foot9-inch center might play tonight in Boston against the Phoenix Suns.

President Ford visited the elegant Golden Pavilion, tried his hand at an ancient Japanese stringed instrument and dined with geisha yesterday in this ancient Japanese imperial capital.

A blue Michigan flag flapped in the crisp, late-autumn breeze above the Ohio House of Representatives today signaling some early arrivals from the North for the Ohio State-Michigan football game Saturday.

People like Herbie Hancock, Donald Byrd, Chick Corea and Josef Zawinul have discovered that a deliberate simplification of their music can reap satisfying financial rewards from the progressive rock audience, and perhaps artistic rewards as well.

With almost reckless assurance, NBC seems to have entered direct competition with the films of David Lean. Last week the network offered a new version of "Brief Encounter" and wound up on the side of unmitigated disaster in inevitable comparisons with the old film version. Tonight at 8 it tackles "Great Expectations." The comparisons can be considerably kinder.

With the Christmas shopping season starting, it is welcome news that United Parcel Service-and not just the Post Office-is here to stay. A compromise formula recommended by W. J. Usery Jr., chief Federal mediator, has at last ended the twelve-week U.P.S. strike on terms that will keep the company in operation here.

An expert on United States capital markets told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that preservation of the auction market system for corporate securities had little or nothing to do with a thriving New York Stock Exchange or a viable broker-dealer community.
The increase in the consumer price index announced by the Labor Department today means the nation's 665,000 auto workers will share in a record $4-million-a-week pay raise beginning next month.

Consumer prices showed another large increase in October, though less than in most other months this year, the Labor Department reported today. The increase in the Consumer Price Index last month was nine-tenths of 1 per cent both before and after adjustment for normal seasonal changes in some prices.

The General Motors Corporation announced further layoffs today and the Ford Motor Company reduced the price of its subcompact by $66 in moves to fight the slump in car sales and reduce large inventories of unsold cars.

Plans to impose a statewide property tax to resolve New Jersey's school financing problem floundered at a conference of the Senate Democratic majority today as legislative leaders predicted that it would be rejected decisively in an informal vote on Monday.

A man with a toy pistol held a senior official of the Mexican Embassy hostage for one hour here today before being overpowered by policemen, a police spokesman said. No one was hurt in the incident in the embassy, the spokesman added.

Controversial measure enabling New Jersey residents to take alleged environmental polluters into court was given its final legislative approval in the State Senate today, despite broad opposition by industry and organized labor.

After taking a giant step forward of 10 cents a pound in the previous five trading sessions, the March delivery contract in world sugar futures declined the daily 2-cel.s-apound limit yesterday.

James W. Morrison, a silentfilms actor, died Nov. 15, his 86th birthday, at a nursing home here. Mr. Morrison graduated from the University of Chicago and enrolled in the American Academy of Dramatic Arts.
A 16-foot jumper by Donnie Freeman with 20 seconds to play clinched a 116110 triumph for the San Antonio Spurs tonight over the New York Nets in the American Basketball Association.

Greece got her first elected Government today after seven years of military rule. Premier Constantine Caramanlis, 67 years old, and his Cabinet of 19 Ministers and 16 Under Secretaries were sworn in to replace the caretaker Government that supervised last Sunday's elections-the first in a decade.

The city's Board of Health acted yesterday to strengthen the protection of children against lead poisoning. It did so by voting at its monthly meeting to reduce by one-third the point at which lead in the blood is considered potentially dangerous.

Bombs destroyed two crowded pubs in the heart of Birmingham tonight, killing 17 persons and injuring about 120. Many of them were teen-agers. It was the worst attack in the series of bombings that have hit Britain over the past two years, an offshoot of the violence in Northern Ireland.

To their delight, because they want to keep the competition going the officers of the New York Yacht Club Ass found four challenges for the America's Cup when they opened the envelopes earlier this week, 60 days after the end of the last defense of yachting's prestigious trophy.

RANGOON, Burma--A 6-year-old child was killed the other day when he let go of his mother's hand and fell through a hole in the floor of a moving bus. It was a freakish accident, but in the minds of some Burmese it was just another sign that the steady deterioration of the economy in the last decade has brought the country to a desperate point.
S. Everett Gleason, a former State Department official who shared the Bancroft Prize in History in 1954, died Wednesday of lung cancer at his home in Washington. He was 69 years old.

O'Keeffe, the Republican Mayor of Plainfield, a lot of fun, considerable ribbing and some painful moments.
Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey yesterday announced a 14-member group of advisers who will aid him in preparing a package of consumer-protection legislation.

Even before delivering his formal State-of-the-State message, Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey has made a strong first move to put into practice at least one promise he made during the campaign-improvement in the courts of New York State. By naming an independent commission that will help screen candidates for the bench as well as advise him on legislation, he has signaled the State Legislature that he is serious about raising judicial standards.

European track and field officials are launching an all-out war against anabolic steriods, drugs used to build muscle. Athletes will be tested at all major European meets in 1975 and disqualified if the tests prove positive, the European Athletic Association announced yesterday.

That was when Mr. Mennin's style was formed. and he has never departed far from it.

Four of the most versatile jazz pianists in town-Roland Hanna, Hank Jones, Dick Hyman and Marian McPartlandput their eight hands together in a set of performances at Michael's Pub on Wednesday evening that marked the first public appearance of the Jazz Piano Quartet..

A defense lawyer warned yesterday that the Justice Deapartment's six-year-old antitrust action against the International Business Machines Corporation would face further delays of six to nine months if a Government motion to amend its Complaint is granted.

Joseph F. Crangle, the Democratic state chairman, will announce his resignation today, effective in mid-December. The resignation confirmed reports that he had been pressed to quit by Government-elect Hugh L. Carey, who is supporting Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic leader for the post. Mr. Cunningham was an early Carey backer. Mr. Crangle initially supported Howard J. Samuels for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

A 42-year old expatriate Cuban from Miami described by Federal authorities as a major international narcotics smuggler has been convicted in absentia by a Brooklyn trial jury. He disappeared in the middle of the trial.

Senator Jacob K. Javits will reportedly seek election in January to the third-ranking post in the Senate Republican leadership in an effort to moderate the party's conservative image and viewpoint.

Hicksville managed only 61 yards total offense and five first downs today and succumbed to the power of the Holy Trinity ground game, 31-0. Holy Trinity, directed by Tim Timlin, the senior quarterback, worked for 329 yards, 298 on the ground. Timlin was 3 for 5 for 31 yards in the air.

College students who only a few years ago seemed to care little for grading systems, the traditional measure of academic success, are again competing hard for top grades, a New York Times survey has shown. And educators are worried about some of the side effects.
The National Front for the Liberation of Angola, one of three competing guerrilla movements here, has emerged in recent years as this Portuguese colony's most powerful African force.

Penn capitalized on two fumbles and a pass interference penalty today and defeated Dartmouth, 27-20. The Quakers clinched third place in the Ivy League. Penn rallied for three touchdowns in the second half with a 4-2-1 won-lost-tied mark, Dartmouth finished with 3-4.

The judge who placed former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew on probation says it was more important to get him out of office than into jail. He said that officials involved in the case had feared that a trial might end in a hung jury and divide the nation.

Ralph Capone, who had national notoriety when he was a member of the crime syndicate run by his brother Al Capone during the Prohibition era of the nineteen-twenties and early thirties, died Friday at a nursing home in Hurley, Wis. He was 81 years old.

Although racial tensions in the United States Virgin Islands seem to have eased, tourists are still avoiding this resort area.

The engagement of Betty Jane Harris to Louis Douglas Barba, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Barba of Short Hills, N. J., and Stowe, Vt., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Harris Jr. of White Plains.

For the second time in four months, Peru's military rulers have resorted to drastic action to silence criticism of their policies. They have closed three magazines, exiled ten journalists and arrested five leading members of the Lima Bar Association, including its president. For good measure, they have ousted 137 American Peace Corps volunteers, who had been working mostly in forestry, agriculture and education.

Merley Calleghan, the Canadian novelist, has written a book titled "Winter," with a lyric celebration of what he calls "the winter warmth of home," The took, full of pictures of ice and snow, is going on sale across the country just as the people of this vast frozen land settle into their cold-weather ritual.

Mark Fellers, the Clemson quarterback scored three touchdowns and Ken Calicutt, a halfback, rushed for 197 yards to lead the Tigers to a 39-21 victory over its old intrastate football rival, South Carolina, today.
Jimmy Connors and Arthur Aase set up an all-American men's singles final with victories today in the $100,000 South African tennis championships. The final is Monday.

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar returned to the Milwaukee Bucks line-up last night and the Knicks' five - game winning streak disappeared. The overpowering center, sidelined for 16' games with a broken bone in his right hand and cornea damage to his right eye, scored 17 points, grabbed 10 rebounds and blocked four shots in the Bucks' 90-72 victory at Madison Square Garden.

Sirica's courtroom with earphones clamped to their heads and listened over the static to the scratchy but familiar voice of the former President.

WASHINGTON--The percentage depletion allowance for petroleum producers may be in actual danger of repeal for the first time since it was enacted 56 years ago. The House Ways and Means Committee, by a one-vote margin, approved a bill last week that would end the depletion allowance, effective next year, for the larger oil producers, and in 1979 for the smaller ones and for companies operating on the Alaska North Slope.

Chilly November nights are owl nights. Not even the early-nesting great horned owl will be courting till January, so he and the barred owl and the little screech owl are merely announcing their presence. This is their time to hoot, or screech, or yammer. There is no such thing as a hoot owl, of course, but both the great horned owl, he with a five-foot wingspread, and the slightly smaller barred owl do hoot.

To the Editor: Administration spokesmen, particularly Secretaries Morton and Simon, are continuing to push for an increase in the tax on gasoline. This manifestly unfair measure, which would penalize most those least able to pay, is extolled as a panacea which will solve the oil shortage, provide funds for jobs for unemployed, lick inflation and reverse the recession.

U Thant, the quiet Burmese schoolteacher who became the third Secretary General of the United Nations and held that post longer than any other person, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 65 years old.

The State Commission of Investigation charged yesterday that the City's criminal-justice system had become a jumble of ill-coordinated and inefficient agencies, each pushing its own budget and interests with no regard for any over-all plan to cope with increasing crime.

Richard E. Wiley, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has proposed that the three television networks adopt a joint policy that would restrict adult-oriented programs to the later hours of the evening and include a comprehensive warning to viewers that a show might be unsuitable for children.

Plans for a housing project considered by the city to be the keystone of plans to revitalize downtown Brooklyn are being revised because of soaring construction costs, a state official said yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that its members lost a total of $34.1-million during the third quarter of 1974, in contrast to an aggregate profit of $19.9-million a year earlier.

The value of trade between China and the United States is going to be least $300-million less this year than expected as a result of cancellations and postponements by the Chinese of a series of grain and soybean purchases.

Metro-Goldwn-Mayer, Inc., announced yesterday in Culver City, Calif., that it intended to buy 2 million shares of its own common stock but would not convert to a private company. A politically active Hudson County park policeman, who suffered an apparent heart attack late Friday after being reassigned to foot patrol duty, remained in critical condition today,
President and Mrs. Ford will celebrate Thanksgiving Thursday with a family dinner and a brunch with members of Mr. Ford's Grand Rapids, Mich., high school football team of the nineteen thirties.

The Senate Armed Services Committee decided today not to summon Gen. George S. Brown, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, for an explanation of his critical comments about Jews in the United States.

Francoise Giroud, France's Secretary of State for the Condition of Women, yesterday turned down an invitation to address a meeting of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization "in view of the decisions taken by UNESCO, shocking in my eyes, with regard to Israel."
The State Public Advocate launched a legal attack today on, seashore areas that are closed to the public, by filing suit against private beaches in Bav Head.

MYRON, By Gore Vidal. 244 pages, Random House $6.95. Predictably, "Myron" is to its predecessor, "Myra Breckinridge," what your usual movie sequel is to its precursor. A movie called "The Fly" comes to mind for some reason--an understated yet powerful sci-fi thriller about a man who through a mix up with a transformation machine exchanges not his gender but his head with a common house.

A former military policeman and a teen-aged girl were sentenced in Federal Court today on separate charges stemming from the kidnapping last March of John Calzadilla, 8 years old, and the disappearance of a $50,000 ransom raised by the boy's father.

A Federal district judge today ordered that bribery charges against John B. Connaly be tried separately from other Federal charges against the former Texas Governor.

A new wave of worker discontent is knocking some of the barnacles off a labor movement sunk in bureaucratic smugness. Resolute insurgents, using the union-democracy guarantees of the Landrum-Griffin Labor Reform Act of 1959, have begun to demolish citadels of trade union autocracyfirst in coal and now in steel, where a 36-year-old rebel has just shattered machine control over the union's biggest district.

Sales of new cars continued to remain in a severe slump in the last 10day selling period, industry figures showed yesterday. Commenting on the results, Henry Ford 2d, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, predicted that the sales decline "can get worse."

Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton told California's two Senators today that he had decided to postpone until February the hearings on the Administration's accelerated leasing of offshore oil lands.

Weekly steel production has begun to reflect the effects of the coal strike. Figures released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute placed output for the week ended Nov. 23 at 2,642,000 tons, the lowest level for any week this year.

Premier Kakuel Tanaka, facing alleged financial scandals and record laws in popularity polls, announced his resignation today. Mr. Tanaka officially informed leaders of the governing Liberal-Democratic party and then the Cabinet of a decision he had already confided to them. He will remain in office until the' Liberal-Democratic party, a conservative grouping, picks his successor, a process expected to take a week or -10 days.

"I'm a sheep in wolf's clothing," the President fatuously said, adding: "I told the First Secretary I'm going to get him one." That is one American promise to the Soviets that ought not to be honored.

Dr. Roscoe P. Kandle, who as New Jersey Commissioner of Health from 1959 t 1970 was active in combating air and water pollution, died yesterday in the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research. He was 65 years old and lived in Trenton.

A major northern New Jersey realtor agreed in Federal court in Newark yesterday to submit to supervision of its rental practices to insure fairness to black applicants. Paul Schmidt, owner of the Henpal and Mipal realty companies, which control seven apartment houses in predominantly white Bergen County, agreed to explain the specific reasons that black applicants for apartments, in the next three years are rejected.

An American aircraft carrier has entered the Persian Gulf for the first time in 26 years, the Pentagon announced today. The dismissals retrench ments and spending cuts Mayor Beame ordered last Friday in a move he called "the tightest austerity program undertaken by the city since the Depression" are designed to reduce a projected deficit of $430-million in New York's 1974-75 expense budget.

Robert A. Goeller, president of Hatzel Buehler, electrical contractors, 420 Lexington Avenue, died Friday in Mamaroneck, N.Y., where he lived. He was 84 years old and also had a home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

Katherine Campbell Barclay, wife of Dr. Gordon L. Barclay, managing director of the Research Foundation for Mental Hygiene in Albany, died of cancer yesterday at their home, in Loudonville, N.Y. She was 57 years old.

Early this year the group of old-music experts known as the New York Pro Miisica went out of existence after 22 years, pleading financial distress. The news left many admirers bereft, and it upset some Pro Musica members who felt the, group should be allowed to survive.

A surge in exports swung the United States trade balance into a small surplus in October after five months of occasionally large deficits, the Commerce Department reported today.

To the Editor: Mayor Beame's proposal for housing in New York City deserves a polite chuckle and then consignment to the scrap heap in advance. It is disappointing indeed, because it is based on a vision of city government as a "moving force," on elusive or nonexistent funds and on a startling disregard for the resources we already have apart from government. Proposals like these will only compound. our problems.

Earl Albion Hughes, retired turf-racing columnist for Cue and Sports Illustrated magazines, died Monday at his home in Washington, at the age of 82. Mr. Hughes had also been a reporter for The Philadelphia Record.
Criticism of President Ford's tentative arms control agreement with the Soviet Union has begun to develop here, and some officials predict that the accord may provoke a fight in Congress.

Fists flew again at a New York Giants' practice, but the chief concern today was a bruised right knee that may sideline Leon McQuay for Sunday's game against the Bears in Chicago.

About 100 policemen, a magistrate and seven students were injured today in India's northern state of Punjab when the police clashed with 6,000 student demonstrators, the Press Trust of India news agency reported.
James P. McGuire, senior vice president of Cushman Wakefield, the real-estate management concern, died Tuesday. He was 64 years old and lived at 31 Dunhill Road, New Hyde Park, L.I.

Last April Mrs. Joyce Arkhurst had breast cancer surgery. The news from her doctor was extremely hopeful. Her tumor, a tiny, very early cancer detectable only by X-ray, was among the most curable, and no further treatment was deemed necessary.
The Ford Motor Company today announced layoffs for 25,200 more workers next week because of the sale slump.

WASHINGTON--Whatever our difficulties, and they are many, Americans have one overwhelming reason to be thankful this year: Richard Nixon is out of the White House. The new tapes played at the Watergate cover-up trial have added chilling depths to the knowledge of what we escaped. It was not just deception and abuse of power but conscious criminality. It was that rarity in high office, genuine evil.

Representatives of six community boards in Manhattan yesterday criticized the Beame administrations proposal for a new $1.1-billion West Side Highway, and some said they dubted that agreement by the highway planners on a plan would ever emerge.
Eight fire companies in four boroughs with be eliminated as part of a cutback in services by the Fire Department to save $8.3-million, Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan announced yesterday.

School Chancellor Irving Anker said yesterday that he had received a report documeeting a swollen payroll, fiscal mismanagement and a possible $1-million deficit in Community School District 9 in the Bronx and that he probably would take over management of the district.

Shafiq al-Hout, who heads the Palestine Liberation Organization's office in Beirut, announced yesterday that the organization had arrested 26 persons in Lebanon and other Arab countries on suspicion of involvement in the hijacking of a British airliner to Tunis last weekend.
More than 12 tons of undelivered mail, some dating to 1967 and most of it advertising material, have been found in a postman's attic.

George M. Steinbrenner 3d, principal owner of the New York Yankees, was suspended for two years yesterday by Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn because of his Federal conviction for illegal contributions to political campaigns.

The Venezuelan Government announced late yesterday that American-owned iron ore companies operating here would be nationalized on Jan. 1.
Mary Jansen, 9 years old, lay alongside the bodies of her slain family for nearly two days. She believed she Would also die of the bullet wounds inflicted by her mother.

The Dow Chemical Company said today it was awarding five shares of its common stock to each of its approximately 4,000 employes who worked during a six-month strike by the Dow's factory in Midland, Mich.

MY PEOPLE have grown weary of hearing the songs of Thanksgiving. My people have grown weary of looking back at the first winter when the white man came singing songs of praise to a white man's God who had blessed the new experiment in the "bleak wilderness" where no man had set foot.

Joseph Monserrat, a member of the Board of Education, attnded meetings here and in Puerto Rico involving a $211,660 board contract with a manpower training company while the company was paying him as a public relations consultant, according to an account yesterday by a board administrator.
John D. deButts, chairman of the United States Industrial Payroll Savings Committee, has announced that the 1974 campaign has exceed its goal of 2.4 million new or increased savers.

Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned Congress today of a "permanent decline of our nation's economic and political power" unless world oil prices could be forced down, mainly through a major new oil conservation effort of "austerity" proportions in the United States.

Fourteen prominent Spanish politicians detained yesterday in a apparent police crackdown on center-left efforts to set up a united front were released today, the police said. Detained on a charge of illegal assembly, the 14 appeared individually before a magistrate today.

The Illinois Supreme Court upheld today the obscenity convictions of adult bookstore operators in Moline and Rockland, ending a five-year court battle that had gone to the United States Supreme Court and back.
More than a third of the Senate today called on three Government agencies to investigate the sharp rise in the price of Sugar.
Ferguson Jenkins, who went to Texas, and Jim Wynn, who left the state, were voted by their peers as baseball's comeback players of the year.

Edward S. silver, a member of the State Commission of Investigation and a former Brooklyn District Attorney, died yesterday at Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 76 years old and lived at 222 East 17th Street in Brooklyn.

Joseph Satkin, the Passaic landlord convicted in September of killing a woman and three children in a fire last year at three of his buildings, was sentenced today to life in prison by Judge Edward F. Johnson in Superior Court.

Dr. Clair E. Turner, a pioneer in public health, died yesterday, -apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Arlington, Mass.

A trio of Newark police detectives learned a great deal about rules and regulations when they were members, of the Barringer High football team in Newark about 25 years ago. They became pretty fair football players, too, helping their school to a tie for the City League championship in 1950 before continuing their education and athletic careers in college. Afterward, they began their days as law enforcers.

Jeannette Fields, who, with Jack Fields her late husband, operated resorts in Ferndale, N. Y., and Lakewood, N. J., died yesterday in Los Angeles. She was 84 years old.
