The index of leading economic indicators plunged to its lowest point ever in September, and is in its longest sustained decline in five years, the Commerce Department said today.

The owners of 614 of the 632 luxury apartments in the year-old Winston Tower 200 condominium on the Palisades in Bergen County overlooking the Hudson River here last night voted to assess themselves "in excess of $5,000" to finance a lawsuit against the builders and sellers of the high-rise apartment units.

Troops were reported movingg into the troubled northern Ethiopian province of Eritrea today. The motive for the troop movement was know only to the 120 soldiers who, control this East Afiican nation and who on Saturday ordered the death of their own leaders and of 59 prisoners ranging from noblemen to an army private.

One of the world's most liberal divorce laws, a nofault arrangement that requires only a year's separation, was passed by the Australian Senate tonight and was con.sidered certain to go into effect throughout the country.

Tape of St. John's vs. St. Mary's (Nova Scotia) game. (Television--Channel 67 9 P.M. FOOTBALL C. W. Post vs. Hofstra, at Greenvale, L.I., 11 A.M. Iona Prep vs. New Rochelle High, at Mt. Vernon, N.Y., 10 A.M. (Television -- Channel 11, 10 A.M.) (Radio -WVOX, 10 A.M.)

The chief prosecutor at the Watergate cover-up trial wound up a long and often bitter crossexamination of John N. Mitchell today by charging that the former Attorney General had "stonewalled" and hidden the truth.
Gigi Laguesse, owner of the Ranch Restaurant on Main Street, distributed free Thanksgiving dinners today, just as she said she would, and promised to "do it again next year if I can afford it."

For the first time, women will serve on the 100-member Archdiocesan Council of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America. The appointments were recently announced by Archbishop Iakovos, Primate of the church.

Perqueta Courtney, a former musical-comedy actress, died Tuesday in the De Witt Nursing Home. She was 80 years old. Miss Courtney, the widow of Reggie Childs, the band leader, had leading roles in "Tumble Tumblee" "Merry Merry"
Why is a group of Catholic school basketball player going to spend Christmas in Israel? Partly to play basket ball; mostly to learn. Bishop Ford of Brooklyn will leave for Israel Dec.

Following are excerpts from the ruling yesterday by Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn suspending George M. Steinbrenner 3d, principal owner of the New York Yankees, from taking part in the team's affairs for two years:

Secretary of State Kissinger today resumed talks with Chinese leaders Spokesmen said the five-hour discussion was held in "a very good atmosphere." Mr. Kissinger has spent a total of nine hours in meetings since he arrived Monday for his seventh visit to China. Most of the talks have been with Deputy Premier Teng Hsiao-ping and the new Foreign Minister, Chiao Kuan-hua.

There are now only six more shopping performances before "The Nutcracker." In other words the New York City Ballet is coming to the end of its third week of repertory before the Christmas spate of 40 performances of "The Nutcracker."
The engagement of Lady Leonora Grosvenor, elder daughter of the Duke and Duchess of Westminster, to the fifth Earl of Lichfield, also known as the photographer Patrick Lichfield, was announced today.
Wisconsin's law banning the sale of contraceptives to unmarried persons has been struck down by a three-judge Federal panel.

Commissioner Tedd Munchak of the American Basketball Association, incensed by incidents of extreme physical violence in the league this season, issued a strong warning yesterday regarding further unsportsmanlike conduct. In a memorandum to all general managers, coaches and referees, Munchak said in part: "You are hereby given official warning that this office will not tolerate unsportmanlike conduct of coaches, players or any personnel of the club toward any other players, coaches, fans or officials."

Pionner 11 plunged into and out of Jupiter's magnetic field today. As the spacecraft sped toward its Monday encounter with the planet, the Pioneer entered the field, only to lose it five hours later and 120,000 miles closer to Jupiter.

Manhattan District Attorney Richard H. Kuh yesterday shouted in anger at Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts for the justice's decision to grant a postponement in a criminal case until January, when Robert M. Morgenthau, the newly elected District Attorney, assumes office.
The McCrory Corporation omitted its regular dividend of 30 cents a share for its fourth quarter, it was reported yesterday after the board's action late Tuesday.

Through a day of early frustration with highly regarded horses, Frank Martin saddled a Winner at Aqueduct yesterday with what he considered the "least likely to succeed." After seeing such well-played charges of his such as Princess M. L., Rube the Great and Accipiter failing to win, Martin watched Syrian Star take the last race on the card.

While two dissenting members contended that the Planning Commission was approving a "fiction," the commission approved yesterday by a vote of 4 to 2 plans for a.controversial 30-story mixed-use tower in the Lincoln Square Special District.

BAYONNE -- Passers-by would have thought there was a wedding reception or anniversary celebration at the Gallagher's last weekend, but the party was just a gathering of neighbors welcoming their former Representative home form prison.

The Wilrttemberg Chamber Orchestra in its first performance here on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall was somewhat thrown into the shadow by the trumpet pyrotechnics of the guest soloist, Maurice Andre, an astounding virtuoso with few peers in his craft, Nevertheless,

Shafiq al-Hout, who heads the Palestine Liberation Organization's office in Beirut, announced yesterday that the organization had arrested 26 persons in Lebanon and other Arab countries on suspicion of involvement in the hijacking of a British airliner to Tunis last weekend. He said at a news conference that they would be tried in open court and that such incidents harmed the Palestine cause. [Page 1. Columns 1.2.]
CHICAGO (NL)-Named Irv Noren as thirdbase coach. OAKLAND (AL) - Unconditionally released Dal Maxvill, infielder; assigned Gaylen Pitts, infielder, and Leon Hopten, pitcher, T to Tucson.
Hundreds of riot policemen smothered attempts by anti-Government Roman Catholic demonstrators to march from outlying parishes to downtown Saigon early today.

The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' economic commission meeting here is almost certain to recommend an increase in oil prices to compensate for inflation, sources close to the meeting said.

As the significance of the world food crisis becomes more apparent to wellfed Americans, the call for people to cut down on consumption of meat, especially grain-fed beef, is increasingly being voiced by citizens' groups, religious and humanitarian organizations and some food and nutrition experts.

Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard said yesterday that he was so encouraged by the early results shown by the patient in whom he implanted a second heart that, despite criticism from some surgeons, he was eager to do the same operation on a waiting patient "today, tomorrow" or as soon as a suitable donor was found.

What was Red Kelly doing. with that bullwhip? The coach of the Toronto Maple Leafs carried it throughout the game against the New York Rangers last night at Madison Square Garden, but obviously didn't use it enough. The Leafs lost, 4-1.

BAYONNE -- Passers-by would have thought there was a wedding reception or anniversary celebration at the Gallagher's last weekend, but the party was just a gathering of neighbors welcoming their former Representative home from prisoff.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday ended their seven-session losing streak and finished with sharp gains in slower trading.

The strains between the Government of President, Valery Giscard d'Estaing and the news media grew today when Premier-Jacques Chirac said he had ordered the police to oust striking newsmen from the national radio-television system's headquarters.

Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said today he hoped that the committee's hearings on Nelson A. Rockefeller's nomination to be Vice President would be completed by the end of next week and that the nomination would come to a vote in the House the week of Dec. 16.

All over the world, consumers have encountered a mysterious legend on bakery, pasta and snack products: "Reg. Penna. Dept. Agr." It means registered with the Pennsylvania Department of Agriculture. But why Pennsylvania?
The Soviet Union is preparing to deploy its first multiplewarhead nuclear missiles in remodeled' underground firing sites within a few months, the Pentagon said today.
John Newcombe and Chris Evert won semifinal matches today in a $100,000 professional tennis tournament.
D. Louis Tonti, former executive director of the Garden State Parkway, was released from a Federal prison camp today after serving 20 months for his role in an alleged extortion plot.

Reggie Leach and Bobby Clarke proved to be the key combination tonight as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 6-2, and held the lead in their division of the National Hockey League.
A Collingswood, N.J., woman who last week lost custody of her 6-year-old daughter to foster parents has been charged with kidnapping the girl from a Philadelphia schoolyard.

Charles Rumford Walker, a retired Yale University official, died Tuesday at his home in Wellfleet, Mass. He was 81 years old. Mr. Walker, who graduated from Yale in 1916, became secretary of the Yale. University Council in 1942.

Contrary to -a popular misconception, there are stretches of genuine wilderness east of the Mississippi. None is of the size of the mountain and desert wilderness of the West. Some were scarred by lumbering early in the century and are only now returning to their natural condition. But each has its unique qualities, some are spectacularly beautiful, and all are worth saving as population densities increase and the man-made environment sprawls ever outward.

Negotiations between the West German banking consortium Hans Gerling and the Zurich Insurance Group in an attempt to avoid the Bankhaus I. D. Herstatt settlement proceedings turning into a bankruptcy case are continuing.

Modupe Abigboye, a street trader, who normally pays little attention to Government decrees, greeted the recent announcement of a free program of education for elementary pupils with some interest, and with mixed emotions as well.

Congress has directed the Federal Communications Commission to report by Dec. 31 specific actions the agency is taking, or planning to take, to protect children from television programs containing violent, obscene or indecent materials. The assignment is fraught with complications, because the television industry is not homogenous, standards for programs that are suitable for children are elusive and the power of the F.C.G. to enforce discretion is limited.

Terrence McNally and Miguel Pinero, the playwrights, have been selected by the Dramatists Guild to share the 1973-74 Elizabeth Hull-Kate Warriner award. The cash prize of $7,000 will be divided equally between them for their plays, "Short Eyes" by Mr. Pinero, and "Bad Habits" by Mr. McNally.

James F. Regan, President of the Board of Education, said yesterday that the board was willing to trim $45-million from its $1-billion budget as its share of Mayor Beame's efforts to reduce the city's huge budget deficit.

A number of layoffs, particularly in the electronics industry, were announced yesterday by a variety of companies. The Celanese Corporation said that, because of "a sharp reduction in demand for textile products and in order to maintain tight control over inventories," its domestic fiber group "furloughed about 3,300 employes during the past month."

Some 330,000 pounds of foreign lobster tails will be auctioned Tuesday after sitting frozen for two years in a Boston warehouse. The tails were seized by the Customs Service when agents contended that they had been caught off the Bahamas

The Ballet Theater Foundation, parent unit of the American Ballet Theater, has assured the New York State Council on the Arts that it will follow the recommendations of a recent audit by State Controller Arthur Levitt that questioned various aspects of the organization's fiscal management.

Chief Judge Charles D. Brei tel of the state Court of Ap peals received yesterday the Emory Buckner Medal for distinguished public service from the Federal Bar Council, a group of lawyers who-practice in the Federal courts.
Louis B. Russell, an Indianapolis schoolteacher, who underwent heart transplant surgery more than six years ago and who has been the world's longest.
Fists flew again at a New York Giants' practice, but the chief concern today was a bruised right knee that may sideline Leon McQuay for Sunday's game against the Bears in Chicago.
President Ford's popularity has fallen to its lowest point to date, in part because of discontent over the economy, according to a Gallup Poll made public today.

In Domestic Relations Court yesterday, Judge Nanette Dembitz ruled in favor of Representative Mario Biaggi, the Bronx Democrat, in a paternity suit brought by Bunnye Hearne, a volunteer worker in his mayoral campaign last year.
Thirteen years ago Burton N. Pugach was convicted of hiring three thugs to blind his girlfriend, Linda Riss, so that "no one else will want vou."

For the jurors who have been squestered for 42 days in the Watergate cover-up trial, Thanksgiving is to be a daylong reunion with their families under the close watch of deputy United States marshals.

The United Nations General Assembly today addressed a "solemn appeal" to Ethiopia's military rulers to spare the lives of detained persons. During an Assembly debate preceding the decision to send an urgent message to Ethiopia,

Attorney General William B. Saxbe has approved the first joint operating agreement between separately owned newspapers permitted under the four-yearold Newspaper Preservation Act, the Justice Department said yesterday.

With more than two dozen ski areas in the Northeast ready to welcome holiday crowds this weekend with limited snow covered terrain, ski-shop dealers in the metropolitan area showed optimism yesterdayover the prospects for a profitable season. "Until the end of last week," said Otto Hajek, the operator of the Sportiva shops in Yorkville and midManhattan, "we were selling mostly tennis equipment. Honestly, I'm not kidding. In fact, we're still selling it.
NBC-TV Tuesday night made a late substitution of an 8:30 movie because the originally scheduled film was deemed inappropriate to follow a children's special.
Two young airmen convicted of murder refused today to select the manner of their execution-guns or the rope-and were sentenced by a judge to be shot at sunrise, Jan. 21.

Four of the 24 crewmen were reported missing when a Panamanian freighter sank off Okinawa today. The other crewmen, all Chinese from Taiwan, were rescued by a Japanese patrol ship, the Maritime Safety Agency reported.

Bache Co., Inc., the brokerage house, said today that its first priority in the new year would be to strengthen its 2,000-person sales force -- if possible through the acquisition of other brokerage firms.

When Americans sit down today to devour millions of turkeys, they will unknowingly help alleviate the international food crisis-at least for one day. The gobbler, it seems, could just turn out to be the food conservationist's ally. For every pound of grain he eats, the turkey produces a pound of meat.

"The people are the ones that are going to be losing," said Fireman Richard Driscoll of Engine Company 91-2, yesterday, as he leaned against a fire truck in the East Harlem station his company shares with Engine 911. The city, he added "is playing with their lives."

Manton B. Metcalf Jr., senior partner of Metcalf Bros. Co., a woolen and worsted concern, died Tuesday. He was 81 years old and lived here and in Rumson, N. J Mr. Metcalf, a 1916 graduate of Harvard, was a lieutenant in aviation in World War I.
Federal authorities announced yesterday that they had broken up a major gun-distributing ring with the arrest of l0 suspects accused of stealing gun parts from legitimate manufacturers,
The Junior League of the City of New York honored 32 debutante provisional members at its annual ball in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom last night. The young women were presented to Mrs.
A $2.50 gold piece about the size of a dime but valued at $75 to $85 has been found by a city employee in a Manhattan parking meter.

"When the generals first came to power," said a banker surveying six years of the leftist revolution proclaimed by the Peruvian military Government, "they thought they could sweep away everything and rebuild a new economic system overnight.
The Little Hoover Commission, which had been appointed by Governor Wilson to make an efficiency study of state gov ernment, resigned today without making any recommendations.

A recount of votes cast on Nov. 5 in the United States Senate race in New Hampshire showed today that the Democrat, John A. Durkin, bad won by 10 votes over the Republican, Representative Louis C. Wyman.

Four children died today in a fire at their grandparents' home. The children's mother, Mary Ann Stovell, was at work and had left her children with her parents. The four were identified as Laron, 4 years old; Denice, 3; Larry, 2, and Randy, 1.

Charles W. Pettengill Sr., a senior partner in the law firm here of Hirschberg, Pettengill, Strong Nagle, died last night at Greenwich Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 156 Overlook Drive here.
The stock market closed with modest gains yesterday in moderate pre-holiday trading, though some late selling erased many earlier advances.

King Hussein said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization had made, but failed to keep, a secret pledge to end its opposition to him. He still plans, however, to turn over to the guerrilla group responsibility for the West Bank of the Jordan River, he said.
The Communist party leader in the American republic, where a series of nationalist trials has been stages lately, has been removed from his post.

The Appellate Division upheld today the stringent drug law pushed through the Legislature in 1973 by Goy. Nelson A. Rockefeller. The court said the law did not violate the "cruel and unusual" punishment provisions of the Eighth Amentment to the Federal Constitution.
Bake McBride, the wingfooted center fielder of the St. Louis Cardinals, was named yesterday as the National League rookie of the year by the Baseball Writers Association of America.
Legislation to ban the Irish Republican Army and curb the spread of terrorism from Northern Ireland to Britain began its passage through Parliament today.

The Christmas shopping season begins officially tomorrow, with its expected surge in consumer buying. A large part, of course, will be transacted via credit--more than half of all department and specialty store volume is handled through charge accounts-so it is important to understand how charges on credit purchases are determined.

The Bohack Corporation, the New York supermarket chain now operating under the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, yesterday reported a sharply higher loss of $45-million in the 26 weeks ended July 29, against. a loss of $711,000 in the same 1973 period. Sales in the 26 weeks declined to $157.7-million from $164.7-million.
Two naked sunbathers were arrested yesterday on Venice Beach by policemen who announced a get-tough policy to enforce the city's new antinudity ordinance.

A Federal drug enforcement agent who was paralyzed from the armpits down in a shootout during an abortive drug purchase in New York City two years ago received title to a custom-built home near here today.

Those who need answers to difficult questions in the minor problems of bridge and the major problems of life can usually get help if they know where to go. Concerned with the narrow line between failure and success in both areas is Boris Koytchou of New York,
Bake McBride, the wingfooted center fielder of the St. Louis Cardinals, was named yesterday as the National League rookie of the year by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

A Baltimore engineer who allegedly made kickbacks indirectly to N. Dale Anderson, former Baltimore County Executive, was charged today in Federal District Court herewith filing a false corporate tax return.
Union delegate from the Paris mail-sorting centers voted tonight to return to work following a sixweek strike that has totally disrupted the national postal and telecommunications systems.

The San Francisco Mima Troupe, now at the Westside Theater on 43d Street as part of Chelsea's Westside World Series, is offering in repertory its praised production of Bertolt Brecht's "The Mother" with a completely original work, 'The Great Air Robbery." which is written, directed and performed by the troupe itself.
A West Haven man was charged tonight in a shoot-out early today in which one man died and five others were injured.
The military junta in ethiopia elected a new chairman today to replace Lieut Gen. Aman Michael Andom, who is said to have died while resisting arrest during a military power struggle Saturday.
After lying for 11 years as a pile of stones, the Temple of Dendur, New York's adopted Egyptian monument, is about to become a building again.
The Cabinet of South Vietnam was realigned today with the addition of littleknown members while teen-age Roman Catholic demonstrators clashed fitfully with the police.

The United States dollar scored some gains on international money markets today while the price of gold declined. Dollar gains came in Frankfurt, Zurich, Paris and Milan. Declines were registered in Amsterdam, Tokyo and some Scandinavian markets.
The atmosphere on the Rutgers University Forum, New Jersey's oldest talk show, is so friendly that one guest leaned into the microphone in the middle of a show and said, "Well, off the record."

Marvin Barnes agreed today to return to action with the Spirits of St. Louis, and the American Basketball Association team agreed to assist him in solving any financial problems he may face. The rookie center, who walked out on the team and his $2.1-million contract last week, met with the club president, Harry Weltman, at the Spirits' offices.

Some say that there's been a revolution in the care of the retarded. They point to remarkable programs with new teaching techniques that promise to help retarded children lead productive lives. They see the institution, once a primary solution, now in retreat, as emphasis on community life for the retarded comes to the fore.
Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon ordered today the mobilization of the National. Guard in an effort to cut down on a wave of sabotage connected with the strike of waterworks personnel.
Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has asked United States District Judge John J. Sirica to reduce the sentence of John W. Dean 3d, former white House counsel.
The Rev. Pedro Arrupe, superior general of the Society of Jesus, said today that his order needed to undergo a "profound, objective, open" examination of its situation.
Pinball machines installed in two student cafeterias at City College in the spring of 1973 have sparked something of a craze among a small but growing and devoted following.

To make the recreational facilities of Long Island Sound more available to the public, a federally financed study has concluded that it would be easier and cheaper to build artificial islands in the Sound than for governmental agencies to purchase shoreline properties.

MISHIMA, By John Nathan. 300 pages Little Brown. $8.95. In 1970, Yukio Mishima, Japan's best-known living novelist, committed harakiri by driving a short sword into his left side and drawing it across his body to the right . When he slumped froward, one of his specially trained "cadets" attempted to behead him, as he had been instructed to do, with a long sword.

Margaretta Rockefeller left the hospital yesterday, three day after undergoing surgery for the removal of her right breast following the discovery of cancer. "I feel great, I am thankful," said Mrs. Rockefeller, whose left breast was removed six weeks ago.
The President summoned his communications chief to the main house and began a verbal assault: the telephone lines were not working, the President shouted. Why not?

Secretary General Waldheim said in Cairo at the end of his Middle East talks that unless there was a breakthrough in negotiations, war might break out by next spring or early summer. He said his visit had helped the Syrians and Israelis. to delay a showdown.

George Washington in the New Jersey Boxing Hall of Fame? Don't laugh; the first president hasn't been voted in yet but there's a chance he might be some year soon. "Washington, as we all know," says Adrian Bailey, who organized, the Hall of Fame six years ago, "spent a good deal of time in New Jersey. But what many people don't know is that he was an amateur boxer.
In the National Football League some teams are tired, some are hurt, some are getting better, some worse and some going nowhere as the season comes down to the last three
President and Mrs. Ford celebrated their first Thanks-giving in the White House With a reunion of the president's Grand Rapids high school football teammates.
Thousands of players from all parts of North America began arriving here tonight, eager for battle in the Fall National Bridge Championships, which begin tomorrow.

Four years ago in a speech to his fellow members of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, Norman B. Norman, chairman of Norman, Craig Kummel, suggested that since the big management counseling concerns were increasingly nudging into the agencies' sphere of influence, perhaps they should join the association.

With feed grain supplies now at one of their lowest levels since World War II, the nation's pork and poultry farmers are again reducing production, and the cattle feeders have made another big cutback in the animals they are fattening.

Clint Longley, whom an awful lot of people had never heard of, threw a 50-yard touchdownn pass to Drew Pearson with 28' seconds left in the game today, and that spectacular play enabled the Dallas Cowboys to beat the Washington Redskins, 24-23.
About 2,000 veterans staged a demonstration here today in supportt of the present Constitution, which has recently come under increasing criticism.

The Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold, has decided to join an investigation into conflict-of-interest allegations against Joseph Monserrat, a member of the Board of Education, according to aides of Mr. Gold.

On a shelf behind Mayor Beame's mahogany desk in City Hall is a telephone console with 10 buttons. Each button is marked with the name of a city official. To be enshrined in one of those tiny plastic cubes is more than status: is places one at the center of things in running the city.

On a shelf behind Mayor Beame's mahogany desk in City Hall is a telephone console with 10 buttons. Each button is marked with the name of a city official. To be enshrined in one of those tiny plastic cubes is more than status: it places one at the center of things in running the city.
Rick Martin scored his 15th goal of the season and assisted in two other scores tonight, as the Buffalo Sabres. defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 5-2, in a National Hockey League game.

The State Health Department has drafted sweeping changes in the state's Hospital Code, including specific requirements for emergency rooms and outpatient facilities, intensive-care and coronary units, surgical areas and regulations on the use of radioisotopes.

Margaret Thatcher, the Conservative party's spokesman on economic' affairs, conceded today that she has been storing up canned food for years and said that' "I regard it as no more than prudent housekeeping.

In the course of an hour or so yesterday afternoon, about a dozen people in various' parts of Manhattan reporting fires by pulling a lever in a street. box alarm, pushing a button in a new stainless steel alarm post, phoning the Fire Department or dialing 911.

Morristown completed its second straight unbeaten season and offered strong credentials for a bid to the state playoffs yesterday when it defeated Dover, 55-0, before more than 5,000 fans in Morristown. .

President 1di Amin today dismissed his Foreign Minister, Elizabeth Bagaya, saying that she had made love with a,European in a toilet at the Paris Airport and had had contacts with British and American intelligence.

Harry G. Fromberg, a retired Brooklyn Republican politics, died Tuesday at the Jewish Institute for Geriatric Care, New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 85 years old and lived at 945 East 10th Street, Brooklyn.

Trick plays set up three thirdquarter touchdowns today and lifted the Denver Broncos to a 31-27 NationalFpotball League victory over the Detroit Lions that virtually destroyed Detroit's playoff hopes. The loss was only the second in the last eight games for the Lions but dropped their won-lost record to 6.6.

Cardinal Hayes's Tony Al?? put the finishing touches on a brilliant two year, high school career yesterday while leading the Cardinals over Mount St. Michael, 20-0, in the 32d meeting of the two schools. s.
Cleveland's high-scoring guard, Austin Carr, scored 32 points tonight as the Cavaliers overtook the Philadelphia 76ers for a 110103 National Basketball Association victory.

HYDERABAD, India-A bundle of 12-foot uranium fuel rods was exhibited here recently, dangling from a crane at the new Nuclear Fuel Complex where it was made. Only its "enriched" uranium content had to be imported.

While both Government and Opposition leaders are saying that the Opposition's recent election victories were a major step toward restoration of democratic government, the nation's hopes for change in the wake of its first free elections in a decade. are tempered by fears of a backlash.

Dr. Robert M. White, the head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administra tion, has been selected to receive the 1974 Rockefeller Public Service Award for the Development and Protection of Physical: Resources.

Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany has proposed a "code of good behavior" for huge multinational corporations doing business in his country and in the United States, a code to be broadened later to include all of Europe.

Americans celebrated Thanks-giving in a variety of ways, In Peking, Secretary of State Kissinger dined on shredded duck instead of the traditional bird, but his hosts tried to make up for this by having an orchestra play "Turkey in the Straw."

A Troy, N. Y., man jailed on murder charges in the death last Feb. 2 of his 8-month-old son was freed after his wife admitted to the police that she had falsely accused him of placing the infant in a bathtub of scalding water. The accused man, 26-year-old Menir Abdelshahid, maintained that the boy had slipped beneath the water when he was left unattended briefly.

Soma Suzanne Golden and William Alexander Behr were married yesterday at noon in the garden of the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin E. Golden, in Washington. Rabbi Eugene J. Lipman performed the ceremony.

Gladys Tibbetts Steinkraus, widow of Herman W. Steinkraus, who headed the Bridgeport Brass Company, died Wednesday at Westport, Conn. Mrs. Steinkraus, an artist and photographer, also operated the Westport- Moorland Kennel.
An apparent earthquake rolled through the San Francisco Bay area today. There were no immediate reports of serious damage.

October sales in the country's leading chain store organizations rose 12.6 per cent over the level of October 1973, accordto Chain Store Age magazine. For the first 10 months of 1974, sales rose by a margin of 11.7 per cent compared to the year before.

Secretary of State Kissinger told his Chinese hosts tonight that he had achieved "a better understanding" of their viewpoint on his visit here and would take it "seriously into account in conducting our foreign policy."

President Ford, in a shift economic perspective with major policy implications, now believes the widespread concern about a recession requires the same top priority he had previously reserved for the problem of inflation, ranking aides indicated today.
Iona Prep and White Plains registered victories yesterday in traditional games. Iona defeated New Rochelle for the eighth straight year, 3212, as the Gaels-scored two

The owner-trainer team of Sigmund Sommer and Frank (Pancho) Martin contributed the chief item of entertainment at Aqueduct yesterday. Free Hand, running under their sponsorship, won the $56,300 Queens County Handicap in a surprising result.
Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria appealed today to Ethiopla's military rulers to spare the lives of Emperor Haile Selassie, his family and. other political prisoners.
The body of a young woman found today near this Schoharie County community was identified this evening as that of a college student from Long Island who was last seen on Nov. 2.
Broadway ticket brokers almost as scarce these days as tickets to a hit show, are bracing for a good season and a possible renaissance that would recall the days when they ruled the Rialto.

The Chicago Board Options Exchange, riding a new wave of investor interest in what used to be known as "puts" and "calls," announced yesterday that its new $2.5-million trading floor would be opened on Monday.
Cleveland's high-scoring guard, Austic Carr, scored 32 points tonight as the Cavaliers overtook the Philadelphia 76ers for a 110-103 National Basketball Association victory.
Union delegates from the Paris mail-sorting centers voted tonight to return to work following a sixweek strike that has totally disrupted the national postal and telecommunications systems.

Michael Lorimer, one of the guitar's bright young evangelists, returned to Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night in furtherance of his mission. At the age of 29, the lanky Californian has reached an impressive standard of musicianship and technical command. But, as his recital suggested, he has arrived at a rather dangerous level in his career.
Secretary General Waldheim is convinced that a new. Arab-Israeli war may well break out by next spring or early summer unless a breakthrough in Middle East negotiations is achieved.
Two girls from the Dominican Republic, born joined at the pelvis, were discharged from Children's Hospital today.

Libya, the North African nation that in 1970 was the first petroleum-exporting state to expose the vulnerability of oil companies and consuming countries to price and production pressure, is now producing only slightly more than 1 million barrels of oil a day compared with 3.7 million in 1970.

To make the recreational facilities of Long Island Sound more available to the public, a federally financed study has concluded that it would be easier and cheaper to build artificial islands in the Sound than for governmental agencies to purchase shoreline properties.

The New York City Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Elinor C. Guggenheimer, warned that some fish dyed with vegetable dye and flavored to pass as smoked salmon-the Iox of the world famous delicacy bagel and Iox--was a German fish known as saithe, or seelach.
Robert Bruce Coleman Jr., former 'drama critic for The NewYork Daily Mirror, died Wednesday at Medical Arts Center Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 20 West 64th Street.
Rick Martin scored his 15th goal-of the season and assisted in two other scores tonight, as the Buffalo Sabres defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 5-2, in a National Hockey League game.
To many scientists the most significant advance in understanding how heat can be used to drive engines was made a century and a half ago--and ignored for a full generation.
A 35-year-old man with a record of arrests was found shot to death early yesterday in the basement garage of the apartment house where he lived, at 61-45 98th Street, Rego Park, Queens.
Ron Atanasio scored after 10 seconds of play today as Adelphi University advanced to the National Collegiate Division II soccer final with a 3-0 victory over Federal City College of Washington.
Senator Peter H. Dominick, Republican of Colorado, has been approached about becoming Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, The Washington Star-News reported today.

Officials expressed relief today over the United Nations vote saving the seat for the Government of Marshal Lon Nol for another year. Nervous wealthy people, black-market merchants and high Government officials who have been making huge profits from the war also relaxed a little with the knowledge that they can continue their activities.

Archbishop Makarios of Cyprus arrives here tomorrow for talks with the Greek Government on the Cyprus issue, before his first return to the island since last summer, when he was ousted as President in an abortive coup.
Brick Township completed in undefeated regular season Yesterday with a 14-6 victory ever Toms River North in Toms River and moved close For a South Jersey, Group 4 playoff berth.
Official of the Federal Aviation Administration were searching a runway at Kellogg Airport today for portions of a Navy plane that crashed yesterday, killing all five men aboard.

Sheila Loretta Farkas, a director of projects for Programming Methods, a division of General Telephone Electronics, was married yesterday to Robert Gideon Abbott, director of research and development with Yourdan, Inc., computer software consultants.
A former intelligence officer in Japan's old imperial army who did out in a Philippine jungle for 30 years is disenchanted and having difficulty adjusting to a new life after a gap of three decades.

Population growth in the United States is now below 1 per cent a year and approaching zero, according to a United Nations report.

Every day we read reams of words on the energy crisis, the recession, and their national and international effects. But I've read little about the impact of these problems on the world's greatest city. The fact is that these crises are greatly accelerating New York's social and economic problems.

With every mail bringing fresh horror stories from readers caught in 'the collapse of good restaurants recommended in this column, I feel reluctant to pull the rug out from under Chez Michel, an extremely agreeable spot that has been in operation for two months now at 808 Lexington Avenue.

The 10-day strike by the faculties at New Jersey's eight state colleges ended-at least temporarily - when the teachers agreed early this morning to an offer by Governor Byrne to mediate their demands for higher salaries and increased benefits.

Hawaii's sugar worker will be begin voting next week at 16 plantations on a share-the-profits proposal that, if ratified, will bring them about $38-million in added wages and bonuses over the next 26 months.

Aides of Governor-elect Hugh L. Carey said yesterday that he would propose legislation to restore full home rule to New York City on apartment-rent matters, thus enabling the Beame administration to pursue its goal of abolishing the controversial maximum-base-rent system of limiting rents in controlled apartments here.
Earlier this year the youth newspaper, Komsomolskaya Pravda, ran an expose of a professional soccer team in the Siberian city of Bratsk that was masquerading as a n amateur club.

Joe Paterno's 10th game as Penn State's head football coach turned into a totally satisfying experience for the 47-year-old Brooklyn native as his Nittany Lions rallied from a 7-6 half-time deficit and routed Pittsburgh, 31-10, tonight.
A 63-year-old woman on a pension has won a battle to prevent the East Bay Municipal Utilities District from cutting her check by 60 cents a month.

In Cleveland, Mayor Ralph J. Perk is planning to lay off 1,104 city employes on Jan. 1. Of them, 312 are policemen and firemen. Pioneer li stepped up its picture-taking and light measurements today as it sped closer to the giant planet of Jupiter. The unmanned craft was sweeping up from below Jupiter for its close approach Monday night under Jupiter's south pole.

Linda Smith, an English major at Stony Brook University, will have the rail position with Nightly Scott in the first Canadian-American college-student harness driving championship pace at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.
Felix A. Bonami, a retired electrical engineer, died yesterday at Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived at 131 Deer Track Lane, Irvington, N.Y.

The French National Assembly early this morning passed a bill legalizing abortion through the 10th week of pregnancy. The vote, after-three days of heated debate, came at 3:40 A.M., Paris time (9:40 P.M. Thursday, New York time.) In favor were 284 Deputies, 38 more than the necessary majority of 246. There were 189 votes against the measure and 17 abstentions or absences.

Thomas A. Edison College, New Jersey's experimental "school without walls," is preparing to implement its new four-year Bachelor of Arts program, which was recently approved by the state.

Richard. C. Gerstenberg, Chairman of General Motors,'predicts that his company will not have any major price increases in the near future and has joined other top executives in urging the Ford Administration to help the auto industry out of its severe sales slump.
A moving van toppled and crushed a pedestrian to death yesterday in Brooklyn after the van and a can collided at an intersection with a defective traffic light, according to the police.

What will provoke civil strife and build a formidable long-run threat to the ruling Provisional Military Council is a continuation of the bloodbath.

This winter I shall try Isabella Beeton's recipe for jugged hare. Mrs. Beeton, an Englishwoman born in 1836, the eldest of 21 children, was only 21 years old when she began work on her monumental "Beeton's Book of Household Management," which is still the best-selling cookbook of all time.

Jay Hammond, the Republican challenger, has unseated Gov. William Egan by 287 votes, a recount of ballots cast in the Nov. 5 general election showed today.

The surprise Ford-Brezhnev agreement setting numerical limits on strategic offensive missiles and bombers does not "put a cap on the arms race," as Secretary of State Kissinger claims. On the contrary, it would authorize both sides to go ahead with their planned build-ups. Costs and instabilities are likely to increase.
Westfield virtually clinched a North Jersey, Section 2, Group 4 playoff berth yesterday by defeating Plainfield, 31-14, behind a brilliant performance by Glen Kehler before 10,500 fans in Plainfield.

To the Editor: The most frequent justification of the fourfold price increase of OPEC's oil is the sharp rise in the price of basic industrial and agricultural products that oil producers have to import from the advanced countries. Quite recently a senior Arab official said during the Rabat conference: "If the West is quadrupling the price of basic food supplies, we quadruple the price of our oil. What is the difference?" (news story, Nov. 4).
A Japanese naval task force of planes, destroyesrs and a submarine tried today for the first time since World War II to sink a ship--a crippled, burning tanker.

The Hofstra locker room, was furious this morning, while Coach Howard (Howdy) Myers calmly waited outside on his last day as the school's football coach. "See what they say about us." screamed a player as he tore apart a cradboard sign that read," No hope for Hofstra."
Idle coal miners began receiving copies today of a proposed new contract that is expected to end the nationwide strike by the 120,000- member United Mine Workers union. union.

Ken Koval scored with 3 minutes 55 seconds left to give East Meadow an 18-15 victory over Uniondale yesterday at Uniondale In one of four Nassau County games.

When Dr. Christian N. Barnard makes surgical rounds at Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town, South Africa, now, he interprets separate electrocardiograms of two hearts--one beating three times as fast as the other- in the same patient, the heart transplant pioneer said in a telephone interview.

Secretary General Waldheim said in Cairo at the end of his Middle East talks that unless there was a breakthrough in negotiations, war might break out by next spring or early summer. He said his visit had helped the Syrians and Israelis to delay a showdown.

Two policemen drove up to a women's apparel Store here today and went inside to investigate a ringing burglar alarm. After finding nothing missing from the shop, they returned outside and discovered that their patrol car was gone.

Tomorrow is the 100th anniversary of the birth of Sir Winston Churchill, and television is not without its share of tributes. Aside from recently writing some provocatively misguided articles on the British leader, Richard Burton plays Churchill in "The Gathering Storm," which can be seen at 8:30 this evening on NBC.

Deborah Ellen Steinberg, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward L. Steinberg of Long Beach, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Michael Brownstein, son of Joseph Brownstein of Long Island City, Queens, and the late Mrs. Brownstein.
A Federal judge says I.Q. tests must not be given to black children in California if the tests do not reflect the cultural background of the students.

The Soviet Union, hitherto publicly pleased with the results of Leonid I. Brezhnev's meeting in Valdivostok with President Ford, today showed its first uneasiness at criticism in Washington of the understanding the two leaders reached on limiting offensive nuclear arms arsenals.

A cyclone swept through Bangladesh today knocking down homes with 100-mile an hour winds and leaving thousands of people homeless. Four islands off Bangladesh were swept by a tidal wave, and the fate of thousands of islanders was uncertain.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 29--University of Pittsburgh, which faced a financial crisis in the mid-nineteen-sixties, has accumulated enough funds to pay off $27.7-million in debts. Chancellor Wesley W. Posvar announced recently that Pitt had put into escrow the final $6-million, to be paid to the Equitable Life Assurance Society on April 1, 1976.

The producer-director combination of Stuart Ostrow and Bob Fosse, whose musical "Pippin" has been a Broadway resident since October, 1972, to the cheerful tune of more than $2.1-million in net profits, have joined forces as a movie team for the first time.

The marriage of Ann Wooster Bedell, a doctoral candidate in architectural history at Columbia University, to Cameron Farquhar MacRae 3d, deputy superintendent and counsel of the New York State Banking Department, took place yesterday afternoon at Governor's Harbour, Eleuthera, the Bahamas.

Manuel Fernade Magelahaes, editor of the Lourenco Marques newspaper A Tribuna, was arrested and forced to board a Portuguese airliner to Lisbon on Thursday, the daily Noticias de Beira reported today.

Ninety-one countries will participate in the tournament to determine the 16 soccer teams that will compete in the Olympic Games in Montreal. The amateur committee of the In ternational Soccer Federation, other wise known as F.I.F.A., declined to accept late entries last Friday when the committee held a meeting in Zurich to finalize plans for the 1976 Olympic tournament.

Leon Rochefort, Bobby Lalonde and Greg Boddy scored goals to back Gary Smith's 27-save shutout as the Vancouver Canucks scored a 3-0 victory over the New York Islanders in a National Hockey League game tonight.

Mike Kruczek set a national season passing record and Keith Barnette, a fullback, crashed for his 21st and 22d touchdowns of the season today as Boston College routed Holy Cross, 38-6. The Eagles were in command all the way in rolling to their sixth consecutive victory.

The Knicks will meet two top teams In the National Basketball Association's PacificDivision in Madison Square Garden. They play the Los Angeles. Lakers Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. and Bill Walton and the Portland Trail Blazers Saturday at 8 o'clock.
The People's Pipewatch--started last June to determine which industries are polluting the Hudson River and how--Has something of a mystery on its hands:
Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield will sponsor a seminar on self breast examinations on Dec. 9. It will be held at the Scotch Plains Library, starting at 10 A.M.

Continued evidence of serious recession has altered the public stance of the Ford Administration, whose officials are now addressing that problem with attention at least equal to their concern over inflation.

Bernie Ebersole, safety, and Curt Morgan, a linebacker, turned intercepted passes into second-half touchdowns today to lead Delaware to a 35-14 victory over Youngstown in a college football playoff game.
The New Jersey Society of Certified Public Accountants will hold its 1974 Scholarship Awards Examination on Dec. 14 and 15.

A report recommending the creation of preventive mental-health programs in Bergen County schools is under revision because of a lack of active support by county mental health and school agencies and a shortage of available funds.

The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of Dec. 2, 1973. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from earlier issues of the Book Review.
Except for a shovelful of earth that was dug up on a rainy day in October, a peaceful, 10acre segment of oak-andhemlock woods north of here has been little disturbed for ages.
